Criticizing the surveillance systems’ quality, the councillors pointed out to several incidents of travellers who visited corona-affected countries not coming under the surveillance of the authorities.

In one such an incident in Pottakkuzhi, a youth who returned from Italy three or four days ago hadn't reported about his travel history to the health authorities. On Tuesday, the division councillor who came to know about it, informed health officials. “I informed the health department officials. There are many such incidents,” said Jimini, councillor from Pottakkuzhi division.

“A couple from the area, had come in the flight with the family in Pathanamthitta (some of who have been tested positive for the virus) on February 29. Following reports that some of the members of the Pathanamthitta family who returned home from Italy and tested positive for Covid-19, the couple from Pottakkuzhi contacted me,” Jimini said.

“The couple had come home to meet the husband’s ailing father. Two days after they reached home, the father died, and hundreds visited home for paying their respects to him. I informed about the development to the health department officials. Now, the wife has been admitted to the isolation ward of Government Medical College, Ernakulam for flu,” Jimini said.

The councillors said similar cases have been reported from other parts of the city. “A few days ago, a youth returned home to Fort Kochi from Italy. He is the son of a sexton in Fort Kochi and he and his family members failed to inform the neighbours about his arrival. When we came to know about it, we informed the health department. Now, the youth is under surveillance,” said K J Antony, opposition leader, Kochi Corporation.

Health standing committee chairperson Pratibha Ansari said some more councillors have brought similar issues to her notice. “I have passed on the details to the health department,” Ansari said.

Antony Francis, a councillor from Chullickal, said there were several people who have returned from locations such as Italy and Jerusalem. “The authorities are in the dark about the details of such travellers. Though I sought the details of such patients from health department, they said don’t have it,” Francis said.

Similarly, there were reports that a group of 40-odd people from Vaduthala returned from Italy a few days ago. However, the councillor from the division said the group didn’t visit Italy. “They visited places like Jerusalem. On Monday, a team of health officials visited them. Officials said that none of them have shown the symptoms of the disease,” said O P Sunil, councillor from Vaduthala.

Title: IT cos take preventive measures
Content: Kochi: Several IT companies in the city have cut down on travel, shifted meetings to virtual mode and have extended work-from-home option to a wider number of employees as a precautionary measure against Covid-19 The two-day #Future, a digital summit scheduled to be held in Kochi on April 2 and 3, is also likely to be postponed against the backdrop of pandemic scare.“There is a high chance of it being postponed. But we are looking an alternative option as it gives us an opportunity to push for a virtual summit since the event is all about digital. As of now, we have not taken any decision,” said chief minister’s IT fellow Arun Bala.Bala said postponing the event is problematic since all global speakers have confirmed and already six months of efforts have gone behind organizing it. “Since a virtual summit is technologically possible, we are weighing the options,” he said.Infopark Kochi CEO Sasi P M said many companies have cut down on travel and asked their staff to work from home . “We are continuously in touch with the health department and are passing on all directives by them to companies. We are also undertaking measures like fumigation on the campus, said Sasi.“Many companies are placing hand sanitizers in the reception and have made wearing of masks mandatory,” said Aneesh of Progressive Techies, a welfare organization of IT employees. HR departments of IT firms are also organizing events to create awareness on Covid-19. tnn

Title: More ambulances to be pressed into service
Content: Kochi: A meeting convened by district collector S Suhas on Tuesday decided to press more ambulances into service for shifting persons with symptoms of Covid-19 to Government Medical College, Ernakulam. It was also decided to take urgent measures to ensure that all safety and sanitation facilities are being provided to drivers of ambulances, which are engaged in transporting persons with suspected cases.As of now, there are around five ambulances, which transport persons with symptoms of Covid-19 from Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial) to the medical college. The district collector said that the number of ambulances used for the purpose would be increased. Five more ambulances will be pressed into service. On Tuesday, TOI had carried an article which highlighted the situation where unsanitized ambulances were being used for shifting persons with symptoms of Covid-19. The report had also explained the difficulties faced by the ambulance drivers. “Now, only one person will be transported to the medical college at a time, so that persons with Covid-19 symptoms won’t come in contact with each other. Besides, more facilities to ensure the safety and hygiene of ambulance drivers will be provided,” said Suhas. But the authorities didn’t heed to the demand for sanitizing the ambulances after each trip. “It is very difficult to sanitize the vehicles after each trip. The vehicles would be sanitized whenever a case is tested positive,” Suhas said.Kerala Government Drivers Association leaders had sent a complaint to the district collector seeking immediate measures to ensure proper sanitization of the ambulances after each trip. The drivers said that the cleaning of ambulances was entrusted with an agency, which has been assigned with the duty of sanitizing aircrafts at Cial. “The employees working with the agency won’t be available for cleaning ambulances while aircrafts wait for sanitizing. So, it may take one or two days, in certain cases, to get the ambulances sanitized,” they said in the complaint. The drivers demanded a dedicated agency for cleaning the ambulances.The drivers, who are deployed for the duty continuously, are not given any special uniforms, PPE kit and N 95 masks. They also had complained that there is no space for ambulance parking at Cial. “Drivers wait under the shades of trees outside the airport,” they said.

Title: Telangana high court picks holes in speed governors’ sale; issues notice to government, dealers
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Tuesday issued notices to the state government and transport commissioner wondering why bank guarantee was reduced from Rs 1 crore to Rs 5 lakh for dealers who were authorised to procure and fix speed governors for heavy commercial vehicles.

Justice Abhinand Kumar Shavili also issued notices to 16 dealers and sought answers from them within two weeks while hearing a petition from a manufacturer of speed governors.

PVA Padmanabham, counsel for the petitioner, said the government was claiming that it was a policy decision without first explaining the grounds upon which it fixed Rs 1 crore guarantee initially and reduced it to Rs 5 lakh a few weeks ago all of a sudden. “People who do not have adequate facilities to procure and fix the speed governors are also given the task of fitting them,” he argued.

The case will come up for hearing after two weeks.

The counsel said while new vehicles that are being sold have in-built speed governors, for the vehicles that are operating the Centre had fixed certain parameters. These define the type of speed governor to be fitted and the dealer who would fix it.

A Supreme Court committee headed by Justice Radhakrishnan had imposed fool-proof encrypting methods to ensure that the same speed governor purchase receipt would not be used for multiple vehicles. Also, details of all such vehicles which were fitted with speed governors should be uploaded into the Centre’s Vahan data website.

Though Telangana does not follow the Vahan data mode, it has issued a notification for implementing Rule 118 of the Central Motor Vehicle Rules which make speed governors mandatory.

However, some manufacturers argued problems arose with the entry of middlemen into the trade who started dictating terms. The price of a speed governor is between Rs 1,800 and Rs 2,000. However, Rs 6000 and above was charged per each speed governor.

“It was these middlemen who were instrumental in getting the specific guarantee performance to be furnished by select dealers reduced to Rs 5 lakh from Rs 1 crore,” the manufacturers said.

When the bank guarantee was Rs 1 crore, there were only three dealers. Thanks to the drastic reduction in the bank guarantee amount, the number of dealers who were selected has gone up to 17. “But, the price of speed governor remained at Rs 6,000 and above,” they contended.

The manufacturers alleged that money minted in this manner would cross Rs 140 crore, going by the number (3.5 lakh) of commercial vehicles in Telangana which are operating sans speed governors.

Title: Scrap 1-min rule at Inter exam centre: PIL
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: An advocate filed a PIL in the Telangana high court on Tuesday, urging the court to scrap a circular issued by the Telangana State Board of Intermediate Education ( TSBIE ) on disallowing students from taking the exam if they are late even by a minute.

The Intermediate public exams start at 9 am and students entering the exam centre at 9.01 am are also not allowed inside as per the new rule.

The petitioner said, in his plea, that TSBIE had brought this ‘one-minute late rule’ without taking into consideration the practical problems. “This rule is adversely affecting the students and their future. Hence, it deserves to be quashed,” he contended.

His counsel Abhilasha made a mention before a bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy informing it about their petition and sought an urgent hearing on the ground that the rule was adversely affecting poor students, who were not able to make it to the examination centres on time and late by a few minutes.

The bench asked the counsel to complete the process of filing the plea before making a mention. The petition was later filed. Bhaskar told the media later that they would make a mention before the bench on Wednesday again with a request to take up the case as poor students were adversely hit on account of the rule.

“There are certain things like bad roads, ill health, distress at home, etc., which are not in the hands of the students,” he said. Added to this, the board was locating the exam centres far away from the colleges of the students. “Also, there are mistakes pertaining to communication printed on hall-tickets,” he said.

He said the board should concentrate more on creating awareness among students on the need to arrive early. “Though it spoke about a mobile application that helps the students and their parents locate the exam centres, not many parents know about it,” he said.

“More over, the one minute late rule has no legal basis,” he added.

Title: No rift with DMDK over RS seat, says min Raju
Content:
Madurai: Stating that there is no misunderstanding between AIADMK and their key ally DMDK over the allotment of Rajya Sabha seat , information and publicity minister Kadambur C Raju said it was the media that gave a ‘twisted’ version of the news.

He was responding to a question on whether there was dissatisfaction in the DMDK camp, that has a bigger cadre base, over allotting the seat to TMC leader G K Vasan.

Raju told reporters in Kovilpatti that there was no agreement with any of their alliance parties regarding the RS seat unlike the one they had with the PMK.

“Decision for the RS seat was taken by the chief minister and deputy chief minister as deputy coordinator and coordinator of the AIADMK,” he said and added that there has not been any statement from them (DMDK) and there is no need to clarify on this. If a situation arose they (DMDK) will be called for talks.

On the accident that claimed the lives of three people on the sets of Kamal Hassan-starrer ‘Indian 2’, the minister said his department is conducting tripartite talks with the producers’ council and crew members.

He expressed confidence that the outcome of the series of meetings would help avert such accidents in future and that the government alone cannot act on it. Backing Kamal’s statement, the minister said that “we have learnt a lesson” from the crane accident that left three people dead.

Title: Curbs issued on mass gatherings in Kerala amid coronavirus outbreak
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With eight more persons testing positive for Covid-19, the government has enforced strict restrictions on mass gatherings in the state. It has been decided to close all educational institutions , except medical colleges , in the state till March 31. However, there will be no change in the examination schedules.Announcing the decisions taken at the specially convened cabinet meeting here on Tuesday, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the state is on alert mode and hence there is a need for taking adequate precautions.At present, 14 positive cases are admitted in various hospitals in Pathanamthitta, Kottayam and Ernakulam. The parents of the three-year-old kid, who was declared positive on Monday, tested positive. The results from the National Institute of Virology were made available on Tuesday evening. All three are now isolated in Ernakulam Medical College Hospital.Among the other new cases reported on Tuesday, four are in Kottayam and two in Pathanamthitta. All six persons contracted the virus from the three of a family from Ranni who had travelled from Italy.“The restrictions are to check the spread of the virus. It has become evident that the virus has spread from the three people who had come from Italy to Pathanamthitta. Hence it is the time to take adequate precautions,” the CM said.The people who had gone to receive the Pathanamthitta family from the airport have also tested positive. Two are the daughter and son-in-law of the 54-year-old father. In addition, the parents of the man also tested positive. These two elderly persons have been placed in the high-risk category as they suffer from several pre-existing health conditions.Efforts are on to save the lives of the two. All four are at Kottayam Medical College Hospital.In Pathanamthitta, the two new cases were reported from people who had come into close contact with the Ranni family. These two have been isolated at a hospital in Kozhencherry. A two-year-old kid who had come in close contact with the family has also been categorized as high-risk.Health minister K K Shailaja, in a press conference, said the daunting task of mapping the people who had come in contact with the primary positive cases is continuing. “Only once this is complete could we say that we have achieved the target of the first phase. Then the second phase to find out the people who had secondary and tertiary contacts with the primary cases has to be completed,” she said.All schools and colleges, including professional colleges, in the state will remain closed till March 31. This will be applicable also to CBSE and ICSE schools. Examinations from class l to class VII will not be held. All tuition classes, entrance coaching centres and other special classes have been asked to shut down till the month end.The CM has urged all religious heads and institutions to organize festivals and other rituals without mass gatherings. All government functions have been suspended till March 31.The Union health ministry sanctioned testing facilities at Kozhikode and Thiruvananthapuram MCHs. The state government has sought approval for such centres in Kochi and Kannur as well.

Title: Covid-19: Plan to screen domestic passengers at Hyderabad airport put on hold
Content: HYDERABAD: The state health department has decided to purchase two standing thermal screening kits to be used at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) for better screening of international passengers. While the state had requested the Centre for the equipment, it decided to go ahead with the purchase since the Centre did not respond. Meanwhile, the plan for screening of domestic passengers will remain on hold for now.“Since we had limited staff and equipment for screening, we decided to purchase the kits,” said Eatala Rajender, state health minister. “Also, 200 staff members have now been deputed (in three shifts) at the airport so that the screening is thorough. As for domestic screening, we have approached the Centre, but did not get any response. But as long as all states are having an intensive screening of international passengers, it won’t be much of a problem if domestic screening is not taken up immediately.”In addition to the existing nCovid-19 testing facility at ICMR lab in Gandhi Medical College, the Centre has approved testing at Osmania General Hospital (OGH), and will consider allowing testing at Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM), the minister said.He also said that the first patient who tested positive for nCovid-19 in the state (24-year-old software professional) is likely to be discharged in the next four days, since he has already tested negative once. A confirmatory test is awaited from National Institute of Virology , Pune.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: Health checks mark Mayapur Gour Purnima celebrations
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Gour Purnima, the biggest festival of Iskcon , was celebrated at its headquarters in Mayapur with a lot of caution on Monday, thanks to the coronavirus scare. Since nearly a lakh devotees had gathered for the celebrations, many of them foreign devotees, a massive medical screening was arranged for each of them under the directions of the state government.

Chief minister Mamata Banerjee had asked the Kolkata centre of Iskcon for details of the medical arrangements. Accordingly, a doctor from the state health services, Malabika Paul, has been deputed for five days at Mayapur to oversee the work of the internal medical team. This team has three doctors — Soumik Debnath, Lipika Sharma and Santosh Roy. The district magistrate and his team have also been co-ordinating with the Iskcon authorities.

A statement from Mayapur said that all foreign devotees who have come in for the celebrations after January 1 have been screened. The Chinese devotees were asked not to fly in and there were a large number of cancellations from them voluntarily. A dedicated Facebook page has also been set up by the Iskcon Mayapur authorities that carry all the directives regarding precautions that have been taken and need to be taken.

“Notice boards have been set up at prominent places to spread awareness among the devotees,” said Subrata Das, spokesperson of Iskcon Mayapur.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Charred body of man found in Ramnad district
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The charred body of a middle aged man was found in a village near Ervadi in Ramanathapuram district on Tuesday. The body was exhumed and postmortem was conducted in the presence of revenue officials.

While the identity of the deceased person is not known yet, as the face was burnt beyond recognition, it is suspected that it could be that of Kumar from Chinna Ervadi village, who went missing a few days back.

A man missing FIR was registered with the Ervadi police station based on a complaint by Kumar’s father-in-law Muthumaniyan on Tuesday.

A police officer said that they received information regarding an abandoned scooter at a secluded place in Yendal village on Tuesday and a team was sent immediately.

The team found burial marks and informed higher officials. A team lead by district superintendent of police reached the spot. In the presence of higher officials and the VAO, a fully burnt body was exhumed.

“The body is fully burnt and we could not identify the deceased immediately. It is suspected to be Kumar’s body since his vehicle was found abandoned there. However, it can be confirmed through a DNA test,” an official said.

The motive behind the murder and perpetrators involved are yet to be ascertained.

Title: Four nabbed for stabbing drive inn employee over altercation
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Four persons, including three history sheeters , were apprehended by Banjara Hills police after they assaulted the staff of a drive inn and stabbed one of them, following an altercation over cigarette smoking on Monday night.

The accused have been identified as Amer and Ubaid Ansari, history sheeters at Mirchowk police station, Malik, history sheeter at Dabeerpura police station and their associate Mouzzam. According to inspector Kalinga Rao, the accused went to Kabara drive inn at road number 12 on Monday night and picked up an argument with a staff, Shiva, when he stopped Mouzzam from smoking.

“When the accused did not listen to Shiva, manager of the drive inn Rashid and later owner Arif tried to convince them. The accused started threatening the staff and assaulted Arif. One of the employees Pavan, who takes care of valet parking, came for the rescue of Arif. Amer attacked him with a knife, causing five stab injuries on his back and side. Arif also suffered a cut on his hand,” the inspector said. TNN

Title: Minister inaugurates road work in two wards
Content:
Madurai: Cooperative minister Sellur K Raju on Tuesday inaugurated road projects to be carried out at two places in the city. Roads will be relayed in six cross streets and main streets in Chockalinga Nagar in ward number 19 at a cost of Rs 1.25 crore. In total, roads will be re-layed for a total distance of around 2km with 4.5m width.

Talking to reporters, Raju said that already developmental work to the tune of Rs 1.67 crore has been completed. It includes sinking new borewells, re-laying roads and laying paver block roads. Seven works, including the one inaugurated on Tuesday estimated at a total cost of Rs 2.24 crore are under progress. He said that road works alone has been carried out to the tune of Rs 3.93 crore in this particular ward in the last one year.

The minister also inaugurated road work at a cost of Rs 20 lakh in Suseela Ranganathan Avenue in Muthupatti, which comes under ward 93.

A total of six road works at a cost of Rs 59 lakh have been completed in ward number 93 so far. Seven more are under way at a cost of Rs 1.56 crore.

He said that works are under way a war-footing to set right the portion of traffic Island, which caved in on Sunday during his inspection. The incident took place due to a leak in a sewer line, which resulted in erosion of soil underneath it, he said.

Title: Maharashtra caps Ola, Uber surge pricing at three times taxi fare, but defers rule till April 6
Content: MUMBAI: In a mixed bag for Ola-Uber users , the state government has capped the fares of app-based cabs at three times the fare of kaali-peeli taxis .At present, the fare of black-and-yellow taxis is fixed at Rs 14.84/km, so aggregator cab fare cannot surge over Rs 44.52/km even on days of very high demand. The usual fares of the aggregator cabs are much lower than that of Kaali-peelis.A government resolution issued on Monday also said that a minimum Re 1-Rs 2 fare hike can be allowed for autorickshaws and taxis subject to approval from the Mumbai Metropolitan Region Transport Authority (MMRTA).The GR is in line with most of the recommendations of the B C Khatua committee, which was set up by the previous BJP-Shiv Sena government to look into surge pricing by aggregators following demands from taxi unions and passengers.However, the government said it would not take any coercive steps against aggregator cab drivers till April 6, when Bombay high court is scheduled to hear a plea by aggregators against the City Taxi Scheme introduced by the previous government.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Poultry business hit hard, losses pegged at Rs 500 crore
Content: HYDERABAD: The poultry industry in the state has been hit hard amid rumours that the novel coronavirus can be transmitted through consumption of chicken, the prices of which have fallen considerably as a result.Since January 15, poultry industry in the state has incurred a loss of Rs 500 crore. While the chicken market has suffered a loss of around Rs 400 crore, egg traders incurred a loss of around Rs 100 crore. The numbers were released by Indian Poultry Equipment Manufacturers Association (IPEMA) on Tuesday. The Telangana Poultry Federation (TPF) said that losses have exceeded Rs 600 crore. As on date, the price of skinless chicken stands at Rs 100 per kg. The prices went down in February first week. “Even when there were no rumours about coronavirus, the average chicken price ranged from Rs 180 to Rs 200. In February last week, the price dropped to Rs 70 per kg. People in poultry business said they are selling live birds (broiler) for Rs 14 per kg.“We are selling live birds for Rs 14 per kg, there are no takers due to the rumours about the link between coronavirus and chicken and egg consumption being spread on Facebook and WhatsApp,” said Errabelli Pradeep Rao, president, TPF.Chakradhar Rao of IPEMA said that losses are only mounting. “I am not sure when the business will be back on track,” said.When TOI contacted chicken retail stores, they said that people are giving chicken and eggs a miss due to doubts.Meanwhile, several associations are planning to organise chicken melas. “We organised meals to bust myths, but things haven’t changed, but we want to leave no stone unturned,” said Pradeep Rao.

Title: Lungi sale: Textile store owner booked
Content:
Madurai: The city police have booked a proprietor of a textile store in Kamarajarpuram for selling ‘lungis’ illegally under the brand name of a popular company.

The unnamed proprietor has been booked under sections of the Trademark Act and Copyright Act based on a complaint received from a representative of the company from Chennai on Monday. Clement, the public relations officer (PRO) in his petition stated that lungis manufactured elsewhere were being sold in Varun Jyothi Textiles in Kamarajar Salai and a few other shops under their brand name. He sought action against the store owner and urged the police to stop using their brand name. It has resulted in bringing bad repute for their brand, he stated.

Deputy commissioner of police (headquarters) received the petition and ordered an inquiry. Police approached the trademark registry office in Guindy in Chennai seeking a report. Based on information received from an assistant registrar from the office, the case was registered. The Vilakkuthoon inspector of police Logeswari registered the FIR. Town Range assistant commissioner of police Surakumaran is conducting further inquiries.

Title: District collector directs AAI to strengthen screening at airport
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: District collector K Gopalakrishnan on Tuesday directed the Airports Authority of India (AAI) to strengthen the screening facility for passengers at the Trivandrum International Airport in view of the increasing threat of Covid-19 . A meeting held at the airport and chaired by the collector reviewed preparedness to deal with the crisis.The airport has a medical team, which functions round-the-clock, at both domestic and international terminals, working in three shifts.“The directives from civil aviation department should be followed strictly. It is noticed that some international travellers refuse to give samples. In such cases, sample can be collected forcefully,” said Gopalakrishnan.The collector also gave directions to install instruction boards at airport, railway stations and bus stands regarding Covid-19.AAI has advised all international airports to enhance universal screening of all arriving passengers and to provide more number of counters and equipment to reduce queues and waiting time last week.Around 2,000 passengers reach the international airport every day. Thermal scans for screening passengers are arranged at five health desks at the international terminal. Team of nine to twelve medical officials from AAI and state health department is working at the health desk.“There were three health desks when passenger screening was started at the airport and it has been increased to five. Also, the number of staff at health counters has been increased to handle the large number of passengers. More staff are available during night hours, when there are more flights. The international passengers are allowed to proceed towards immigration counter after thermal scanning. In case, a passenger shows symptoms of fever, cough or respiratory distress, they are taken for sample collection at a government hospital,” said an AAI official from medical wing at the international terminal.A health desk comprising a medical officer, health inspector and staff nurses are working at the domestic terminal. “The desk has been functioning at the domestic terminal for the past one month. The surveillance has been strengthened this week as more cases are reported from different states. We have to ask the travel history of each passenger and check if they had travelled to any affected country. Strict checking is conducted at the airport and there is adequate number of staff at the health desk. With the directive from district administration, we will increase surveillance,” said Dr Suraj B S, assistant surgeon, Kerala health services, who is part of the medical team.Ambulances have been arranged at both terminals to ferry symptomatic passengers to hospitals. Also, special announcements regarding Covid-19 are being made at airport as well as during flight services.All passengers coming to India are required to fill a self-reporting form and submit a copy of the same to the health and immigration counter. Details including cities and countries visited since last 28 days and symptoms of fever, cough and respiratory distress should be mentioned. All international passengers who travelled to Covid-19 affected countries or had contact with people having such travel history should mention the details at the health counter.

Title: ‘Arasu Cable to distribute 10L set-top boxes soon’
Content:
Madurai: Tamil Nadu Arasu Cable TV Corporation Ltd chairman Udumalai K Radhakrishnan on Tuesday said the government has placed orders for procurement of 10 lakh new set-top boxes with the approval of the board.

He said the set-top boxes were expected to arrive in 15 to 20 days. They would be distributed free of cost to people in areas where the government cable television network does not have presence.

The chairman was interacting with reporters after taking part in government events in Tuticorin district on Tuesday. He denied reports that there was a setback for Tamil Nadu Arasu Cable TV Corporation. He said the number of boxes had dropped to 18 lakh from 35 lakh, even before he assumed office as its chairman of the board.

“The number has now increased to 28 lakh boxes. It will grow stronger with the procurement of the 10 lakh new boxes,” he said.

Title: 54 of 184 drunk drivers jailed
Content:
Hyderabad: Continuing its drive against drunk drivers, the Rachakonda traffic police booked 184 cases against people driving under influence.

The traffic police filed chargesheets against all of them, and imposed a total fine of Rs 3,83,000. Among those caught, 54 were imprisoned. In the 184 cases, 159 were two-wheelers, 10 three-wheelers and 15 four-wheelers.

The courts also cancelled or suspended driving licenses of the violators for a period of three months.

The police urged citizens to follow traffic rules, and said that the drive against drunk driving will continue throughout the year. TNN

Title: IT firms taking steps to deal with situation
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The IT industry , which depends on international travel for business, has been hit hard by the spread of coronavirus. Major firms have introduced a travel freeze in the wake of the spike in global Covid-19 cases and are relying on technology for communication.

Alexander Varghese, chief operating officer of UST Global, said that all IT firms have business continuity plans and have devised strategies to deal with the situation. “Most of the companies have introduced a travel freeze and have switched to audio or video conferencing. Of course, there will be exceptions. All employees are given proper awareness on precautionary measures. Those who have travelled to affected countries are advised home quarantine. Also, those planning vacations to foreign countries are asked to stay at home. Work-from-home options are accorded to persons from affected areas. Employees are co-ordinating with their managers on necessary measures,” he said.

Kerala IT Parks CEO Sasi P M said the situation has not affected business in the sector so far. “Even before the Covid-19 outbreak, many companies were encouraging work-from-home options. So it is not a concern for several IT firms. However, international travel restrictions will affect client visits and marketing-related work. So far, the spread of the virus has not affected the sector, but if it continues, the situation might change,” he said.

Sasi said that necessary precautions, as per the directive of health department, have been adopted at IT parks, where large numbers of employees work together. Housekeeping sections are advised to take proper sanitization measures.

The Kerala Startup Mission has postponed crucial visits of delegates from countries like US and Japan. It has also postponed around 15 events planned across the state.

With employee safety utmost on the minds of firms, some technologies, including biometric access, are being discouraged. Most companies have stopped using biometric punching as a security measure.

Title: ‘Will follow Kerala model if needed’
Content: Speaking about a 12-member team’s visit to Kerala, state health minister Eatala Rajender said the team found that Kerala was following a decentralised surveillance method at district level. “The swine flu wards ready at district hospitals can be used for the purpose. If needed, we will follow Kerala model.” The team visited Alleppey and Thiruvananthapuram districts in Kerala where first three positive cases were reported. tnn

Title: Swiggy food delivery boy crushed under RTC bus wheel
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 22-year-old food delivery boy working with Swiggy died on the spot after he was knocked down by a TSRTC bus in Miyapur on Tuesday.

The deceased, L Suman, was heading towards Kukatpally from Miyapur to deliver food to a customer when an RTC bus hit him at around 8.45 am on Tuesday. Police said that the victim’s head was crushed under the wheels of the bus.

“Suman was wearing a helmet. At a signal near Ambedkar Nagar in Miyapur, the bus driver hit the bike while he was taking a left turn,” said Miyapur SI Ravi Kiran.

The TSRTC bus was going towards Mahatma Gandhi Bus Station (MGBS) from Nizamabad. “The victim was crushed under the left rear tyre of the bus and died on the spot,” police said.

The bus driver, Sainath, from Sangareddy district , was taken into custody by the police on Tuesday and booked under Section 304-A (causing death by negligence) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Title: Guarding the skies: No challenge too big for country’s air warrior
Content:
Secunderabad: Air Vice Marshal Sagar Bharti (rtd) spent 36 years of his life serving the country.

As the air officer commanding (AOC) at Air Force Station, Yelahanka, Bengaluru, he was tasked with locating the helicopter that had gone missing with the then chief minister of Andhra Pradesh, YS Rajasekhara Reddy, and some officials.

“We deployed over a dozen helicopters and nearly 80 IAF personnel, including technical staff were on the job of locating the missing helicopter,” Bharti recalled in a conversation with TOI. Sagar Bharti was ready with a plan of action. The search and rescue operation zeroed in on a certain area and came across the helicopter which had crashed.

All five on board had died. “We got out commandos to slither down with a rope and retrieve the mortal remains,” Sagar Bharti said. He himself flew the mortal remains in an Indian Air Force (IAF) helicopter to Hyderabad and then later to Idupulapaya in Kadapa where the burial of the chief minister took place.

Sagar Bharti admits that flying in different terrain and weather needs skill and in hostile conditions, it can be even more challenging. “In Sri Lanka where the IPKF carried out operations against the LTTE, my helicopter with 20 troops was targeted and shot at. That was the closest I came to a war-like situation. But I landed the helicopter without much of a problem though the helicopter suffered 20 bullet shots ,” he recalled.

Following in his footsteps, his son, Sangam Bharti too joined the IAF. Flt Lt Sangam Bharti is also married to an IAF pilot – Flt Lt Saanya.

During his career in the IAF, Sagar Bharti has flown prime ministers Rajiv Gandhi, Atal Behari Vajpayee, IK Gujral, Presidents APJ Abdul Kalam, Giani Zail Singh and union ministers including George Fernandez and Rajnath Singh. He also had a diplomatic posting as air attache at Ukraine.

“Glamorous as it sounded, in order to become a pilot in the IAF the training that one had to undergo was tough,” Sagar Bharti recalled. And that training helped in discharging many functions including undertaking rescue missions during floods in Andhra Pradesh and Gorakhpur (UP) , shifting casualties in J&K, dropping troops in Sri Lanka, playing a role in the Kargil war and in insurgency areas in the north east. “The high altitude and the jungle terrain were a challenge and flying there during my very first posting gave me more confidence,” he recollected.

Was just his training enough to react to emergencies and handle challenging situations? To this Air Vice Marshal Sagar Bharti says, “Human nature is such that when you come across such emergencies, there is a biological clock which automatically gets ticked off and you ensure the safety of people.” He also credited his training and experience as valuable assets.

One of the highlights of his career was receiving and flying former President APJ Abdul Kalam. “He was my hero,” he says describing Kalam.

Sagar Bharti was commanding air force station in Thoise, the northernmost base of IAF and Kalam was the first president to visit this base and Siachen. “As President, he was supreme commander of the armed forces and he spent an entire day with the troops which was a great source of encouragement,” he recalled.

Title: Ayurveda resort in Kollam closed down, guests to be monitored
Content:
Kollam: To ensure vigil against the spread of Covid-19, revenue authorities on Tuesday closed down Maithry Ayurvedic resort and homestay at Chirakkara near Chathannur where 42 tourists , including those from Covid-19-hit countries were lodged for the past few days.

Following reports that foreigners from Covid-19-affected countries were staying there, a team led by deputy collector Sumeethan Pillai, who holds the charge of RDO, sealed the resort and homestay.

The resort was unauthorized and had no licence to accept foreigners as guests, said Pillai, adding that people who stayed there would be quarantined at the resort for 14 days to ascertain if any of them contracted the virus.tnn

Title: Water board to deliver tanker in 48 hours of booking
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: In what might prove to be a major relief to consumers this summer , the Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) has decided to deliver tankers to consumers within 48 hours of booking through the Metro Customer Care (MCC) contact number 155313.

Earlier, citizens would receive tankers within three to four days, especially during summers.

The water board serves around 9.70 lakh consumers.

At a meeting with water board officials on Tuesday, HMWS&SB managing director M Dana Kishore announced a mega summer action plan to ensure that the demand is met.

“Around 230 additional water tankers will operate to meet the demand. We have also opened 23 filling stations and 110 filling points,” said Kishore.

The board is also installing mini electricity generators at water filling stations to tackle power cuts.

It is also planning to depute special inspection teams of 10 senior officials to tackle water shortage. “Besides these special teams, another 100 officials will inspect the areas where the water pressure is low and monitor the situation at the filling stations,” he said.

The water board said it is spending Rs 50 crore to revive defunct borewells and other emergency work in tail-end areas as part of the action plan.

Title: Police: Doctor had argument with wife before shooting self at house
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: After the 43-year-old anaesthetist Ravindra Kumar shot himself at his villa in Saket-Mithila of Kapra on Monday, his wife has told the police that she had to run out of the house on Sunday night as Ravinder assaulted her.

Dr Smitha told police that Ravinder had asked her to accompany him to his elder brother’s newly purchased house in Tellapur. However, as Smitha was not ready to go, Ravindra Kumar went to the house alone at around 3 pm on Sunday.

“Ravindra Kumar had dinner with his family members and returned home at around 9 pm. After returning, he started consuming liquor and picked up an argument with his wife for not accompanying him to his brother’s house. During the argument, he assaulted her twice. Rattled with his behaviour, she ran her out of the house and went to a doctor couple in her neighbourhood. The other family dropped Smitha at her parent’s house in Dilsukhnagar,” a police official from Rachakonda commissionerate said.

Smitha did not take her phone with her while leaving the house. Subsequently, Ravindra Kumar called his 12-year-old son - who was already at his grandparent’s house since Saturday night - at around 2 am.

“Smitha answered her son’s phone. After hearing her voice, he disconnected the call. We have sought the details of Ravindra Kumar’s call details,” Kushaiguda ACP K Shiva Kumar said.

After preliminary probe, police has said that Ravinder’s hospital business was not going well. Police has also revealed that the anaesthetist had obtained the weapon’s license after he received threats from members of a pseudo naxal gang in 2017. “In 2016, a pseudo naxal gang was arrested for threatening businessmen and doctors like Ravindra Kumar for money. Fearing threat from the gang members, Dr Ravindra Kumar applied for gun license and he got it in 2017,” the inspector said.

Ravinder Kumar was the MD of Shri Adithya Hospital in Dammaiguda and Dr Smitha worked there as a gynaecologist.

Title: Covid-19: Technopark on precautionary mode
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Now, offices of IT companies based in Technopark have an ‘open door’ policy, shedding the biometric access control system at the entry of buildings. Several IT company offices are keeping their doors open in order to avoid spread of diseases from high-touch areas such as door handles.Housekeeping staff are some of the busiest persons of the IT parks these days as they have been designated with the task of keeping high-touch areas such as doorknobs, elevator buttons, stair railing etc. sanitized frequently. As companies began stocking hand sanitizers and masks, the shops around Technopark are experiencing severe shortage.Sasi PM, CEO, IT Parks, said that directions were given to keep commonly touched areas sanitized every 15 minutes. “Companies have been directed to provide hand sanitizers. There is a shortage of masks. Steps were taken to isolate persons with symptoms and to inform the health department,” he said.Several IT companies have asked their staff, who visited home town of Pathanamthitta where positive cases of Covid-19 were reported, to work from home for around two weeks to prevent spread from affected areas. “Several persons who have to travel via Pathanamtitta too were asked to stay at home as there are chances to get infected during travel,” said an IT professional. There is also demand from IT professionals to give more work-from-home options, which several companies have agreed to.Group of Technology Companies (GTech) is associating with Kerala chapter of Indian Medical Association and Technopark co-operative society to provide awareness for IT professionals. GTech CEO Vishnu V Nair said that a meeting with be held with Gtech and health department officials on Wednesday at Technopark to discuss the precautionary measures to be taken in crowded places like IT parks.Several programmes planned by organizations and companies within Technopark were postponed due to precautions taken in view of spread of Covid-19. Majority of companies cancelled their Women’s Day public events. Empowering women in IT (eWIT), an organization of women IT professionals, is the latest to cancel their Women’s Day celebrations grand finale, which was scheduled to be held on Thursday.Companies such as UST Global have deployed service of doctors at their campus. Several companies have posted pamphlets on ‘social distancing’ and other etiquette to be followed at the time of pandemic.“Rumours are spreading like wildfire. There were instances where people spread rumours about presence of corona positive cases in Phase III campus of Technopark and H1N1 in a company. All these turned out to be fake information. Misinformation in social media is another issue. We ask persons who forward such messages to give the source or delete such messages without creating more trouble,” said Rajeev Krishnan, core member of Pratidhwani, a socio-cultural organization in Technopark. Rajeev, however, added that crowding of people at cafeterias and elevators is unavoidable as of now.

Title: Farm hands seek changes to MGNREGA
Content:
Madurai: The All India Agricultural Workers Union (AIAWU) on Tuesday held a demonstration at the district collectorate demanding better implementation of the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) scheme.

The members of the organisation led by state vice president, P Vasanthamani, protested the apathy shown by both state and central governments in the implementation of MGNREGA since 2014.

The protesters demanded increase in MGNREGA employment from 100 days to 250 days, increase in daily wages to Rs 600, payment of workers’ wages within 15 days, expanding of MGNREGA to urban areas, and display of work schedule for one year at local panchayat notice boards to ensure transparency.

Title: Artiste complaint to SC/ST panel
Content:
Hyderabad: A Telugu film artiste has lodged a complaint with the SC/ST commission chairman Erolla Srinivas, alleging that the brother of a well-known choreographer had abused her with her caste name and also tried to sexually exploit her.

Srinivas has assured the artiste Divya that the commission would look into the complaint, investigate the matter and take necessary action.

In a representation, the artiste alleged that the choreographer’s brother was also trying to pull her into a prostitution racket. The artiste said she was being mentally tortured and urged that action be taken against him.

Title: Uninterrupted power for isolation wards
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Electricity minister M M Mani has directed the Kerala state electricity board to take appropriate measures to avoid power interruptions in isolation wards set up for Covid-19 patients and suspect cases at hospitals across the state.

The minister’s directive for ensuring uninterrupted power supply for isolation wards came in the meeting of top KSEB officials held on Tuesday. It was also decided to provide immediate power in case isolation wards are being shifted or set up in buildings currently without a connection.

tnn

Title: COVID-19 scare: Blood sample of man admitted to Government Rajaji Hospital tests negative
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MADURAI: The blood samples of the 35-year-old man admitted to the Covid-19 isolation ward at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) tested negative on Tuesday.

The man, who returned from Italy on February 29, got himself admitted to GRH on Monday after he developed symptoms of sore throat. The hospital authorities had earlier said that he didn’t have any symptoms of Covid-19. But, he was isolated as a precautionary measure. On Tuesday, GRH dean Dr J Sangumani confirmed that the man’s sample tested negative.

Meanwhile, Madurai district collector Dr T G Vinay inspected the Covid-19 isolation ward at the GRH and held discussions with the dean on the measures to be taken. Speaking to reporters, the district collector said that stringent measures are in place to prevent the possible spread of the virus in Madurai. “Lab to test Covid-19 samples is functioning in Theni. However, the facility will be made available in Madurai soon,” he said.

After reports of two more people from Dindigul district being admitted to GRH on suspicion of having symptoms of Covid-19 came out on Tuesday, the GRH dean clarified that it was not the case. “Doctors checked the two patients after there were suspicions. They were not even admitted to the isolation ward. They both have been discharged,” said Dr Sangumani.

Meanwhile, screening of passengers continued at Madurai airport. Starting a few days ago, after every international flight where passengers could have made contact, cleaning of the area is being done using proper chemical proportion of cleaning agents as a precautionary measure. Hand sanitizer gels are also being provided to arriving international passengers to clean their hands when stepping out of the airport. So far, more than 15,000 passengers have been screened for Covid-19 since January 28.

Title: 26-year-old jumps to death from 13th floor
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 26-year-old man committed suicide by jumping from the 13th floor of an apartment building in Miyapur on Tuesday.

The deceased, Balaram Mohan , who was earlier working with a software company, had quit his job in September 2019 and was looking for a job. He was staying at a PG accommodation in Kondapur .

“He would often visit his friend’s relatives in Miyapur. On Tuesday, he went to the thirteenth floor of their apartment building and jumped from the common balcony. It is a 14-storey building,” said Miyapur SI Ravi Kiran.

According to the police, the deceased’s friends, who stay on the seventh floor, had gone to Tirupathi. “Mohan’s friends said that he was depressed over not being able to find a job. No suicide note was found,” said the SI. The incident occurred at around 2.15 pm on Tuesday.

Police registered a case of suspicious death.

Title: Case filed by Karvy posted to next week
Content:
Hyderabad: Justice Abinand Kumar Shavili of the high court on Tuesday posted to next week the case filed by Karvy Stock Broking firm challenging the serious fraud investigation office (SFIO) probe into its affairs. The Centre took a week’s time to file its counter in the matter.

Last week, Karvy went to the high court, expressing fear that the Centre may order a probe into its affairs. But by the time the case was taken up, the central government produced an order from the Centre that brought in an SFIO probe confirming the fears of Karvy.

The Centre cited a preliminary probe report by registrar of companies and informed the court that this formed the basis for their decision. Karvy is insisting that all the material that led to the probe order should be furnished to it.

Title: Retd IAS officer’s wife booked for illegal water line at residence
Content:
Hyderabad: A criminal case has been registered against a retired IAS officer ’s wife for obtaining illegal water connection at her house.

The vigilance wing of Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) conducted raid at the house of P Kalyani, wife of P Vanamali, on Tuesday and identified two unauthorised water connections. It was found that the water board had disconnected one connection in 2012 but it was later reconnected.

“P Kalyani has failed to produce any documents pertaining to a 15- mm water connection. It has been learnt that the house has not received permission for any water connections,” M Ravi Chandan Reddy , the chief vigilance officer of HMWS&SB told TOI.

Jubilee Hills police have registered an FIR under sections 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease and danger to life), and 430 (mischief by injury to works of irrigation or by wrongfully diverting water), against Kalyani. The punishment can be imprisonment up to five year or fine, said Reddy.

In an earlier incident, the Banjara Hills police had registered a case against Kalyani in January 2017 for trespassing into her domestic help Kumari’s house and assaulting her for allegedly stealing Rs 10 lakh.

The water board has also conducted raids at two other properties in Jubilee Hills. Illegal connection was found at the house of a MV Krishna Reddy, who has given the premise to M/s Monika Broadcasting Private Limited. Illegal connections were also found at the property of a K.Dayasagar Reddy.

Title: Isolation wards arranged in private hosps
Content:
Kottayam: The district administration stepped up precautionary measures in the wake of Covid-19 cases that were reported in the district. Collector P K Sudheer Babu said that the situation was under control and there was no need for concerns. Isolation wards were arranged at the medical college hospital and general hospital. Isolation wards were also set up in taluk as well as private hospitals also, he said.

Meanwhile, Covid-19 was confirmed in four persons who were kept under observation in the medical college hospital. All four are relatives of the family who had arrived from Italy and later tested positive for Covid-19. Two of them are an elderly couple from Pathanamthitta and the other two are from Kottayam. According to hospital authorities their health condition is satisfactory.

A total of 10 individuals are under observation in the district for Covid-19. Among them nine are in the isolation ward of the medical college and one is in general hospital.

Around 76 individuals, including those who encountered Covid-19 patients were advised home quarantine by the health department. Now, the total number of individuals, who are under home quarantine, have risen to 167. Meanwhile, efforts are on to find those who have come into secondary contact.

The district collector advised people to avoid holding functions where there is a possibility of a mass gathering. He also said that minimum participation of people is advisable for unavoidable functions like marriages. He also lauded the decision of the St Antony’s pilgrim centre which decided to conduct its prayers service online. He has also directed the entrance coaching centres in the district to end classes till March end.

The public were advised not to use swimming pools in clubs, hotels and training centres. Meanwhile, private hospitals in the district have extended cooperation in Covid-19 treatment. Around 24 isolation rooms have been arranged at various hospitals.

Title: Temple festival: Massive processions cancelled
Content: T’puram: The ‘Ottam’ ritual of Nedumangad Ammankoda Mahotsavam, an annual temple festival of three major Devi temples in Nedumangad with a history of more than 300 years, was held here sans any pomp, in view of rise in Covid-19 cases. The festival organizers decided to do away with all the pompous processions and cultural events after the district collector instructed them to avoid mass gatherings.Ammankoda Mahotsavam is an annual festival of three major temples, Mutharamman Devi Temple, Melamkode Devi Temple and Muthumari Amman Devasthanam Temple. Tuesday was the penultimate day of the valedictory of the festival. It was also the most important day of the festival. Usually, massive processions are taken out from all three temples covering the entire Nedumangad town. But, this time it was cancelled following the direction from the district administration. All cultural events scheduled on Tuesday night and Wednesday have also been cancelled. These include music concerts, dance shows, ‘singari melam’ and ‘pookkavadi’.“We cancelled all cultural events but carried out the rituals as planned,” said Murugan Achari, president, Muthumari Amman Devasthanam Temple, Nedumangad. This was a festival that has been organized for the past 365 years without fail. Hence, we conducted the rituals, he said. The main ritual on Tuesday was a procession of the deities of the three temples. A ‘kuthiyottam’ and ‘thalappoli’ ceremonies were also held.Nedumangad DSP Stuart Keeler said that since it was a major festival the organizers were initially reluctant to comply the directions . They agreed to comply only after the police summoned the temple committee members and local politicians to the DSP office and held talks. tnn

Title: Doctor gets jail for harassing woman
Content:
Hyderabad: A 53-year-old doctor on Tuesday was sentenced to undergo six-month imprisonment and pay a fine of Rs 5,000 after he was convicted on the charges of misbehaving with a woman. A local court convicted the doctor under sexual harassment case.

The convict was a BHMS doctor and resident of Neredmet. The incident occurred in 2017 when the woman was posted as a house surgeon in t he hospital.

While she was on ICU duty in the night, the doctor misbehaved with her by touching her inappropriately.

Title: Hashish oil worth Rs 1crseized at Eanchakkal
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: In a major catch, members of state excise enforcement squad on Tuesday seized one litre of hashish oil that was being smuggled through the city. The seized contraband would fetch more than Rs 1 crore in the international drug market, according to the officials. The hashish oil was stored in two sealed bottles of a coconut oil brand.

The squad officers also arrested two men, who were transporting the substance. The identified are Sudheesh (27), and Justin P Mathew alias Vava (32). Both men are residents of Melukavu in Meenachil taluk in Kottayam district. They were caught from a lodge at Eanchakkal.

The contraband they were carrying was sourced from a wholesale ganja dealer based in Narsipatnam village, Visakhpatnam in Andhra Pradesh.

The excise officers said that Sudheesh was a habitual offender, who was involved in the sale of narcotic substances for the past few years. In the past, he used to conduct his business in Bengaluru. But last year, he was arrested by the Bengaluru police following which he had to spend two months in prison. Following his arrest, he lost all his trusted contacts in Bengaluru. That was when his wholesale dealer in Narsipatnam advised him to shift his operations to Kerala, especially Kochi and Thiruvananthapuram.

The two accused were held following a reliable tip-off received by excise circle inspector T Anikumar who leads the state excise enforcement squad. He was assisted by circle inspector G Krishnakumar and excise inspector T R Mukesh Kumar.

Title: Lakshadweep: A lesson in gratitude
Content:
If you are a person who finds solace in the sun and sand, and longs for the tranquil blue of the ocean, then ditch Goa and Andamans and head to Lakshadweep for your next vacation. This island Union Territory of India in the Arabian Sea is twice as beautiful and half as commercialised.

I embarked a cruise that took me to Kavaratti, Minicoy and Kalpeni. I could relax in the secluded, clean beaches for as long as I wished. I was able to swim in the ocean, snorkel and scuba dive. Moreover, I had the opportunity to see, touch and feel the world underneath, with the tiny fish that flutter vivaciously around their colourful homes: the corals. Watching the sun set in the offing, while the breeze caresses your hair and the cool sand seeps through your toes was truly a serene and calming experience.

My travel experience also included a cultural interaction with the locals, where they presented a few traditional dances and songs. Later, we were distributed local snacks which were so delicious that we absolutely had to sneak a second helping.

The native islanders fish and work predominantly in the coconut and tourism industry. But what intrigued me most was the fact that even with the bare minimum that they survive on, they seemed satisfied and happy. There are no lavish bungalows and malls in Lakshadweep, just humble hutments and shops. They do make you wonder about the futility of constantly wanting more out of everything in life. The ostentatious lifestyle of the mainland has not yet infected the island territory and that is where its beauty lies. The people there are content with what they have; they focus on community growth, prospering not with wealth but with the collective support of each other.

The beauty of Lakshadweep lies in the ability of its people to be grateful for the little things. This was one life lesson that I got from my calming sojourn to the picturesque islands of Lakshadweep.

(The writer is a class 12 student)

Title: 27 ASIs, 69 head constables promoted as sub-inspectors
Content:
Puducherry: Twenty-seven assistant sub-inspectors of police and 69 head constables have been selected for promotion to the post of sub-inspectors of police in the Union territory.

Lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi while welcoming the ‘long-awaited’ move said the decision will boost the morale of the Puducherry police force.

Bedi said the focus of the police force must be on eradicating rowdyism and land-grab in any form.

“The increased police presence will strengthen the effectiveness of Puducherry police in all four regions of the UT. A comprehensive training plan has been organised for them by the police headquarters,” she said.

The Lieutenant governor attributed the promotion to the close coordination between the leadership in the home and police departments. “I congratulate the chief secretary and the DGP and their team for having diligently worked through the process,” Bedi said.

Title: Qutb Shahi tombs regain their glory, US envoy Juster delighted
Content:
U.S. Ambassador to India Kanneth Juster inaugurated the refurbished tombs of Taramati-Premamati at Qutb Shahi ... Read More

HYDERABAD: US ambassador to India Kenneth I Juster attended a ceremony for the completion of all major structural components of the new consulate compound in Hyderabad on Tuesday. He announced that the compound would be completed by Fall 2021.

“I’m pleased to see progress at the new US Consulate Compound in Hyderabad,” said the ambassador at the “Topping Out” ceremony. He thanked the Telangana government and minister KTR for all the support given for the US Consulate General in Hyderabad.

Spread across more than 12 acres, the multi-building consulate complex is located at Nanakramguda in the Financial District. An estimated $33 million is being invested in the local economy throughout the duration of the project. and an estimated workforce of over 1,000 American, Indian, and third-country workers are involved in construction. The project budget is $350.5 Million.

Further, Juster also announced completion of a US-funded restoration project at the 17th century Qutb Shahi Tombs through the Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation (AFCP).

In February 2019, Juster announced a $103,000 grant through the AFCP, partnering with the Aga Khan Foundation to restore and conserve the centuries-old tombs of Taramati and Premamati within the greater Qutb Shahi Tombs complex.

This is the second grant awarded by the US Government for conservation work at the Qutb Shahi Tombs. An earlier AFCP grant of $101,000, awarded in 2014, contributed to mapping and documenting structures throughout the site and helped transform archeologists’ understanding of the monument’s earliest architecture.

Stating that it was very important to restore and protect the city’s heritage, Juster said, “This is my third visit to the tombs and I am delighted to see that they have been restored successfully.”

Title: One held for spreading fake news in Wayanad
Content:
Kozhikode: Police have arrested one person in Wayanad for allegedly spreading fake news about Covid-19 over social media .

Harris, 38, of Panthipoyil was arrested by the Vellamunda police on Tuesday under sections of the Kerala Police Act for spreading false information over social media that a person hailing from Modakkara has tested positive for Covid-19.

The arrested were later released on bail. District police chief said that strict action will be taken against those who engage in spreading such misinformation.

Meanwhile, Wayanad district collector Adeela Abdulla has said that people who have been directed to remain in home quarantine should strictly comply with the instruction and cases will be registered against violators under Public Health Act and sections of the Indian Penal Code.

11 under surveillance in Alappuzha

According to Alappuzha district administration, eleven people have been admitted to various hospitals in the district on suspicion of contracting Covid-19 (coronavirus disease) on Tuesday. “So far, a total of 99 people are under house quarantine in the district. The number of people admitted to Alappuzha Medical College Hospital, General Hospital, and Kayamkulam Taluk Hospital, now becomes 20. Samples collected from 11 people admitted to the hospitals on Tuesday have been sent for testing,” said officials.

Title: Bomb threat triggers panic at school
Content: Hyderabad: Panic prevailed for a while at the Delhi Public School at Nacharam here on Tuesday morning after an anonymous email warning of a bomb planted in school was received by the management. The email later turned out be a fake one. The police are investigating the source of the email and have sought help of the Cybercrime cell of the Rachakonda Police to nab the sender. tnn

Title: FDA starts random medical store checks in Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik unit of the state Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has kicked off random checks of medical stores in the district to ensure that face masks and hand sanitisers are not sold at a premium.

The agency officials have warned of cancelling the licences of stores if they are found involved in black-marketing of these items.

There are over 4,000 drug stores across the district. “It is not possible for the FDA squads to check each store. Therefore, we are carrying out random inspections and seeking customer feedback to prevent the sale of these items at prices more than the MRP. The demand for both face masks and hand sanitisers in Nashik has gone up by about 10%. So far, there have been no complaints,” said the FDA sources.

According to the officials, there is no scarcity of these two items in the district. According to the Nashik Chemist and Druggist Association there is no significant rise in demand for face masks and sanitisers. “These two items are available at such stores that sell surgical items. We have also directed our members not to sell these items at higher prices,” the association members added.

Title: Trash pile cleared after student airs grievance on TOI app
Content:
Hyderabad: On Sunday, V Bhavya Reddy, a class 7 student, downloaded TOI’s Citizen Reporter app and reported about a garbage pile near her house. On Monday, the very day the report was published, civic authorities cleared the trash from the locality. The garbage had piled up at Gandhi Nagar, Kavadiguda, and even the bins were not emptied.

Niranjan Reddy, father of the girl, said that it was his daughter who downloaded the app and aired the apathy on his name.

“My daughter is a TOI reader. She was aware about the garbage menace in our locality and on Sunday she aired the apathy using the app,” said Reddy, adding, “Apart from the mosquito menace, we were forced to bear with the foul smell emanating from the garbage. I thank TOI and GHMC for clearing the garbage.”

GHMC officials said that ensuring sanitation on selected main roads is the responsibility of private agencies. Some main roads are handed over to private agencies under comprehensive road maintenance programme (CRMP) and sanitation on those stretches is the responsibility of those agencies.

“Though the onus of keeping the localities clean under CRMP is on the private agencies, we keep track of sanitation and also co-ordinate with them to ensure a clean city,” said Hemalatha, GHMC assistant medical officer of health (Musheerabad circle).

A senior citizen from Kavadiguda said that the bins need to be relocated. “The bins have been placed outside a few buildings. I request the authorities to deploy additional vehicles for door-to-door collection of garbage and would urge them to relocate the bins,” he said.

Residents also complain that as the garbage is not cleared regularly, the road gets dirty when the bins are full and the waste overflows on to the streets. “The place looks like a mini dump yard,” said M Sindhuri, a resident of Gandhi Nagar.

Title: Puducherry CM V Narayanasamy urges PM Modi to ensure women’s bill is passed
Content:
V Narayanasamy

PUDUCHERRY: Chief minister V Narayanasamy on Tuesday urged Prime Minister Narendra Modi to ensure passing legislation to reserve 33% for women in Parliament and state legislatures . He was speaking at the international women’s day celebrations organised by the department of women and child development in the presence of lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi and others on Tuesday.

Narayanasamy said that the previous Congress-led UPA government in the Centre made concrete efforts to introduce women’s bill in Parliament. Rajya Sabha passed the bill in 2010 but the bill could not be passed in the Lok Sabha, he said.

“The present government in the Centre enjoys a majority. I urge Prime Minister Modi to pass the bill reserving 33% seats for women in Parliament and state legislatures,” Narayanasamy said.

He said Puducherry’s sex ratio (1,050 women for every 1,000 men) stands testimony that the territory remains the safe place for women. Female voters outnumber male voters by 30,000 to 40,000 in the territory, he said.

He claimed that violence against women has come down after the government gave strict direction to the police department to tackle the crimes with an iron hand. He was of the strong opinion that violence against women can be curbed only through stringent punishment to the offenders. He said the government has passed legislation to conclude trial in rape cases and award punishment within three months. But there are instances of delay in executing the punishment for the convicted people, he regretted while pointing out the Nirbhaya case.

The government has launched a mobile application for women’s safety He said the government has proposed to extend 50% reservation for women in education and in future will consider extending 50% reservation for women in employment too.

Bedi listed out the strengths of the Puducherry administration in ensuring the safety of the women in the territory. She said Puducherry has a high-quality family counselling centres, good health care system with medical stories sponsored by the Puducherry and Union governments, excellent anganwadi systems to take care of women and children and a good number of women police officers and constables among others.

She said Puducherry has considerably higher women’s literacy rate and pointed out that educated and employed women focus more on educating their children.

She urged the women to make use of every opportunity and take an active part in the polls to the local bodies.

Earlier welfare minister M Kandasamy threatened to resign if Bedi failed to address the issues in his department within a period of three months. He also submitted a memorandum in this regard to her during the celebrations.

Title: ‘No scientific evidence to suggest non-vegetarian food causes Covid-19’
Content:
Are bats responsible for this infection? Why do all viruses originate from China? Is it true that the virus will subside once summer sets in? – Parimala G Tadas

Since experts say the virus survives on surfaces for days, is it important that our phones are cleaned thoroughly and often? – Ramakant Jaju

When a mosquito bites a coronavirus-infected person, is it possible that it carries the same virus and infects other people with it? – Jayalatha V Swamy

In India, corona broke out first in Kerala. It was combatted by the health department effectively. But in Telangana the situation is different. Gandhi Hospital staff is up in arms to shift the isolation ward to some other place. Do you think that measures taken so far are adequate? — B Ajayakumar

I am six months pregnant and must frequently visit hospitals for scans. I am worried because I am told private hospitals too are now accepting Covid-19 cases. Should I look out for hospitals that do not cater to these patients? – Meenakshi Nair

I

t’s become scary to be near anyone who coughs or sneezes. How paranoid should we be in these circumstances? There is no cure or vaccine; how does this work? — Rakesh Kannoth

Should we stay away from non-vegetarian food? Especially, the ready-to-eat products available in the freezers in super markets and any imported stuff? – Narayanan Srirangam

How effective is the mask? What type of mask one should use? – Sam Singhal

Is the novel

going to stay in India, surfacing season after season like the human influenza virus? – Srinivas KV

Are there chances of co-infection of novel coronavirus and human influenza virus? – Suresh Rao

Various kinds of information are being spread through social media causing a lot of distress. What are the exact symptoms that we should look out for? What preventive measures should we take? — Sanghamitra Malik

How to respond if a family member has these symptoms:

Can you tell us about the origin, spread and mode of infection? Is there any vector or alternate host? When it is not airborne, do we need masks? Is there any information about its response to temperature? – Dr KB Reddy

I have a corporate meeting overseas and must travel to the US via Dubai. What precautions should I take? Is wearing a N95 mask enough while travelling? – SK Sinha

There is no firm evidence to suggest that origin of Covid-19 is from bats. It is not easy to explain why the three originated from China. It may be just a chance, especially as there are more number of people in China or their food habits that can bring zoonotic bugs in context of human. Virus cannot survive outside the host for long. They stay alive on surfaces like tables, chairs, etc. for a while. In warm weather this survival reduces considerably, so it is expected that in summer the spread will be much lower. However, there is no scientific evidence yet to support this.Phone cleaning may not be of much use, simply keeping in pocket will be enough. Best is not to touch mouth/face/nose/eyes without washing the hands with soap, keep distance from people with symptoms and avoid gatherings/crowded places.No, it is not likely, but always better to avoid mosquitoes for other reasons.I understand, Gandhi Hospital in Hyderabad is one of the Government of India centres for Covid-19 test. There may be small hitches but so far system has responded well, and prevention of spread is the best strategy.No need to worry if you take precautions that are generally recommended. Hospital that is accepting Covid-19 patients is not more dangerous than any other hospital or crowded place, as such patients are kept in isolated wards/rooms and additional precautions are in place (that way they may be relatively safer!).There is no need to worry about this, as there are ways to avoid/prevent catching infection by taking general precautions. There is no drug or vaccine, but the infection is generally defeated by our immune system. Only older people or people with other health conditions are at risk, they need to take additional precaution or medical attention. More than 80% of incidents are asymptomatic and people recover without needing any medical help.There is no scientific evidence to suggest that non-vegetarian food or ready-to-eat frozen imported items are means of Covid-19 spread. It is safer to eat healthy and freshly heated food items to ensure neutralising any accidental presence of infectious agents.N95 respirator face mask (costs around Rs 250) is advised for a person who is infected, to prevent the spread when person coughs/sneezes.It is difficult to rule out this. Increased hygienic practices and community action will be needed to control or see this off.In principle, yes, but there are no such reports yet as far as we know.Covid-19 symptoms that may appear two to 14 days after exposure include,runny nose, fever, frequent sneezing and coughing, shortness of breath (all symptoms may not show in each case).1. Avoid going out, stay at home and maintain 3-4 feet distance from other people in your home as much as possible; stay in a separate room and use a separate bathroom, if available.2. Limit contact with your pets.3. Wear a face mask if you must be around other people.4. When you cough/sneeze, cover your mouth and nose with a tissue; immediately throw tissues in garbage; wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds; if that’s not available, clean with hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.5. Avoid sharing household items, including drinking cups, eating utensils, towels or even bedding. Wash these items thoroughly after using.6. Clean high-touch surfaces daily using a household cleaner or wipe. These include counters, table tops, doorknobs, bathroom fixtures, toilets, etc.Stay healthy, use vitamin supplements like vitamin C. Don’t panic or take stress. Relax by watching your favourite TV show, surfing internet, talking to friends on mobile. Most people recover and by self-quarantine prevent spread of infection. Continue monitoring your symptoms. If they worsen, such as you if you begin to have difficulty breathing, seek medical help.Covid-19 is reported to have emerged from the Chinese city of Wuhan and there are unconfirmed suggestions that it has zoonotic origin. There is no strong scientific evidence of any alternate host so far. There are indications that this virus is sensitive to higher temperatures, but it is not certain how much of help will the summer season be. Remember, lot of places are air-conditioned where temperature does not change with season.Here is what is known about Covid-19 and knowing this will help in taking precaution to prevent its spread:Person-to-person spread: The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet) through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs. People are thought to be most contagious when they are most symptomatic.
