However, some spread might be possible before people show symptoms; there have been reports of this occurring with this new coronavirus, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.Spread from contact with contaminated surfaces or objects: It may be possible that a person can get Covid-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it (from an infected person who coughed/sneezed on the object) and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. The virus that causes Covid-19 seems to be spreading easily and sustainably in the community, known as community spread, in some affected locations.Take general precautions such as avoiding touching things. Don’t touch your face before washing your hands with soap or wiping with alcohol-based disinfectant (carry one in your hand bag). Mask is not of much use, it may be counter-productive as one tends to adjust it frequently by hand. Maintain 3-4 feet distance from people, if possible, and avoid venturing into crowded places.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Mother-daughter duo admitted to isolation ward
Content: NASHIK: A 23-year-old woman, who returned to the city from Dubai around a week ago, and her mother were on Tuesday admitted to the isolation ward of the civic hospital as they were suffering from cold and cough — symptoms of coronavirus A senior health department official said that the mother-daughter duo were admitted to the isolation ward as a precautionary measure because one of them had visited the Gulf region, where coronavirus cases have been rising.Dubai is a part of the UAE, which has reported 74 infections across the country so far.Nikhil Saindane, additional civil surgeon of Nashik civil hospital, said the woman returned from Dubai on March 4. “On Monday, she started suffering from cold and cough, following which she went to the Bytco Hospital. She was on Tuesday referred to the civil hospital to check if she had caught coronavirus,” he said.“Since the mother is also suffering from cold and cough, we got her too admitted to the isolation ward as a precautionary measure. Their swabs have been sent to the NIV for tests and the reports will be available by Wednesday,” said Saindane.Civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale said the woman had gone to Dubai to attend a Satsang programme and that she was in the emirate for seven to eight days.“Apart from the mother-daughter duo and another patient in the isolation ward, there are 17 travellers from affected countries whose health is being monitored by us at their homes on a daily basis,” he said.“The travellers concerned have been asked to not move out of their house for 14 days as the virus dies in a person’s body in that period,” added Jagdale.

Title: Covid-19 cases: Kozhikode medical college hospital gets testing lab
Content:
MCH lab commenced its operation by conducting tests on six samples

KOZHIKODE: The government medical college hospital (MCH), on Tuesday, commenced the testing of swabs collected from suspected Covid-19 cases. The laboratory to test these swabs was arranged at the virology research and diagnostic centre ’s biosafety level-II (BSL-II) lab, which comes under the department of microbiology .

According to MCH authorities, the lab commenced its operation by conducting tests on six samples received on March 10 and all the six of them tested negative for Covid-19.

Kozhikode MCH principal Dr V R Rajendran said, “The lab will carry out tests on all samples received at the lab from north Malabar and other districts in the state. The facility will help to provide the test results within five hours of receiving the samples,” he said.

Meanwhile, KGMCH superintendent Dr K G Sajeeth Kumar said that the hospital collects swab and blood samples from people belonging to high-risk groups. “Hospital authorities will keep the suspected person belonging to high-risk group under 14 days’ observation even if the test turns negative. In case, if the test results turn positive then the samples will be sent to Pune-based National Institute of Virology for reconfirmation,” he said.

With the new lab, district health department here need not send the collected samples from suspected patients to NIV lab at Alappuzha Medical College Hospital. With this, the state now has three labs for testing samples, the other two being the medical colleges at Thiruvananthapuram and Alappuzha.

Central government has already provided probes and standard operating procedure to Kozhikode Medical College Hospital authorities to carry out tests. Medical college authorities have already deployed trained staff at the lab and it will receive swabs from all five districts in north Malabar.

Title: Labourer held for stealing cellphones
Content: Hyderabad: A 27-year-old labourer was nabbed by Rachakonda police on Tuesday for stealing three mobile phones in Nacharam police station limits. The accused was identified as Battula Venkatesh from HB Colony, Moulali. The accused was booked and sent to judicial remand and all three phones were recovered from his possession. tnn

Title: Woman robbed of her gold chain in Mhasrool
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: A woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 35,000 in the Mhasrool area by two unidentified bikers on Monday.

The police said the victim, a 42-year-old resident of Mhada Colony in Kalanagar along Dindori Road, was walking home around noon. When the woman was near the Lane No. 1 board of Kalanagar, two persons riding a high-speed bike came close to her and the one riding pillion snatched the 14 gm gold chain she was wearing. The bike then sped away.

The victim said the chain robbers were 30-35 years old. The victim was not able to give the registration number of the bike the robbers were riding.

Chain snatchings incidents have been taking place frequently over the past three months. According to the police, they have set up checkpoints across the city. In the past couple of months, the police have also failed to arrest any chain robber. However, the chain snatchers also seem to conduct recces of areas before committing the crime.

Senior police officials said that the criminals would not be able to escape for a long.

Title: Churches break with tradition as precaution
Content:
Kottayam: Churches are breaking with tradition in the wake of Covid-19 scare. Malankara churches have made safety arrangements in their rituals and prayers .

In a historic move, the Malankara Jacobite Syrian Church has decided to serve bread and wine during mass to faithful in their hands. A pastoral letter regarding this has been sent by Thomas Mar Timotheos, metropolitan of Kottayam diocese, to all churches, priests and managing committee members.

The letter says that this is a temporary arrangement. Since the virus spreads through touch, handshakes are to be avoided as a greeting and replaced with the namaste.

It also instructed believers to put an end to kissing of hands and instead bow before the Bible or cross and relics before leaving church. The practice of smearing oil on the forehead from the oil lamp is to be avoided.

The Church has also made safety arrangements for the practice of confession. Towels which are used on the altar have to be changed after use. Those who have fever or cough will have to stay at home. Arrangements will have to be made for the faithful to wash their hands with soap before entering the churches, says the letter.

Meanwhile, Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church too have stopped all prayer meetings, Sunday school classes and public meetings other than mass on Saturdays and Sundays. The church has also sought lesser participation for funerals.

The Mar Thoma Church has suspended Sunday mass, church meetings and lent prayers till March 31.

The Thrissur archdiocese of the Syro-Malabar Church also appealed to believers to avoid programmes like conventions, oottuthirunal, and other celebrations where large number of people are likely to converge.

In a statement issued in Thrissur on Tuesday, archbishop Andrews Thazhath appealed to the believers to follow the directions of the government and health authorities to prevent Covid-19 infections.

Title: Duo held for stealing bikes
Content: Hyderabad: The Crime Team of Panjagutta Police Station arrested two persons for stealing bikes on Tuesday. The accused were identified as Dabbakunta Shesaiah and Rayishetti Goverdhan. Both work in the same dental hospital at Srinagar Colony. Police seized 14 bikes from their possession and booked them under 379 (theft) of IPC.tnn

Title: Nashik: Two youths arrested in Mhasrool firing case
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The city police on Monday arrested two youths in connection to the Mhasrool firing case that took place in the Shantinagar area in Makhmalabad.

The two individuals are identified as Prashant Balasaheb Phad (27) of Vidya Nagar and Kunal Sudhakar Ekhande (21) of Shantinagar. Both of them were arrested from near the Kannamwar Bridge near Dwarka on Monday night.

The two suspects were produced before the city court, which sent them to police custody till March 13.

Pandharinath Dhokane, senior police inspector of the Mhasrool police station said they have launched a search to arrest the two other suspects involved in the firing incident. “An individual identified as Kiran Bhadange was injured by a bullet on his left hand. The police said that the attackers had a tiff with Bhadange about two weeks back and they were fearing that Bhadange would eliminate them. Following this, they decided to kill Bhadanage,” he said.

He added that they have also recovered two firearms that were used in the firing incident.

The arrests were made by crime branch unit 1, under the guidance of CP Vishwas Nangare Patil.

Meanwhile, on Tuesday, the central unit of the crime branch detained a person from Shantinagar area, who allegedly provided the firearms to the attackers. The police said that they were in the process of arresting the firearm provider.

On Monday at around 10.30 am, Bhadange was on his way to a laundry shop when he was intercepted by the attackers. On seeing the four attackers, Bhadange started to run after which the attackers fired a bullet on the former. While the attackers missed the first shot, the second round hit Bhadange on his left hand.

Bhadange managed to reach his house and bolt the door after which the attackers escaped.

Title: Girl selected for Nasa trip, woman trucker honoured
Content:
Cuddalore: Class XI student K Jayalakshmi, who won a trip to National Aeronautics and Space Administration ( Nasa ) in the United States in May 2020, and Jothimani Gowthaman, the only woman driver of 60-tonne heavy cargo truck with 24 wheels from Tamil Nadu, were among those honoured during the international women’s day celebrations organised by NLC India Limited.

Joint secretary (coal ministry) Vismita Tej and superintendent of police (idol wing) S Rajeswari honoured the duo and others in the presence of Rakesh Kumar, NLCIL chairman-cum-managing director, and R Vikraman, director (human resources), as well as others. The company announced a prize of Rs 1 lakh each for Jayalakshmi and Jothimani.

Speaking on the occasion, Rakesh Kumar recalled the contribution of women employees in the field of engineering, medicine, sports and other areas in the company. He outlined the company’s role in empowering women employees.

He also made special mention on the company’s skill development initiatives for women from project affected families.

Vismita Tej emphasised the need to provide equal opportunities for women at the workplace to empower them. She said the roles and jobs for women should not be stereotyped by any organisation.

Earlier, the celebrations began with the screening of a short film on the contributions of women employees to the company, the society and economically weaker sections in the villages surrounding the lignite town. Neyveli Ladies Club president Kanchan Rakesh Kumar released a souvenir to mark the occasion. Forum of women in the public sector (Wips) presented sewing machines to six needy women from nearby villages.

Title: Toppers more stressed out than ever, say psychologists
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: It’s not the academically weak students who are approaching psychologists seeking help, but those scoring high marks are the ones who actually seem to be under tremendous stress.

Clinical psychologists say that they received calls from many Intermediate first year toppers asking if they would be among the toppers this year too. Likewise, many students, especially from the rural areas, are said to be approaching psychologists trying to know if they would be able to meet their parents’ or teachers’ expectations.

“A student called me and started crying. He said that he always topped in mathematics and his teacher is expecting him to score high marks even in the board exams,” said P Jawaharlal Nehru, a clinical psychologist, who mostly deals with students from rural areas. He said that despite preparing well and going through the syllabus thoroughly, students are worried that they might not reach their teacher’s expectations.

He said that he received calls from students from Mahabubnagar , Nirmal, Adilabad, West Godavari , Bhimavaram , Srikakulam, Sangareddy , and other towns and districts.

Seconding with Nehru, another clinical psychologist Anitha Are said that she received calls from state toppers in previous board examinations saying that they were afraid they might not be able to top in the exams this time.

Psychologists also said that students, their parents, and teachers, are also calling to ask if they can consume non-vegetarian food during the exam season, by what time a student should sleep, how to improve memory among various other things. “Many students want to know how they can improve their memory. All I could tell them is to revise thoroughly and take breaks while preparing so that they are not stressed out,” said Mazhar Ali, a senior psychiatrist, adding that he recommended meditation and breathing exercises for those facing anxiety issues.

Some of the other questions that are being asked by students, psychologists say, are how to always stay motivated, what will happen if pages are left empty in between answer scripts, among others. They said that many students were also worried about not performing well in Sanskrit examination, which is considered to be an easy subject.

Title: Include banana in noon meal scheme, farmers tell govt
Content:
Trichy: Banana farmers have appealed to the state government to include banana, a complete food, in the noon meal scheme to help farmers get a reasonable price for their crop.

In a letter to chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami, state organiser of the farmers’ wing of the Tamil Manila Congress Puliyur A Nagarajan said that when traders are selling Nendran chips for Rs 400 per kg, the producers get just Rs 10 per kg. It shows the pathetic condition of farmers, he said.

“Farmers cultivate Nendran banana in thousands of acres in Trichy district. Earlier, we had a very good demand in Kerala and it is not the case now. So, the government should fix a minimum support price, so that farmers would not incur a loss. Otherwise, the government should procure the variety and serve it to children under the noon meal scheme. Even the government can distribute it to the children in the form of chips,” he told TOI.

The agriculture marketing department should create some awareness about the marketing condition to the farmers, so that they can limit production according to the market conditions, he further stated.

“The banana belts such as Trichy and Karur should be announced as a protected zone for promoting banana cultivation to create opportunities for value addition of the produce,” he added.

Title: Cyber criminals dupe 8 from Nashik of over Rs 8 lakh since February
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Eight people were cheated to the tune of over Rs 8 lakh by fraudsters who posed as an executive of an online payment wallet and sought their KYC details.

The cybercrime police, who have registered two offences in this regard, said a man from the Tidke Colony area lost Rs 5.26 lakh between Friday and Saturday.

The complainant said that he got a call from a person who took details of his bank account on the pretext of updating his online payment wallet and later withdrew Rs 5.26 lakh.

In the other case, seven people were cheated of Rs 2.86 lakh in a similar fashion between February and March, said police.

Inspector Devraj Borse of the cybercrime police station said the fraudsters called them and said they wanted to update the KYC of the online payment wallet.

“The victims were told to download certain applications like Quick Support and Any Disk on their mobile phones. The fraudsters then siphoned off Rs 2.86 lakh,” said the officer.

The cybercrime police said that such cases involving fraudsters making random calls to people on the pretext of being bank officials or representatives has become common.

After winning the trust of their victims, the fraudsters take the details of their bank accounts and later cheat them of their money.

Police said that of late, online fraudsters have been sending certain links to their victims while urging them to click on the same, which ends up a person losing money.

Title: Nashik: Most road accident fatalities between midnight & 6 am
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Vehicled being driven at high speeds at night have been causing the highest number of road accident-related fatalities in the district, revealed the Nashik Regional Transport Office (RTO) at a workshop organised by it in the city for RTO officials from across five districts in the division.

In the January 2013-August 2018 period, 2,316 people died in 2,879 road accidents that took place between midnight and 6 am, said the Nashik RTO officials. Though the number of vehicles on the road during this time is less, the fatalities are more.

In a recent accident, a 34-year-old biker died when he was knocked down by a speeding sports utility vehicle (SUV) in the Nashik Road area around 12.30 am on Monday. His wife, riding pillion, suffered head injuries and a fractured right leg and is currently admitted in a private hospital in Nashik city . The SUV’s speed was so great that the vehicle’s airbags had deployed on impact. The biker died despite wearing a helmet.

Senior police officials too said that the vehicular speed was the primary killer.

Nashik rural police superintendent Arti Singh said, “There are a lot of things that lead to road accidents during the night hours . Though there are fewer vehicles on the road, the drivers are almost always overspeeding at night. Truck drivers transporting perishable items that need to be delivered on time also speed their vehicles. At the same time, many of them may also be tired and sleep-deprived. Those who doze off, meet with accidents.”

She said people should avoid night drives whenever possible. Illumination on the road is also important. Often, motorists are not able to make out the edge of the road. Hence, the installation of blinkers, cat’s eyes are important as well. The SP said they have also written to the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) to put up blinkers and cat’s eyes on the road.

Police officials said that since the roads are relatively empty at night compared to the daytime, the speed of vehicles is on the higher side. When the motorists have to apply sudden brakes, they fail.

There have been many accidents of speeding motorists ramming their vehicles into standstill vehicles on the road. Motorists have also got injured or killed when the vehicle in front of them had slowed down.

Meanwhile, the other time slot that recorded a high number of casualties in the survey by the RTO is the period between 3 pm and 6 pm wherein 2,299 people died in 3,036 accidents.

Title: Chairman, vice-chairman of CII elected
Content:
M Sankaranarayanan and K Vijay Ganesh

PUDUCHERRY: M Sankaranarayanan , Grand Technologies managing director and Aathmalayaa School (Karaikal) founder-cum-chairman, was elected as chairman of the Confederation of Indian Industry ( CII ), Puducherry state council for 2020-2021.

Poclain Hydraulics Pvt. Ltd. managing director K Vijay Ganesh was elected vice-chairman of CII, Puducherry state council.

A mechanical engineering graduate with an MBA, Sankaranarayanan has industry experience of more than 30 years in various disciplines, including operations, human resource, marketing, administration and finance. He has been closely associated with CII. He was the vice-chairman of CII Puducherry state council in 2019-2020. He was also the co-convenor of CII manufacturing/micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) panel (2018-2019) of CII, Puducherry.

Vijay Ganesh served as a convenor – manufacturing and MSME panel in 2019-2020.

Vijay Ganesh holds a master’s degree in engineering management from Birla Institute of Technology and a bachelor’s degree in mechanical engineering from National Institute of Technology , Trichy .

Title: ‘Dry land horticulture can bring good returns to farmers’
Content:
Madurai: Deputy director of horticulture, Madurai, G O Bhoopathy says that Murugesan’s orchard is proof of successful dry land horticulture. In a brief chat with TOI he says that the method could bring good returns to farmers. He says other farmers should try this on their land.

Is growing exotic fruit varieties like jambus, soursop and figs possible in Madurai’s climate?

There is a concept called dry land horticulture, and Murugesan is an example that it can be done successfully. Almost all types of exotic fruits, including dragon fruit, and figs can be grown this way.

Isn’t irrigation important to horticultural crops?

If the farmers go for drip irrigation, which is subsidized by the central government, farmers can reap the benefits. Fruit trees can be grown this way even in the driest land.

What is unique about going for dry land horticulture?

These fruits are rich in minerals and full of nutrients and sell for a very good price and farmers can really benefit from it.

Title: Growing exotic fruits in Madurai no longer a mirage
Content:
Madurai: Orchards aren’t something one expects to see in Madurai. But on the outskirts beyond Thirupalai, an experiment to change that is, literally, bearing fruit.

In an orchard, R Murugesan, a farmer, has been able to grow exotic fruits, many of them unknown to Madurai’s landscape. The achievement is a result of a few years of experimentation and hard work.

Murugesan says that he took it as a challenge to grow fruit-bearing trees in his 10 acre land, when many told him that the land is good for paddy only. “I decided to plant exotic fruit varieties, such as jambu or wax apple, figs, soursop, star fruit and oranges, which were not known to be grown in Madurai soil. My friends from Bangalore helped me get the saplings,’’ he said.

The jambu trees that he planted two years ago have grown well and are laden with fruit and the branches are breaking due to the weight. He has covered the two big trees with nets to ward off parrots and other birds.

Other trees such as soursop, orange and star fruit have also started bearing fruit. Murugesan says that his orchard is proof that nothing is impossible. Now, he plans to expand his orchard by planting around 40 more saplings of jambu, soursop, fig and gooseberry.

He ensures that he does not use chemical fertilizers for his plants, though people suggest him of using enhancers to quicken the growth. He uses manure of his goats and native cattle for his orchard and drip irrigation ensures that the plants get all the water they needed.

Apart from this he has a couple of jackfruit trees, banana groves, guava and mangoes. Many of the exotic fruits such as jambus sell for not less than Rs 120 per kg and there are many residents in Madurai city who make advance bookings for their share, when the harvest begins. “Farm fresh fruits are rare in Madurai, and we look forward to our share whenever Murugesan says he will pick the fruit,” said S Saraswathi of Anna Nagar.

Madurai district collector T G Vinay visited his orchard. Murugesan received a certificate of appreciation for his efforts from the collector on the Republic Day, which he says was a great source of encouragement.

Title: Health department seeks MD doctors, ventilators to treat patients
Content: NASHIK: The district health department is taking all necessary steps to ensure they are ready to treat patients found suffering from corona virus (Covid-19).As part of this, senior officials of Nashik civil hospital have sought ventilators , multi para monitors and five additional MD doctors for treating the positive Covid-19 cases.Suresh Jagdale, district civil surgeon, said, “A request in this regard has been made to district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal . While there is no immediate need for the equipment and doctors, the demand has been made in view of a possibility in the near future as five positive cases have already come to fore in Pune.”He added, “The district guardian minister has assured us that he would speak to the state health minister in this regard and make the doctors and necessary equipment available to the Nashik civil hospital at the earliest.”Jagdale said the doctors or medical equipment would be used as and when required. “An isolation ward has also been set up at Malegaon general hospital. The equipment and the doctors are needed there,” he said.Meanwhile, 15 beds have already been reserved at Nashik civil hospital if more travelers from affected countries start suffering health issues and have to be admitted in the isolation ward.“So far, all travellers from affected countries who developed health complications mainly cold, cough or fever after coming to Nashik and had to be kept in the isolation ward for treatment have tested negative for the disease,” said Jagdale.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Vellore collector reviews preparedness
Content: VELLORE: Collector of Vellore A Shanmuga Sundaram on Tuesday examined preparedness measures launched against the spread of coronavirus in the district.Inspecting disinfectant use by civic workers in the new bus stand, Shanmuga Sundaram distributed awareness pamphlets to the public and passengers at the terminus.Addressing media representatives, Shanmuga Sundaram said, “In the wake of coronavirus alert, the Vellore district administration has come up with preparedness measures, including making hand sanitisers available at all public gathering spots such as schools, colleges and other tourists spots. We have also made arrangements to conduct two-day awareness programmes at all public spots in the district headquarters, educating people about the seriousness of the infection and how to ensure protection from it.”As per our report, more than 800 students from various countries study in Vellore Institute of Technology and we have sent a circular to the college administration asking it not to send the students to their country for any reason, the collector said.We have also advised the college not to allow parents from abroad to visit their children, Shanmuga Sundaram said.The Vellore district administration has launched steps to set up 13 screening spots to prevent the spread of coronavirus through patients from abroad visiting CMC hospital and other tourists spots, including foreign devotees during their visit to the Tirupati temple in neighbouring Andhra Pradesh.Shanmuga Sundaram also requested people not to panic as the situation is under control.Deputy director public health department Suresh, Vellore corporation sanitary department officer and other public health department officials were present during the awareness programme conducted by the district administration.

Title: Nashik: Vipassana cancels its camps for March
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The well-known Dhamma Giri – Vipassana International Academy at Igatpuri has cancelled all three camps this month due to the Covid-19 scare. Over 2,000 participants, including many foreigners, were registered to attend the session.

The institute has sent emails and messages to all the participants saying that the residential camps were being cancelled for indefinite time as they have been instructed to avoid large gatherings.

Madhu Savla, head teacher of the Vipassana centre, said “We had a discussion with district collector Suraj Mandhare on Monday, who instructed us to cancel the gatherings in wake of the outbreak of Covid-19 across the globe. We have intimated all the participants via emails and messages that the camps stand cancelled until further instructions.”

The first monthly short camp of 10 days, which was to begin on Wednesday had 600 male and 400 female registrations. Such camps take place every month, which have about 10% foreign participants to take part in the meditation activities. The other short camp was to begin from March 25 with 700 male and 400 female registrations.

“As many as 150 participants had registered for the long camp of 30 to 45 days. Among the participants were 70 foreign participants. The camp was to commence on March 25,” a volunteer told TOI.

Every camp also involves nearly 20 volunteers (dhamma sevaks) to help in smooth functioning of the self-introspective activities for the whole day.

The entire practice of Vipassana is based on mental training. The participants practice meditation by keeping silent for the whole day and are asked to abstain from any contact from their family and friends.

The beginners take up the short 10-day camps. Those who want to go for the longer camps of 30 days have to complete several short camps whereas to participate in the 45 days camps, completion of two 30 days camps is mandatory.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Five women arrested for selling arrack
Content:
Representative image

VELLORE: The Vaniyambadi taluk police, while conducting a surprise raid at Vijayanagar and Veeranamalai on the Andhra Pradesh border on Tuesday, arrested five women and seized about 300 litres of arrack from them.

Following multiple complaints that spurious liquor was being smuggled from Andhra Pradesh and sold in the border villages of AP and Vaniyambadi in Tamil Nadu, a team led by inspector K Mangayarkarasi, acting on a tip, conducted a surprise raid at more than five places. In the raid at Vijaya Nagar, police arrested Rani, 51, Sumathi, 48, Tirupathi, 35, and Vijaya 51. In a similar raid at Veeranamalai, they arrested Vijaya, 55. In all, they seized 300 litres of arrack from the five women. Inquiries revealed that the accused were involved in smuggling of arrack made in AP for more than a decade and sold it from their houses. Police registered a case under Section 4(1-aaa)and 4(1-A) of the Tamil Nadu Prohibition Act.

Title: PIL seeks greater accountability from social media firms over hate speech
Content:
BENGALURU: In light of last month’s riots in Delhi in which over 50 people lost their lives, former Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) ideologue K N Govindacharya has filed a public interest litigation (PIL) in Delhi high court seeking a direction from the court to ask social media platforms to disclose details of their designated officers so that the public can flag hate speech and fake news/videos and these can be taken down in time. The court has listed the matter for a hearing, likely to be this week.

The PIL, reviewed by TOI, also seeks a direction from the court for social media platforms to take ‘immediate’ action on such content during events like Delhi riots, in which the latest death toll is 53, besides property damages. This comes in the wake of reports that the home ministry pulled up online platforms earlier this month for not taking down objectionable content fast enough during Delhi violence and warning them of legal action.

The designated officers of the social media firms mentioned here are different from a grievance officer, one of the lawyers involved in the PIL said.

“On many occasions, social media companies have censored or taken down the content, against which many users have grievances, but they are left with no remedy to approach appropriate authority. Similarly, there is hateful content that is not taken down, which in turn causes more crimes and leaves everyone hapless,” the PIL said by adding that such objectionable content is a big source of revenue for social media companies. Govindacharya has made the home ministry, IT ministry, and finance ministry a part of the PIL.

A Twitter India spokesperson declined to comment on the matter while Facebook India did not respond to TOI’s query. Without commenting directly, a YouTube India spokesperson said, “Over the last year, we’ve worked to better surface credible news sources on YouTube. We’ve changed our search and discovery algorithms to surface credible content, built new features that clearly label and prominently surface news sources on our homepage and search pages, and introduced information panels to help give users more sources where they can fact check information for themselves.”

Title: Harvest of summer onion begins, crop arrives at Lasalgaon
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Farmers have started harvesting the fresh summer onions and the kitchen staple is trickling into the Lasalgaon APMC, the country’s largest wholesale onion market. Around 600-800 quintals of fresh summer onions were auctioned on Tuesday at the market. At the same time, around 15,000 quintals of late kharif crop also arrived at the market.

While the shelf life of kharif and late kharif onions is less than a month, the shelf life of summer onions is over six months. Hence, farmers prefer storing summer onions with an eye on better price. Farmers sell summer onions as per their requirement of money.

APMC officials said there is a little price difference between summer and kharif onions. Summer onions are costlier by Rs 500 per quintal than kharif onions. Unseasonal rains had damaged kharif onions and continuous rains had also delayed the plantation of late kharif onions.

This also delayed plantation of summer onions. Every year, plantation of summer onions take place by December end, but it continued by mid-Feb, said APMC officials.

“Usually, the harvest of summer onions begins from the first week of March. But this year, the harvest has delayed due to late plantation. It will take around two-three weeks for the supply of summer onions to normalise,” said APMC officials.

The average wholesale onion prices were recorded at Rs 1,800 per quintal on Monday at Lasalgaon APMC, against Rs 1,930 per quintal on Friday. The minimum and maximum wholesale onion prices were recorded at Rs 1,000 and Rs 1,921 per quintal, respectively, on Monday.

The average wholesale onion prices have dropped by almost 80% in past three months, from Rs 8,625 per quintal on December 16 to Rs 1,800 per quintal so far due to rise in supply as compared to demand.

APMC officials said the rise in supply as compared to demand has led to drop in average wholesale onion prices. The average wholesale onion prices may stabilise after the onion export begins.

On March 2, the union commerce ministry issued a notification regarding lifting of ban on onion export from March 15. According to APMC officials, the average wholesale onion prices may increase marginally by Rs 200 per quintal after March 15.

Title: Nashik: Exhibition dedicated to Kusumagraj
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: A painting exhibition has been organised by four city-based artists in the memory of renowned poet Kusumagraj at Kusumagraj Pratishthan, which will conclude on Wednesday.

The artists have put on display 35 items of paintings and sculptures including six metal sculptures in the exhibition. “We have been exhibiting our paintings in front of the city art lovers for 20 years. This is yet another opportunity for us to display our new endeavours. My paintings are on acrylic and I have experimented from nature to abstract in my landscapes,” said Atul Bhalerao, one of the painters.

The painters will be taking the exhibition at Jehangir Art Gallery in Mumbai at the end of this month. The four artists are teachers in different schools and colleges in the city who have displayed their works in various countries like the UAE and Lebanon. “Within six months, our next stop is Spain,” added Bhalerao.

Over 1000 people have admired the paintings and sculptures at the exhibition in the past 10 days which kick-started on March 1. They have exclaimed that the exhibits are different from others. “I have used a mixed medium in my oil paintings. The theme that I have used is mythological iconography revolving around Lord Vishnu,” said Bharti Hingne, another painter.

Santosh Masal, the third painter in the group, has used roller in his paintings to give a different texture. All the paintings identify and interpret nature in different ways.

Sujitkumar Mukhopadhyay, who is a central government officer in the Currency Note Press, brought his sculptures into the exhibition. “My pieces of art are made up of brass, bronze or wood. They represent nature from my view. As a piece of the mother tree depicts that it gives life to all and deforestation causes harm to it,” said Mukhopadhyay.

Title: Govt keen on monetary aid to empower women: Rane
Content:
Valpoi: Minister for women and child development and Valpoi MLA Vishwajit Rane on Tuesday said the state government was committed to providing financial support to empower women.

Rane was speaking as chief guest during a function held to celebrate Women’s Day at Valpoi.

“Equal opportunity to women on political and social platforms is a must. The department of women and child welfare has been working at different levels in a bid to achieve this,” he said during his address.

The minister also said the process of empowering women has already been initiated through the various welfare schemes that are presently on offer in the state.

Eight women were also felicitated by Rane for their contribution to society.

Title: Latambarcem gets new sarpanch
Content: Bicholim: Dnyneshwar Gawas was elected as the new sarpanch of Latambarcem panchayat, in Bicholim, on Monday. The post had fallen vacant after former sarpanch Prashant Ghadi tendered his resignation recently. As no other nomination was received for the post, Gawas was elected unopposed in the presence of panch members Prashant Ghadi, Sameer Gawas, Kunda Chari, Vandita Ghadi, Bablo Gaonkar, Yeshwant Varak, Trupti Gaonkar and Balkrishna Parwar.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Two women killed as mini-truck overturns
Content:
Representative image

VELLORE: Two women were killed and 12 occupants of a mini-truck suffered injuries after the vehicle overturned when the driver lost control at Nemili in Ranipet district on Monday night.

M Muthu, 50, of Keezhatheri in Tiruvallur district and his relatives were returning to the village after a family function at Thiruvalayam near Nemili when mini-truck driver Prabhu, while trying to negotiate a narrow curve, lost control of the vehicle and it overturned, a senior police officer said. In the impact, M Kavitha, 37, and G Samathanam, 65, were killed on the spot.

The incident left 12 others, including Prabhu, injured. On information, police rushed to the spot and rescued the injured passengers and and sent them to government hospitals in Kancheepuram, Walajapet and Vellore. The bodies of the two women were sent to Arakkonam government hospital for autopsy.

The Nemili police registered a case under Section 279 (rash driving or riding on a public way), Section 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) and Section 304A (causing death by negligence) of the IPC against the driver and are questioning him for illegally ferrying passengers in the mini-truck.

Title: YSRC’s nominees for Rajya Sabha meet Jaganmohan Reddy, to file nominations today
Content:
Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: Rajya Sabha nominees from the state met chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy at his Tadepalli residence on Tuesday.

Minister for fisheries Mopidevi Venkata Ramana and industrialist Alla Ayodhya Rami Reddy met the chief minister and thanked him for selecting them to Rajya Sabha. They said they would do their best to get funds to the state from the central government during their term.

Mopidevi said the development of backward classes is possible only with Jaganmohan Reddy. He said the chief minister had given 50% of the Rajya Sabha seats to the BCs in this round of elections. Besides giving 34% representation to the BCs in the local body elections, he said that the chief minister is committed to give due share to the BCs in all elected and nominated posts. He thanked the chief minister for naming him and his cabinet colleague Pilli Subhash Chandra Bose to Rajya Sabha.

Ayodhya Rami Reddy said that he would mobilise more investments to the state using his connections in the industry. He said that the government was committed to invite more investments to the state and he would help the state on these lines.

Meanwhile, Parimal Nathwani, Reliance Industries representative and sitting MP from Jharkhand, thanked the chief minister for giving him an opportunity to represent AP in Rajya Sabha. He met Jaganmohan Reddy on Tuesday evening and thanked him for the nomination . Nathwani, who is completing his second term as Rajya Sabha member on April 9, is given another chance from AP. He told the media persons that he would use his relations with the investors in the country to develop AP. “I am thankful to the chief minister for the opportunity given to me. I will do my best for the development of AP,” Nathwani said.

Meanwhile, sources in the ruling YSRC said that all the four candidates would file their nominations on March 11 in the assembly. March 13 is the last day for filing nominations and the election, if required, will be held on March 26.

Title: T liabilities rise to touch Rs 2 lakh cr
Content:
Hyderabad: Though government debt is well within the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) limits, its liabilities have mounted to about Rs 2 lakh crore — up by Rs 23,934 crore from the last financial year of 2018-19. Sources said the government owes Rs 10,000 crore bills to irrigation and roads and buildings (R&B) contractors alone.

The liabilities include open market borrowings, loans from the Centre, borrowings from financial institutions and banks and special securities issued by the National Small Savings Fund.

In the fiscal policy submitted to the assembly during the budget presentation recently, it was said the government’s liabilities for 2019-20 stood at Rs 1,99,215 crore, which was Rs 1,75,281 crore in 2018-19. Experts said this was a direct liability on the government since it had taken loans and financial aid from various institutions for implementing schemes and clearing pending bills to the contractors.

“A major portion of the liabilities are market borrowings which rose from Rs 1.33 lakh crore to Rs 1.58 lakh crore. Borrowings from the financial institutions and banks reduced from Rs 14,254 crore to Rs 13,797 crore from the last financial year,” the financial statement said. Senior finance officials said that of the total liabilities, about Rs 80,000 crore was accrued from undivided Andhra Pradesh.

Various corporations, special purpose vehicles (SPVs) such as Kaleshwaram Lift Irrigation Corporation, Mission Bhagiratha Corporation, Hyderabad Road Development Corporation Ltd and other agencies, which were set up by the government, availed loans totalling Rs 40,000 crore in the last five years for which the government stood as a guarantor.

As far as outstanding guarantees were concerned, the government gave Rs 7,000 crore guarantee in the current financial year. The guaranteed amount was Rs 40,241 crore, which saw a jump from Rs 33,739 crore in 2018-19.

“Of the government’s guaranteed loans and assistance, Rs 38,800 crore of Rs 40,241 crore fall in the medium risk category. The agencies and corporations, which had borrowed the money, may not be in a position to repay going by the current financial position. GHMC also falls in this category,” a senior official explained.

The Centre had increased FRBM limit of Telangana to 3.5% of GSDP from 3% in 2017. “Though the government is raising borrowings from the market with loan terms extending to 40 years, the borrowings limit of FRBM was 3%, which is lower than what the Centre has set,” a senior official said. “Telangana’s debt is well within FRBM limits and fiscally prudent,” he added.

Title: Allot stalls by lake before season ends: Mayem locals
Content:
Bicholim: Looking to capitalise on what is left of the tourist season, Mayem villagers have demanded that the tourism department allot them areas for stalls at the lake at the earliest.

They have also urged local MLA Pravin Zantye to make efforts to get tourist buses to the Mayem lake so that business can flourish once more like it did in the past.

“Presently, we are facing an acute financial crunch as mining activities have also been stopped. Under such circumstances, it would have been good if the shops were allotted without further delay,” Vaman Nagvekar, a local from Mayem, said.

Zantye told TOI that everything is in place for allotment of stalls and that only lifting of the election code of conduct is awaited. “Once the code is lifted, shops will be allotted,” he said.

The code of conduct has been enforced for the upcoming zilla panchayat polls and will be lifted on March 23.

With regard to the issue of tourist buses, Zantye said the tourism department has identified four spots — Saptakoteshwar temple in Narvem, Arvalem waterfall, Mayem lake, and Salim Ali bird sanctuary in Chorao.

“Once these are finalised, then tourist buses will start coming to Mayem lake again,” he told TOI, adding that there is ample parking space.

A villager, Deepak Kinalkar, said that the busloads of tourists that would come to the lake in the past helped boost business and that when they stopped their income was severely affected.

“We therefore demand that the government take the initiative to restart tourist buses to Mayem village,” Kinalkar said.

To facilitate tourism and avoid traffic congestion, Zantye said that the road from the lake to Chorao has been taken up for widening.

Three years ago, former Mayem legislator Anant Shet had undertaken beautification and extension of the lake through the tourism department. The work was recently completed.

In the newly extended area, locals were allotted 26 shops to the left of the lake.

Title: Cleanliness drive in Nashik: NMC fines 72 erring citizens Rs 81,000
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: A total of 72 erring citizens have been fined Rs 81,000 in the first eight days of March by the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) for non-segregation of waste, not maintaining cleanliness in public places, dumping of construction waste in open spaces and using banned plastic bags.

The drive was launched on March 1 under the Maharashtra Nagri Swachh Abhiyan and will last for two months.

“The state government has asked all civic bodies to observe cleanliness campaigns in their jurisdiction in view of the 60th foundation day of Maharashtra on May 1. The campaign will be implemented between March 1 and April 30. The state government has already issued a government resolution (GR) in this connection,” a civic official said.

“According to the directives of the state government, participation of the citizens is a must in the civic cleanliness drive,” an NMC official said.

Solid waste management, road improvement and beautification, streetlight repairs and improvement, traffic islands and beautification of road dividers, beautification of city flyovers and gardens, removal of illegal hoardings, implementation of hawking policy, cleaning of city nullahs, regular cleanliness, participation of people and availability of funds are the key components of the civic cleanliness drive.

“We have started taking action against erring citizens responsible for non-segregation of waste, dumping construction waste on open space, dumping of garbage in the open, in order to make the city clean,” said NMC officials.

The civic body slapped a fine of Rs 26,300 on 32 citizens for throwing garbage in public places. “18 have been fined Rs 7,000 for non-segregation of waste, while 17 were slapped fine of Rs 18,500 for dumping construction waste in open spaces,” the official said.

Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game has directed the officials to continue their action against erring citizens until the city becomes clean and plastic free.

Title: Naidu slams EC for not following poll code
Content:
Guntur: TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu said the Election Commission has failed to take action against YSRC cadres and officials for not removing the party colours on government buildings.

“The State Election Commission has failed to control the YSRC leaders even as they are preventing opposition from filing nominations in local body elections,” said Naidu.

He said the SEC should have directed the officials to remove these colours and hoardings and put covers on statues by the time the election notification was issued and election code came into effect on March 7.

He said the government wasted Rs 1,500 crore for painting panchayat offices in YSRC colours and an equal amount would be required now to remove those. He raised objection to municipal administration commissioner Vijay Kumar sitting with SEC N Ramesh Kumar in the press conference.

Naidu condemned the attack on TDP nominee at Pinnelli in Machavaram mandal of Gurazala assembly segment in Guntur district.

He said a police constable obstructed and detained the TDP candidate illegally to block his nomination in Sullurpet. He said that police filed false cases against TDP nominee at Eedurupalli in Nagaram of Repalle area only to frighten and prevent him from filing nominations.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Untreated sewage ravages Buckingham Canal on Old Mahabalipuram Road
Content:
A truck dumping sewage in the backwaters of Buckhingam Canal in Kalipattur

CHENNAI: The backwaters of the Buckingham Canal in Kalipattur on Rajiv Gandhi Expressway ( Old Mahabalipuram Road ) are being polluted by untreated sewage being released by lorries and officials concerned are doing little about it, say residents.

The solid waste that is dumped on the banks and burned by miscreants is compounding the problem, they say.

R Meera, who lives in an apartment complex in the area, said the stench from the untreated sewage and fumes from the burning garbage was unbearable. “We approached the local panchayat to highlight the issue as it was posing a huge health hazard, especially at a time when everyone is in a panic over Covid-19,” she said. While senior panchayat officials did not react, staff in the office had told them that the dumping was being moved to Maraimalai Nagar and the foul smell would dissipate in a few days, she added.

A senior public works department official said they had received a similar complaint from people in Navalur and that they had written to the panchayat there to look into the issue. Now, following complaints on the release of untreated sewage into the water body, an assistant engineer will be sent to the spot to check if the complaints are true. The department will then lodge a complaint with police, he said.

When contacted, J Venkat, an official of the Muttukadu panchayat, under whose jurisdiction Kalipattur village comes, said they regularly receive complaints about untreated raw sewage being let out into the water body. Even in February, they had caught a truck red handed, when it was releasing sewage into the water body, he said. The vehicle owner was made to pay a penalty to the panchayat as well as the taluk office.

Asked about the dumping and burning of unsegregated waste on the banks of the water body, Venkat said the panchayat had obtained permission to relocate the waste to a waste disposal unit near Singaperumalkoil. The work will begin on Wednesday and residents will soon be free of the problem of stench, he added.

Title: Quepem bizmen protest steep hike in sanitation fee, trade licence tax
Content:
Quepem: The Quepem Municipal Council’s (QMC) decision to hike the sanitation fee by nearly 600%, garbage collection fee by over 200% and double the trade licence tax has not gone down too well with shopkeepers in the town. They allege that the hikes are very steep.

Incidentally, recent protests led to the civic body keeping in abeyance a proposal to hike property tax.

The sanitation fee, which was Rs 1 per day, has been hiked to Rs 6. Meanwhile, the door-to-door garbage collection fee, which was doubled in 2018 from Rs 360 to Rs 720, has been increased again, this time by over 200%.

“This year, when I went to pay the fee, the QMC official told me it is Rs 2,270,” bakery owner Felix Pinto said.

And in almost a double blow to the shopkeepers, the trade licence tax for 2020 has been doubled, too.

“Unable to pay both, the sanitation fee and trade tax at one go, I paid QMC half the amount. A few days later, I received a notice asking for the rest of the amount to be paid, along with 50% interest. My garbage bin does not overflow even after eight days,” one shopkeeper, Santosh Samant, said.

Another shop owner, Francisco D’Costa, has forked out Rs 2,695 as sanitation fee. “It is difficult to pay such a huge amount as sanitation fee and then the trade licence fee too, particularly since the business is not hugely profitable,” he said.

Quepem Shopkeepers Association president, John Fernandes recently wrote to QMC chairperson Dayesh Naik requesting that a meeting be convened among the council, the shopkeepers and locals MLA Chandrakant Kavlekar. In the letter he said the council had arbitrarily and unreasonably increased different taxes, which the shopkeepers are liable to pay.

Accordingly, a meeting was held on February 25 wherein shopkeepers put forth their complaints about difficulties they have been facing in paying the increased amounts and demanded that they be lowered. The meeting, however, was inconclusive.

Justifying the fee hikes, Naik told TOI that the civic body had not increased the trade tax for many years, as a result of which shopkeepers were paying a nominal fee.

Fernandes said, “Fee hikes should be proportionate. They cannot be increased so steeply at one shot. Also, some shopkeepers do not generate much garbage and this is an injustice to them. If the council is short of funds, it should reassess house tax. Many people have constructed bungalows and buildings on single room houses, but are paying a nominal house tax.”

Title: HC rejects plea to change zoning of ‘private forest’
Content:
Panaji: The high court of Bombay at Goa has rejected the petition of a businessman from Mapusa who claimed he had been deprived of his fundamental right to practice business as he was being denied a no-objection certificate (NOC) for conversion of a property.

“If the petitioner is permitted to convert the property to any other use, it will be virtually impossible to remedy the irreversible situation. The approach of the deputy conservator of forests in declining the NOC at this stage was quite right and warrants no interference,” the division bench comprising justices Mahesh Sonak and M S Jawalkar said.

The court also stated that the issue of whether the property concerned was private forest or not could not be decided hurriedly and haphazardly. “Such an exercise has to be taken up in a holistic manner,” it said.

The businessman had challenged the November 29, 2019 communication by the deputy conservator of forests, North Goa division, Ponda, which stated that the matter of demarcation of private forests was sub judice before the National Green Tribunal (NGT).

The forest department has stated that the area in question was reflected as private forest in the Karapur Committee report and hence his application for NOC for conversion of the property could be considered.

Shivan Desai, the businessman’s counsel, stated that the exercise of demarcation and review had already been carried out and has been going on for the past 20 years. Stating that the land has not been classified as private forest, he sought that the impugned communication be set aside. The court, however, stated that the NGT has been monitoring the situation and held that the forest department was right in rejecting his application for NOC on the ground that the matter is pending before the NGT.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Hundreds of Telangana, Andhra Pradesh students stranded as Italy on lockdown
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

VISAKHAPATNAM: Hundreds of Telugu students from AP and Telangana are stranded in Italy as the Mediterranean country went into lockdown to tackle the sudden surge in Covid-19 cases. The students are in places such as Padova, Rimini, Modena, Milan — all declared red zones for the virus. With Italy registering 97 deaths on March 9, more government restrictions, especially in travelling, have been placed from Tuesday.

The students are a worried lot given the shortage of masks and restricted entry at supermarkets. From Tuesday, everyone has been told to confine themselves at home while shutting down all public places.

Telugu students that TOI spoke to said hospitals were reluctant to give ‘fit’ certificates and there was no provision to check those without symptoms, making it difficult for them to return. Sources added that Indian embassy authorities too are insisting on fit certificates to be considered for evacuation.

Badarinath Gella from Kodad in Suryapet district of Telangana has just completed his engineering degree from one of world’s oldest institutions in Italy – the 931-year-old University of Bologna. He told TOI from Italy: “Over 30 of us are still stranded in Bologna. I am worried. It is very difficult and time consuming to get medical fitness certificate here, especially because we do not have symptoms.”

Nearly 50 Indian students are studying at the University of Padova, which is again a red zone, while five Telugu students, mostly from Vijayawada, are stranded at Moderna. Leela Krishna Chowdary from Anantapur, studying agriculture in Padova said, “As Padova got quarantined we cannot come back to India. We are not even allowed to move to other cities.”

A Sree Charan Teja from Hyderabad, a final year aeronautical engineering student at Milan, had to remain back as he had a renewal date for a stay permit. “When Codogno was quarantined, there were no stores open, including grocery stores,” he said. “It will be bad if the situation is similar in Milan. There are around 100 Telugu students there. The rules don’t allow more than 10 people at a time in supermarkets.”

He added: “When it comes to health check-ups, we need to call 1500 if we have symptoms. But as per my knowledge there are no health camps where we can volunteer for a virus check-up. As per current national restrictions, all institutes and places of public interest, sports and wellness centres are closed till April 3,” he said.

Prasanth Chasdiel, hailing from Mantada village in Krishna district of AP, who is studying for MSc in tourism economics and management from Rimini campus of the University of Bologna, said: “Rimini has been quarantined along with 11 other provinces. During the outbreak, the flight prices were hiked. We cannot move out and we also need a fitness certificate to come to India. Everyone is worried at home.”

Title: TDP to field Ramaiah for RS polls
Content:
Amaravati: TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu has decided to field a candidate in the Rajya Sabha elections.

With only 23 MLAs, TDP has no numbers to win any seat. TDP’s decision to field the candidate will only prompt the authorities to conduct the polling.

Earlier, the officials thought that it could be a unanimous one as YSRC has the strength to win all the four seats from the state.

Speaking to the media here on Tuesday, Naidu said that they have decided to field senior leader Varla Ramaiah to uphold the democratic process. He, however, appealed to YSRC legislators to support Ramaiah keeping in view of the CM’s undemocratic attitude and anti-people rule.

Naidu said TDP would issue whip to all the party legislators. He said that TDP legislators have to cast their vote by showing it to the party election agent. “We will take action against those violated the whip under anti-defection laws,” warned Naidu.

Sources said Naidu has decided to field a candidate in the RS elections only to make defectors fall in line. Gannavaram MLA Vallabhaneni Vamsi and Guntur West MLA Maddali Giridhar have been hobnobbing with YSRC without quitting as MLAs. They were working for the victory of YSRC candidates in the local body elections without formally joining the party.

Title: Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation starts trial of boats to be used at boat club
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation ( MTDC ) has started trial run of boats that would be used by the boat club at Gangapur dam on the outskirts of the city.

An MTDC official said that the trails are being carried out to ensure that the boats are in proper shape. “The boat club will become functional by April-end and initially 11 boats would be deployed for the tourists,” he said.

This project was the brainchild of district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal and was planned in the year 2014. However, the former BJP-led state government put the project on backburner.

After the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA)-led state government came to power, Bhujbal again started focusing on projects started by him like the boat club.

Bhujbal had recently visited the boat club at Gangapur dam to review the status and directed the officials concerned to carry out the repair work and speed up the project.

“The boats were procured five years ago and needed some repair works. We have a total of 40 boats and have repaired around five of them. We are conducting trials of the boats that are to be deployed for boating in Gangapur dam. We have permission to operate only 11 boats. We will soon seek water resources department’s approval for more boats,” the official said.

“Earlier, we had plans to deploy a private agency to operate the boat club. But we have now changed our plan. We will start the boat club on our own and will take a call on deploying private agency after few months,” the official said.

The MTDC had procured as many as 45 boats for the boat club project, but 10 of these boats were taken to Sarankheda by former state tourism minister Jay Kumar Rawal in last two years. Later, five boats were returned to the boat club.

The district guardian minister has already made it clear that he would not bring those five boats from Sarankheda and he has donated those boats to Rawal.

Title: Foreigner denied bail in sex racket
Content:
Panaji: The high court of Bombay at Goa has dismissed the bail application of a 20-year-old Turkmenistan national who was arrested by Anjuna police last December for human trafficking.

The foreigner, who had come to India on a student visa, was held for his involvement in a prostitution racket involving women from Turkmenistan and Kyrgyzstan, and was booked under the Immoral Traffic Prevention Act.

“He crossed the borders and indulged in such activities despite having come to this country on a student visa and otherwise overstayed his visit, for which he is charged accordingly, and apparently has to face trial before the Judicial Magistrate First Class,” justice Nutan Sardessai said. “Looking at the seriousness of the offence of trafficking, the applicant would not be entitled to the benefit of bail.”

The court said that upon perusing the statements of the survivors that were put on record, it was apparent that the man had a role to play in pushing the women into prostitution and collecting money from them as commission. It also said that the accused’s role was required to unearth the process by which he procured the women and used them for prostitution in Goa.

“The possibility of the applicant fleeing from justice also cannot be ruled out as remote,” the court added.

Title: Chennai: Central metro yet to fully integrate with MGR Central railway station
Content:
The area given to Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) has been paved with interlocked tiles

CHENNAI: It’s been two years since Central metro rail station was opened, but there is no seamless connectivity or a walking path for commuters to access MGR Central railway station .

Alternative arrangements to integrate Central metro to MGR Central are yet to take shape after Southern Railway didn’t allow metro to build a subway connecting the metro station with the railway station.

All entry/exits of the station, which connect two metro lines, have been opened and the area given to Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) has been paved with interlocked tiles. But commuters who take the metro train to reach MGR Central struggle to reach the main railway station to board express trains since there is no dedicated pathway from metro entry or exit points to the railway station.

The uneven tiles are a hassle for the passengers because they find it difficult to roll their trolley bags. Besides, cars, cabs and two-wheelers that drive by the front of the railway station towards the parking area and the Moore Market Complex suburban station come in the way of people who walking from MGR Central to the metro station and vice versa.

“I find it difficult to reach the station with the heavy bags. Most of the people come up through escalators and lifts but have to walk a long way. The long walk is not an issue if there is a smooth pathway that is easier to move luggage,” said Arun Kumar, a passenger headed to Central.

The MGR Central station campus is chaotic in the evening when there are several departures of express trains. Since metro lines connect key areas of the city like Parry’s, Anna Nagar, Egmore, Koyambedu, CMBT, airport and others people proceeding to board trains at Central prefer to use the metro to beat the evening rush hour traffic. Central metro is the second busiest station with around 9,000 commuters using it daily.

In contrast, CMRL and Airports Authority of India have installed good connectivity between airport metro station and the airport using a tube and a walkalator. T K Pandian, a regular commuter, said, “They have built a good facility for commuters to access the airport. Similar planning doesn’t seem to have been done for connecting MGR Central and Central metro.”

A canopy has been installed near the Moore Market complex entrance of the railway station for commuters to reach the suburban and the railway stations.

A railway official said there will be more amenities for passengers when CMRL completes its Central Square project. A new pathway between Central metro and Moore Market Complex will also be set up as part of the Central Square project which is underway.

Title: TDP suffers jolt as Satish Reddy, Kadiri quit party
Content:
AMARAVATI: In what could be big a jolt to TDP , Pulivendula strongman and former legislative council deputy chairman SV Satish Reddy quit the party.

He said he has lost hope in the TDP leadership. He said he failed to get due recognition despite working for the party with commitment. Sources said Satish Reddy is all set to join YSRC.

Satish Reddy had lost assembly elections against YS Rajasekhara Reddy, YS Vijayamma and YS Jaganmohan Reddy in Pulivendula since 2004.

In another shocker to TDP, former MLA and close friend of Nandamuri Balakrishna, Kadiri Babu Rao joined YSRC in the presence of YSRC president and chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy at the latter’s camp office here on Tuesday. Baburao had represented Kanigiri assembly constituency in Prakasam district between 2014-19.

Speaking to the media after joining YSRC, Baburao said he quit TDP after realizing that they could not work under Chandrababu Naidu’s leadership anymore. “I have been working for TDP for the last 34 years and joined YSRC along with my cadre as we can’t work along with Naidu” said Baburao.

He said that people have faith in Jagan’s rule as he had been working for the uplift of all sections in society. “I respect Nandmuri Balakrishna. I believe that my friend Balakrishna was also being deceived by Naidu. I hope he will also realize this soon,” said Baburao.

Kapu leader Thota Trimurthulu, who accompanied Baburao, said Baburao had decided to snap his three decades of bond with TDP as they could not continue with a leader who would not stand by his words. He said Jagan had fulfilled 90% of the promises in nine months.

Baburao lost his first election to the Congress-backed independent candidate Buchepalli Subbareddy in Darsi assembly constituency in 2004. He shifted to Kanigiri in 2009 but his nomination was rejected by the returning officer during the scrutiny of papers for failing to sign an affidavit. After two unsuccessful attempts, Baburao won in 2014 on a TDP ticket. However, TDP shifted him to Darsi in 2019, leading to another defeat.

Title: Land eviction: HC issues notice to Andhra Pradesh govt
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The high court on Tuesday issued notices to the state government while hearing petitions challenging the government’s decision to evict people from the assigned lands and in some petitions directed the government to maintain status quo.

Beneficiaries of assigned lands from all districts moved the high court challenging the government move to take the lands back for various reasons.

More than 200 petitions are in the high court. Many contended the acquisition of various lands that includes assigned lands, village poramboku lands and other lands to allot house sites to the landless poor. As part of the exercise to provide house sites to all under Navaratnalu scheme, the government has started land acquisition in all districts.

The decision to acquire assigned lands sparked a controversy as many of the beneficiaries of the assigned lands are the landless poor and are in possession of the said lands by way of cultivation or by other means. They have moved the HC challenging the decision to evict them from the land assigned to them by the government. tnn

Title: Teach students social distancing to fight coronavirus, advise global bodies
Content: NEW DELHI: Premier international bodies — the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), UN Children’s Fund (Unicef) and the World Health Organization (WHO) — have suggested implementation of social-distancing practices in schools to protect children from transmission of the novel coronavirus The suggestions, released on Tuesday, include staggering school hours and cancelling any activity that creates crowded conditions. “When possible, create 1-metre space between children’s desks. Teach (them to) avoid unnecessary touching,” the joint advisory states.As per available data, individuals aged 18 years and under are at lesser risk of infection compared with the adults, especially elderly people. The symptoms of Covid-19 among children are usually milder, according the US’ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). “Though severe complications — acute respiratory distress syndrome, septic shock — have been reported, they appear to be uncommon,” CDC says. It, however, stresses on taking preventive measures regardless of the rates of infection among children. Among India’s 60 Covid-19 cases, only one patient is a child, a three-year-old boy from Kerala.The WHO, Unicef and IFRC guidelines suggest sick students, teachers and other staff should not come to school and regular hand washing with safe water and soap, alcohol rub/hand sanitiser or chlorine solution should be made mandatory. Schools should clean and disinfect the premises at least once daily.“Schools should promote social distancing — a term applied to certain actions that are taken to slow down the spread of a highly contagious disease, including limiting large group of people coming together,” the guidance states. It calls for schools to established procedures for separating sick students and staff from those are well — without creating stigma — and a process for informing parents or caregivers, and consulting healthcare providers or authorities wherever possible. “In case of absenteeism or temporary school closures, support continued quality education,” the guidelines suggest. Some children may feel stressed about the crisis. Parents have been advised to listen to them and take time to comfort them.“Education can encourage students to become advocates for disease prevention and control at home, in school, and in their community. Maintaining safe school operations or reopening schools after a closure requires many considerations, but if done well, can promote public health,” say the guidelines. “Safe school guidelines implemented in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone during the outbreak of Ebola virus disease from 2014 to 2016 helped prevent school-based transmissions of the virus,” it points out.

Title: District administration all set to begin poll process
Content:
Vijayawada: The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) has made elaborate arrangements for the nomination process, which is scheduled to start on Wednesday. The civic body has appointed 32 returning officers for 64 wards in the city to implement the model code of conduct.

A special training programme for the returning officers was held in the city on Tuesday in which district collector and VMC special officer A Mohammed Imtiaz and VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh trained the officials. Imtiaz asked officials to follow the MCC and elections rules as well the instructions in the returning officer’s handbook and MCC.

“Returning officers and assistant returning officers play an important role in municipal elections. You should act as moderators and act impartially. Voters’ lists and details of polling stations should be made available at the returning officers’ offices by Wednesday morning,” he said.

VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh directed returning officers to be careful in election duties. “Officials should focus on their responsibilities. Accepting nominations, verifying the documents, final scrutiny and withdrawal of nominations should be done properly,” Venkatesh said. Symbols should be allocated to the candidates by following the rules under the election code, he said.

On the other hand, political parties have been busy finalising the candidates. Jana Sena and Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) conducted a series of meetings on Tuesday to finalise the candidates. BJP has turned its focus on key areas like Old City and Satyanarayanapuram. A few YSRC and independent candidates are likely to file nominations on Wednesday.

Title: Defence ministry wants villagers to have proper access to cremation ground
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Defence minister Rajnath Singh has directed the Local Military Authority ( LMA ) in Nashik to provide proper access to the residents of a village in the Deolali Cantonment area to the cremation ground.

The cremation ground is located adjacent to the field range at Deolali and the residents of Shigwe Bahulla village (of Ward VII) have been facing problems getting access to the cremation ground. The village has a population of over 8,000. The military had acquired the land adjacent to the cremation ground for its use.

Nashik Lok Sabha member Hemant Godse had been pursuing the matter with the defence ministry since February 2018. Godse had written three letters to Singh drawing his attention to the problems being faced by the villagers in carrying bodies to the cremation ground for the final rites.

Singh wrote back to Godse on the March 4, informing him about the instructions given to LMA Nashik after examining the issue. “I have directed the LMA to provide a flat strip of land for free access to the residents of the village to the cremation ground. Residents who need access to the cremation ground should not be inconvenienced,” Singh wrote in his letter.

According to the Union minister, a meeting was held recently involving representatives of the Cantonment Board, Deolali, to finalise the alignment of the road.

Godse told TOI that residents of Shigwe Bahulla were having trouble accessing the cremation ground as there was no proper road. “After the new road comes up, bodies and the wood to light pyres can be taken either by vehicles or on shoulders to the cremation ground,” he added.

CBD vice-president Bhagwan Katariya said Singh’s decision has come as a huge relief for the villagers. “The villagers were not keen on shifting the crematorium ground as they had sentiments attached to where their elders were cremated,” added Katariya. CBD’s chief executive officer Ajay Kumar also welcomed the MoD decision. “We will construct the road as soon as we receive the directive from the ministry,” he said.

It, however, stresses on taking preventive measures regardless of the rates of infection among children. Among India’s 60 Covid-19 cases, only one patient is a child, a three-year-old boy from Kerala.The WHO, Unicef and IFRC guidelines suggest sick students, teachers and other staff should not come to school and regular hand washing with safe water and soap, alcohol rub/hand sanitiser or chlorine solution should be made mandatory. Schools should clean and disinfect the premises at least once daily.“Schools should promote social distancing — a term applied to certain actions that are taken to slow down the spread of a highly contagious disease, including limiting large group of people coming together,” the guidance states. It calls for schools to established procedures for separating sick students and staff from those are well — without creating stigma — and a process for informing parents or caregivers, and consulting healthcare providers or authorities wherever possible. “In case of absenteeism or temporary school closures, support continued quality education,” the guidelines suggest. Some children may feel stressed about the crisis. Parents have been advised to listen to them and take time to comfort them.“Education can encourage students to become advocates for disease prevention and control at home, in school, and in their community. Maintaining safe school operations or reopening schools after a closure requires many considerations, but if done well, can promote public health,” say the guidelines. “Safe school guidelines implemented in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone during the outbreak of Ebola virus disease from 2014 to 2016 helped prevent school-based transmissions of the virus,” it points out.

Title: TDP-CPI tie up, list likely tomorrow
Content:
Vijayawada: The Communist Party of India (CPI) has decided to contest the local body elections in alliance with the Telugu Desam Party. The CPI , which has been supporting the TDP in its capital fight, confirmed the news on Tuesday.

CPI state secretary K Ramakrishna and Vijayawada MP Kesineni Srinivas (Nani) organised a joint meeting in Kesineni Bhavan on Tuesday and deliberated on seat-sharing. Representatives from both parties said they have tied up to fight against the anti-people policies of YSRC government.

“Jagan’s government is working against the will of the public. He is trying to damage both Krishna and Guntur districts by shifting the capital. We will bring the failures of YS Jaganmohan Reddy and his government to the notice of the public and seek their support in the local body polls,” Kesineni said.
