“The TDP government had created a large land bank in the capital region with around 35,000 acres and YSRC is trying to misuse it. The TDP will not let it happen,” he added.

Both parties hope that they will win around 75% of the seats in Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC). A list of candidates is likely to be released on the morning of March 12 with the approval of TDP supremo N Chandrababu Naidu.

Title: Telangana: Ex-TRS man took Rs 1 crore to transfer labour officer, then murdered him
Content:
Anand Reddy

WARANGAL: An assistant labour officer (ALO), who allegedly paid Rs 1 crore for his transfer to a former local TRS worker of Warangal , was murdered and his body dumped deep inside a forested area. The ALO, Anand Reddy, had gone missing on March 7. The ex-TRS functionary, identified as Pradeep Reddy, has been arrested.

Cops said it was about four months ago that the ALO requested Pradeep to help him get a transfer from Khammam to Warangal.

“Pradeep promised him a transfer using his influence and asked him to pay Rs 1 crore in instalments. He also promised the ALO a share in his sand mining business. As planned, the entire money was paid to him over a period,” said a senior Warangal police officer probing the case.

When his transfer did not materialise, Anand started asking Pradeep to return his money. “But after the recent local body polls, the party expelled Pradeep due to alleged negative propaganda during elections and he no longer held any influence in the party,” the officer said.

As the ALO continued to pester him for money, Pradeep planned to murder him. He convinced the ALO to take land instead of money, claiming that he has large tracts of land in Bhupalapally. According to the plan, Pradeep called Anand to Warangal and then took him to Bhupalapally on the pretext of showing the land and killed him, police said.

“After committing the murder, Pradeep dumped the body in Gollabuddaram forest area,” said commissioner of police V Ravinder.

Based on a complaint by the ALO’s brother-in-law Indrasena Reddy, police picked up Pradeep Reddy and questioned him. “During interrogation, he confessed to killing the ALO. His body was found in the Gollabuddaram forest. We are investigating the case further,” Ravinder said.

Title: TTD appeal to devotees: Visit only 28 days after foreign trip
Content: Tirupati: With the coronavirus incidence going up across the country with over 50 Covid-19 cases reported so far in India, the biggest temple administration in the country which administers the affairs of the sacred abode of Lord Venkateswara at Tirumala has appealed to the devotees including Indians returning to the country from abroad and foreigners to planning their visit to Tirumala only 28 days after their entry into the country.In a press release, the TTD administration said at any point of time there are many devotees who visit the temple and the threat of the spread of coronavirus will be high.It is due to this scenario that the TTD administration has appealed to returnees from foreign countries and foreigners landing in the country to avoid visiting Tirumala at least for 28 days from the day of their entry into India.

Title: Delay in trial can’t be ground for bail, rules Madras high court
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Holding that mere delay in conducting trial in cases under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act does not take away the bar on granting bail to suspects, the Madras high court dismissed a bail application moved by an accused arrested by the National Investigation Agency (NIA) in connection with a murder case.

A division bench of Justice R Subbiah and Justice R Pongiappan, rejecting the submissions of S Nijam Ali alias Nijam that the trial in the criminal case will consume much time and therefore the accused languishing in jail for a considerable length of time must be enlarged on bail, said: “The nature of crime alleged to have been committed by the accused is such that the prosecution must be given adequate time to conduct the trial by examining several witnesses to prove the guilt of the accused. In this process, the trial may get protracted, however, it will not be a ground for this court to grant bail to the accused.”

The issue pertains to the murder of V Ramalingam, a PMK former functionary , in Thanjavur on February 5, 2019. It was claimed that the murder was committed by members of Popular Front of India (PFI) and its political organisation called Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI) as Ramalingam objected to their ‘religious work’.

Objecting to the bail, the prosecution submitted that it has filed a memo before the trial court for hiding the identity of 15 vital witnesses, who speak about the conspiracy and overt acts of the accused.

After due consideration, the trial court allowed the memo on merits.

“Therefore, we apprehend that the protected witnesses are also living in the very same locality of the accused and there is every possibility of threat to the life of those witnesses, especially when these witnesses have to come forward and identify the accused persons during trial,” the prosecution said.

Recording the submissions, the bench said: “The trial court is directed to examine the hide-out witnesses and record their evidence at the earliest, preferably on or before June 30. Further, on completion of examination of the hide-out witnesses, the accused persons are at liberty to approach the trial court again for grant of bail.”

Title: Coronavirus scare: It’s better to be scared than sorry
Content: CHENNAI: Covid-19 aka novel coronavirus was officially born on Chinese government records on January 14. And it took hardly a month to travel across the globe to Africa and the Americas.Tamil Nadu has reported one positive case and has more than 1,000 people in home quarantine. Tamil Nadu is one of the few states to have two testing labs for the virus and quarantine wards in hospitals across the state. Yet, the state has not put in place certain public health safeguards that some neighbouring states have adopted.Kerala, which reported eight new cases on Tuesday, is working on a war footing. It has suspended all school examinations up to Class V. The Sabarimala Temple Board has advised Ayyappa devotees not to visit the hill shrine for the monthly puja from March 14 to 18. Theatres have been closed till the month-end.For nearly three weeks now, Kerala airports have been screening both incoming domestic and international passengers. Karnataka government was the first to declare early holidays for primary schoolchildren. In both these states, inter-departmental collaboration is evident.Tamil Nadu, meanwhile is treating Covid-19 as an exclusive concern of the state health department, hospitals and doctors. Many departments in the state have either not taken this seriously enough, or have decided there is nothing they can do. As WHO director general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus put it, this isn’t a drill. “This is not the time to give up. This is not a time for excuses. This is a time for pulling out all the stops.”Tamil Nadu cannot sit pretty in the comfort that “only one case” has been reported. It cannot afford to be caught unawares. We are in the middle of a board examination season when 23 lakh students take annual tests. There are no hand sanitisers or liquid soap or awareness posters at exam centres. Except a circular on Monday, making biometric attendance optional in schools, the education department has been mostly silent.Every Friday, people throng theatres to watch new movies. The first IPL match this season in Chennai is slated for March 26, when some 37,000 are likely to jostle in the stadium. There has been no analysis of the risk. The ongoing Tamil month of Maasi is so auspicious, not a day goes without a temple festival or a family function. When asked, an official of the Hindu religious and charitable endowments (HR&CE) said there is no advisory to temples.Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami has convened meetings with officials, good. But that is not enough for a viral strain that has challenged the best medicare systems and protocols known to the world and infected more than 1 lakh people, killing nearly 4,000 of them so far.It is time to put together a multi-disciplinary swift response unit with public health professionals, doctors (and they are not the same), health workers and experts from all possible fields. Public awareness – as much to avoid contracting the virus as to behaving responsibly by volunteering to be in quarantine if needed – is the first shield against the contagion. It won’t be out of place to think of penalties to people who willfully break the quarantine protocol.We are not asking for panic. We are advocating preparedness, though sometimes it’s better to be scared than sorry.

Title: Bengaluru: Blood donation drives take a hit amid coronavirus fears
Content: BENGALURU: Concerns surrounding Covid-19 are hindering blood donation programmes in the city. Several blood banks have confirmed they’ve cancelled their regular donation drives fearing low turnout in the backdrop of increasing confirmed and suspected coronavirus cases.The cancellations started in the last week of February, they said. A mega camp set to be organised by a multinational company in association with Indian Red Cross Society was among them.“The camp was supposed to be held on February 28 but the company postponed it. Usually, between January and March, we collect 3,500-4,000 units. But this month, we may fall short as camps are being cancelled. The Covid-19 scare could be one of the reasons,” said Prashant Chandrashekar, general secretary, Indian Red Cross Society blood bank “Covid-19 concerns have indirectly affected blood donation. There is fear among people to come forward to donate blood. IT firms are on alert mode over the past one week. For them, blood donation drives are not a priority now. Exam season is also affecting our drives,” said Rajat Agarwal, coordinator, Sankalp India Foundation, which keeps real-time data of all blood banks in the city. Three drives that were to be held in next one week have been postponed by the foundation.However, he asserted there’s no shortage of blood and blood components yet. “We have enough stocks in all blood banks. But the impact will be seen if this scenario persists,” Rajat added.Alphanso Kurian, coordinator, Sanjay Nagar Lions Bloodline, said voluntary donors continue to come forward to donate on a daily basis when the need arises.It may be recalled that in Kerala, the government had issued a circular to all blood banks to restrict blood donation from those with travel history to Covid-19 affected countries. No such circular has been issued in Karnataka “We have not seen any dip in stock in blood banks yet. Drives have been going on in villages and small towns. All those who are under home isolation/observation are not going for blood donation. But that should not stop healthy volunteers,” health department officials told TOI.

Title: Bangalore Coronavirus: Health dept seeks details of IT/BT staff with travel history to affected nations
Content:
Travelling from Italy, Korea? Covid-19 negative certificate a must

BENGALURU: Realising that not all international passengers arriving in Bengaluru are declaring their travel history, the health and family welfare department has asked the IT/BT department to collect from employers travel details of IT/BT workers who have visited the affected countries.“A lot of employees may have visited countries affected by Covid-19 in the past couple of weeks, especially after February 21. There have been cases of a few passengers wrongly declaring their travel history or missing screening at airports,” says the communication the health department sent on Tuesday.It wants the IT/BT department to collect details of employees who have travelled to the affected countries in a specific format, which it has provided, and forward them to its designated officers.The authorities’ concerns come in the backdrop of four Bengalureans, IT employees with travel history to affected countries or their relatives, testing positive for Covid-19.The health department also wants IT/BT companies to immediately ask all their employees to work from home if any of them has tested positive and also help in tracing primary and high-risk contacts. Workplaces frequented by the affected persons must be sanitised and fumigated. It has also said that companies must ask employees with influenza-like symptoms to work from home.Health commissioner Pankaj Kumar Pandey said companies have been asked to avoid international trips for employees given the Covid-19 scenario. “It is requested to avoid unnecessary travel to Covid-19 countries. Also any mass gathering programme in the companies should be avoided or postponed as per the Centre’s directive,” said Pandey.However, health minister B Sriramulu said the government is mulling a ban on all international trips by IT employees and government officers.In addition to Visa restrictions already in place, the Union ministry of health and family welfare issued an advisory on March 6 which says passengers with travel history to Italy and Republic of Korea must carry a certificate which states they’ve tested negative for Covid-19.“Passengers travelling from/having visited Italy or Republic of Korea and wanting to enter India will need a certificate of having tested negative for Covid-19 from the designated laboratories authorised by the health authorities of those countries. This will be enforced on March 10, 2020 and is a temporary measure till cases of Covid-19 subside,” reads the advisory which has been sent to all the IT-BT companies.

Title: Can you leak the paper? Inter students’ helpline queries stump psychologists
Content: HYDERABAD: ‘I wasted the entire year playing PUBG, what should I do now to get good marks?’ This was one of the many unexpected questions that counsellors working with the state education board to help students deal with stress during the Intermediate Public Examinations (IPE) had to field this year. One of the psychologists was left stumped when a student asked, “Can you leak the question paper?”While many are seeking help to handle exam stress, the counsellors say that a few students are looking for an easy way to score high marks. In some cases, they just want to clear the exam at any cost.“One of the students asked me if I can share the question paper,” said Dr Anitha Are, a clinical psychologist , who received the maximum number of calls among the seven psychologists whose contact numbers the Telangana State Board of Intermediate Education (TSBIE) released.She said that those asking such ‘weird’ question drop a message instead of calling on the number. “Quite a few students asked me what to do now that they had wasted the entire year playing online games or hanging out with their friends,” said Are, adding that all she could advise them was to study at least important questions so that they could score pass marks.Psychologists also got missed calls from students. “While parents and teachers call and ask for tips, some students are just giving missed calls. It is likely that they are afraid to seek help or are scared that their parents might get upset if they found out that their ward called up a psychologist,” said Anupama Guttimdeevi, a clinical psychologist. She added that although the board asked students to call them between 3 pm and 8 pm, many call even at unearthly hours like 2 am.Another clinical psychologist S Sreelatha said some students have been calling just to check if the number works. “A student just disconnected the call after confirming that the number belonged to a psychologist. There is no follow up, nothing,” said Sreelatha.

Title: Telangana: Robbers murder woman, sever toes to steal jewels
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Unidentified persons broke in and murdered a 42-year-old woman and fled with her gold and silver jewellery in Nizamabad . They also severed two toes of the victim in their bid to steal the ornaments.

The offenders sprinkled vermilion, spices and pickles around the body and lit oil lamps around the body in what police termed as an attempt to divert the attention of investigators.

The deceased, R Varalakshmi, was the wife of Srinivas, construction businessman from Nizamabad’s Aryanagar. According to police, Srinivas left the house on Monday at around 11.30 am for work and the incident came to light after he returned home at around 8.30 pm.

“When Srinivas returned home, the main door was latched from outside. Srinivas opened the door and found his wife Varalakshmi dead on the sofa of the hall. The assailants had hit her on the head with a blunt object and slit her throat with a sharp-edged weapon,” Nizamabad Town Inspector Satyanarayana said. Shocked, Srinivas ran out of the house screaming for help after which neighbours started gathering around the house. The police were then informed about the incident.

“The assailants ransacked the house and escaped with five tola gold and some silver ornaments including the jewellery the victim wore,” the inspector said and added that the assailants had severed two of the victim’s toes to steal the silver toe rings.

“We suspect that sprinkling of various powders and lighting oil lamps has been done to divert the attention of investigators by making it look like an offence committed by someone indulging in occult practices. They also might have sprinkled the powders to make it difficult for sniffer dogs to follow the trail,” said a senior police official from Nizamabad.

The victim’s family has a German Shepherd dog at home which was there when the murdered had occurred. “The dog was tied outside the house but surprisingly neighbours did not hear any barking. We suspect that the accused could be someone known to the family,” said a police official. The victim’s family is from Andhra Pradesh’s Praksam district and her two children are studying in Guntur.

Police are analysing the CCTV footage and cellphone usage details around the crime scene around the time of the offence. “We are following all available leads to zero-in on the offenders,” Nizamabad commissioner Kartikeya said.

Title: Events in Secunderabad dump plastic cutlery, choose the green way
Content:
SECUNDERABAD: Over 1,500 people ate at an event this month at Sainikpuri, all with non-plastic cutlery. Courtesy: cutlery banks that cater to this side of town and helping residents reduce their carbon footprint. Events like the one in Sainikpuri are becoming more common, says Phani Bala Annadanam , whose cutlery was used at the event. Started about six months ago, Annadanam’s Sita cutlery bank is now packed with orders.

The former IT professional says she started renting out steel sets after she tried organising a zero-waste event for her child’s birthday, but found few people who could meet the requirements. “I now have 125 sets which include a plate, bowl, spoon and cups for water and tea,” she says, adding she caters to all kinds of events.

Nidarshana Saikia Das who started The Bartan Company, with a four-member all women team, also stresses on a growing market for reusables. Though located in Nallagandla , her company is often called to supplement stock for larger events in the Secunderabad area. “With number of orders rising, we are planning to open up a branch in the area,” said Das. This would cut cost required to move huge volumes of cutlery, she said.

For those who still prefer disposables, but want to go green, smaller groups such as the NGO ‘Special Friends’ located in Kapra provide leaf-based plates. “Our team comprises of young persons with disabilities and women. We provide training to them in using machines to make green cutlery and provide them employment,” said founder Swathi Kureti.

Title: Telangana: Rs 44 lakh gold seized from thief who robbed women on buses
Content:
Representative image

WARANGAL: A notorious inter-state robber, K Lalitha alias Padma, was arrested and 980 grams of gold ornaments worth Rs 44 lakh were recovered from her by Jangaon police on Tuesday.

Police said Lalitha, a resident of Vaikuntapuram of Kavali mandal in Nellore district, has robbed several dozens of woman passengers at bus stations across districts in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh.

After receiving information that she would be travelling from Jangaon with gold ornaments to sell them in the Hyderabad jewellery market, the Warangal Central Crime Station (CCS) alerted the Jangaon police. A special team was rushed to Jawahar Park in Jangaon, where woman constables took Lalitha into custody.

According to commissioner Dr V Ravinder , K Lalitha used to rob woman passengers to maintain her luxurious life. In 2007, she had stolen gold ornaments from bags of dozens of woman passengers in Kadapa, Guntur, Atmakur, Vijayawada, Eluru and Nalgonda bus stations. In 2018, Khammam police caught her red-handed while trying to rob a woman at the bus stand. She was produced in a court and sent to jail.

After being released from jail, she targeted woman passengers in Karimnagar and Warangal districts. So far, police have confirmed that she has been involved in 17 cases across Mahabubabad, Siddipet, Jangaon, Subedari and Intezargunj, Hanamkonda, Mills Colony, Geesukonda police station limits in Warangal and Devaruppula in Jangaon.

DCP Srinivas Reddy, Jangaon ACP Vinod Kumar, CCS inspector L Rameshkumar and police staff interrogated her and seized the gold ornaments.

Title: Cash-strapped Telangana govt puts unemployment dole on hold
Content:
Telangana chief minister KCR

HYDERABAD: The much-touted payment of unemployment allowance of Rs 3,016 per month to jobless youth remains a non-starter. Highly-placed sources said the state government believes that the allowance can be extended only after the economic condition improves.

In its campaign for the December 2018 assembly elections, the ruling TRS in its manifesto had promised to sanction Rs 3,016 each to unemployed youngsters till they get a job. “No allocations have been made in the recent budget to provide the unemployment allowance to jobless youth,” Telangana Youth Congress spokesperson SP Kranthi Kumar said.

Kumar recalled that TRS had promised government jobs to the youth in 2014 elections. “After the youth voted for TRS, the government had not only failed to provide government jobs but also fill vacant posts,” he said. Enquiries have revealed that over 24.50 lakh people have registered themselves with the Telangana State Public Service Commission (TSPSC) as part of one-time reRs gistration facility. However, not all of them are jobless.

“Many of the 24.50 lakh registered with the TSPSC are working, having a job in either government or private sector. For example, a grade IV employee has registered so that he can take examination for posts in grade III and grade II. A large number of the registered people are private employees, aspiring for government jobs,” said an official.

Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao gave enough indications while speaking in the legislative council on Saturday that his government has got almost four years to implement the promise made to the youth. The chief minister has also made it clear that TRS had never promised a job in every house which, he alleged, was a malicious campaign run by the opposition parties. KCR said he had promised to fill up one lakh vacancies in the government sector, which is being done.

Meanwhile, unemployed youth joint action committee chairman Manavta Roy told TOI that they would be launching an agitation if KCR fails to implement the allowance from retrospective effect from December 13, 2018. “Also, the government should fill up two lakh vacancies in government sector by coming out with a recruitment calendar,” he said.

Title: Revanth Reddy: Opposition cries vendetta, slams arrest of Revanth Reddy
Content:
Revanth Reddy (File photo)

HYDERABAD: Leaders cutting across party lines termed the arrest of Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy as an act of political vendetta by TRS and demanded that the government withdraw the cases against him. CPI state secretary Chada Venkat Reddy and Telangana Jana Samithi president M Kodandaram condemned the arrest of Revanth and said TRS was crushing all democratic norms by unleashing police force against those raising voice of dissent against the government.

Congress leaders alleged that hundreds of supporters of Revanth were prevented from going to Cherlapalli prison where Revanth is lodged. They were planning to take out a rally in the hope that Revanth would get a bail on Tuesday which, however, did not happen. Police denied that they did not stop anyone nor took supporters of Revanth into custody.

Former Congress minister Mohammed Ali Shabbir said Revanth had been arrested for exposing corrupt deeds of municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao . “The state government should first clarify whether or not KTR constructed a farmhouse on 25 acres of land within the purview of GO 111. Whether the farmhouse is illegal or legal? Who approved it?” Shabbir sought to know.

“There are many other farmhouses and properties purchased by KCR family. The government should either order a probe by a House committee, judicial commission or CBI into these allegations,” Shabbir demanded.

Title: MP’s bail plea to be heard again today
Content: A court in Kukatpally on Tuesday heard arguments over a bail petition moved by Malkajgiri MP Revanth Reddy in the drone camera case and posted it to Wednesday. Revanath was arrested on the charges of instructing his associates to use a drone camera to capture the aerial view of a farmhouse in Janwada and sent to judicial remand till March 18. Revanth is currently lodged in Cherlapally prison. Apart from Revanth, Narsingi police had also arrested six of his associates — Praveen Paul Reddy, Vijay Simha Reddy, Jaipal Reddy, Rajesh, Shiva and Om Prakash Reddy — for using drones in violation of government orders to photograph a private property. TNN

Title: Coping with Covid-19: Netizens churn out memes, TikTok videos
Content: BENGALURU: Compelled to work from home because of the Covid-19 scare, a techie asked his friend: “When will this end?” Perplexed, the friend asked why he was yearning to return to office. Pat came the reply: “We are having so many fights at home that we might bash up one another before the virus does.”This is one of the many Covid-19 jokes doing the rounds on social media as people have taken to rib-tickling memes to keep calm amid the scare. From introverts looking forward to quarantine and no-human contact to amusing videos on how to wash hands, the internet is flooded with funny content on coronavirus Meme creators have not even spared famous artworks. For instance, one of the popular memes is a hilarious take on the fresco on Sistine Chapel’s ceiling — The Creation of Adam by Italian artist Michelangelo. While the original work shows god giving life to Adam with a touch of his finger, the meme shows god in gloves, scared to touch Adam. There is also a portrait of Mona Lisa donning a gas mask and rechristened Corona Lisa.With news of exams having been suspended, people are sharing messages like these: “I am left wondering that it took 25 years for god to answer my prayers. Where was this virus when I was a kid?” Another one reads: “Can coronavirus take me before I give my finals? I can’t waste my last days writing exams before the planet is wiped out because of a plague (sic).”Some memes call the virus a dream of Thanos (a villain in Marvel’s Avengers series, where he plans to wipe out half the world’s population). The virus is also being hailed as the dream of several millennials who question the futility of life, while wishing for an end and a better planet. A video of a child licking a metal divider in a public space has gone viral with the caption: “People with coronavirus need to stay for a few weeks without any contact with another human being.”Memes in Kannada and Tamil, which use movie scenes to send across the message, have also become a rage. For the past two days, meme creators have been training their guns on the long public message played before every phone call. “With these long messages, people may or may not be safe from Covid-19. But they might end up in a mental asylum,” read a Facebook post. TikTok videos are taking it a step further with elbow shakes, foot shakes and at times, even both.Karthik Keramalu, a writer and a popular meme creator on social media platforms, says the jokes are a healthy coping mechanism and help share awareness as well.Rupali Bhalerao, a second-year degree student who creates and shares memes almost every day, said be it Covid-19 or any other pressing issue, the idea is to spread awareness while adding some humour.Some also say that meme makers and youngsters need to know where to draw the line while creating funny content as racist jokes are also being shared.

Title: TRS slammed for reducing BCs share in Telangana budget
Content:
Telangana chief minister KCR

HYDERABAD: The TRS government is facing backlash for reducing the budget for the welfare of the Backward Classes. Members of various backward classes welfare associations said it is an insult to the BCs who comprise over 52% of the population in Telangana.

“BCs used to get 3.5% of the total budget. What has been allocated in this budget is just 2.4%. No new schemes have been announced for BC welfare,” said National BC Welfare Association president R Krishnaiah. Stating that over 5.40 lakh applications seeking financial assistance by jobless youth are pending with BC corporation for the last three years, Krishnaiah said that this had resulted in a long wait for those who wanted to take up self-employment opportunities.

Meanwhile, TRS ministers hailing from BC communities said that the government was committed to BC welfare and that they will come out with a sub-plan if required.

Title: Tamil Nadu losing self sufficiency in salt production, say manufacturers
Content:
Salt production in Tuticorin

CHENNAI: Intermittent rainfall coupled with cyclone Gaja and the Centre’s tweak, which has led to thousands of salt manufacturers going to court, has hit salt production in Tamil Nadu . The amount of salt produced by the state in the last three years has significantly come down leaving manufacturers with very little stock to sell during the off-season. Salt manufactured in the state is used for industrial purpose and is also refined and used as edible salt.

According to official sources from the office of the deputy commissioner of salt, the state manufactured 18 lakh tonnes in 2017-18, 16 lakh tonnes in 2018-19 and less than 14 lakh tonnes the following year. Manufacturers pointed out that TN is slowly losing its self-sufficiency in salt production.

During off season, which is between October and March, prices of industrial salt shot up drastically from Rs 800 a tonne to around Rs 1500 a tonne. “To compensate we are importing a large amount of salt from Gujarat,” said M Kandasaamy, a salt manufacturer based in Marakkanam. In the past one year, TN has imported 1,40,000 tonnes of salt from Gujarat, which manufacturers claim is the highest in all the years of salt production.

V Senthil, secretary of Vedaranyam small-scale salt manufacturers federation, blamed the government for not helping to revive the pans destroyed during cyclone Gaja in 2018. “After the tsunami, the state gave Rs 14,500 per acre to manufacturers to revive salt pans, but after the cyclone, at least 3,000 acres of salt pans are still buried under a foot of slush. We received no aid and are struggling to revive it,” he said, adding that many small-scale investors are also shutting shop. “They now see salt production as a loss-making avenue. Also, no new investors are coming forward,” he said.

In 2013, the Centre had stopped renewing leases of manufacturers. It said that it would instead issue fresh tenders. But the deputy commissioner’s office said that they are ‘prohibited’ from doing so, until further notice.

As much as 17,500 acres of salt pans in Tamil Nadu belong to the Centre and it employs more than 60,000 workers. Due to the order, more than 400 salt manufacturers went to court and obtained a stay against the order and at least 100 have shut shop.

“In Tuticorin, many manufacturers’ lease will expire next year and they are preparing to go to court. If the authorities don’t intervene, production will be signifiantly hit,” said P Dileep Prakash, director of Tuticorin Salt and Marine Chemicals Ltd.

“Manufacturers are losing interest. We don’t know what the government wants to do,” said Kandasamy. Marakkanam, which used to produce more than 1,00,000 tonnes of salt a year, produced less than 50,000 tonnes last year. The salt production in Vedaranyam and Tuticorin has come down from 6,08,000 tonnes in 2018 to 2,85,000 tonnes in 2019 and from 14 lakh tonnes in 2018 to around 10 lakh tonnes in 2019, respectively.

In a recent meeting, Ministry of Commerce and Industry (salt section) had proposed the transfer of management of salt-producing lands to the state government. “It is still in the pipeline, no confirmation has been made yet,” said a senior official from the Tamil Nadu Salt Corporation.

Title: Two killed, 24 injured in 3 accidents
Content:
Hyderabad: Two persons died and 24 others were injuries in three separate road accidents across the state on Tuesday. A six-year-old boy died and four others suffered injuries when an auto-rickshaw they were travelling in rammed into a parked truck at Sultanpur hamlet of Mattampally mandal in Suryapet district at 12.05am Tuesday.

According to Suryapet police, the victim was from Donabanda hamlet in Mattampally mandal and was travelling in an auto to Sri Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy temple of Mattampally when the mishap occurred. In another case, 30-year-old Anil Kumar of Imambad in Siddipet died, and five others suffered injuries when the SUV they were travelling in overturned near an old age home in Kondapaka on Rajiv Rahadari in early hours of Tuesday. The injured were shifted to Siddipet for treatment.

At Hanumanthunipeta in Peddapalli district, some 20 students of Master Siddhartha School had a narrow escape after the four-wheel auto they were travelling in overturned near a railway crossing on Tuesday morning.

Title: Coronavirus in Bengaluru: Summer camp organisers wait & watch; parents wonder how to keep kids busy
Content: BENGALURU: This summer vacation may not be like every other year, after all. Several organisers of these camps are either holding back registrations or cancelling their programmes altogether, thanks to Covid-19’s cascading effect.This has put parents in a fix. They don’t know how to keep their kids busy during the long summer break In the normal course, with the academic year winding down, parents would have been making a beeline for summer camps by now. “The registration enquires till now are far from encouraging. We haven’t had too many people opting for the summer camps either. We are hoping the trend will change in the coming days as the virus threat passes. If not, we will be hit hard because these camps are our biggest revenue generators,” said a representative at a multi-discipline sports camp centre, who didn’t want to be named.In swimming, according to Olympian Nisha Millet, who runs the Nisha Millets Swimming Academy, there is a greater demand for personalised coaching. “We haven’t seen a dip in attendance at the pools. If the water is adequately chlorinated, it’s safe to swim. The key is to ensure the surroundings are clean and hygienic, the changing rooms in particular. Also, we have seen an increase in the number of people opting for personal classes at private/apartment pools.”Sandhya Reddy, who conducts classical dance and music camps every summer in Whitefield told TOI she has decided to cancel the session this year owing to the virus. “This has become a matter of international concern and we are no exception. We cannot risk children’s health for anything. In fact, they are the most vulnerable to cold, cough and fever,” Reddy said, adding that she is worried not only about their health during the camp but also their commute.Another organiser said they have decided to put summer camp registrations on hold and are waiting for directives from the government. “For the safety of the children and our staff, we won’t be going ahead for now. We will have to wait and watch,” she said.Sangita, community manager at Lahe Lahe, a non-profit, performing arts theatre located in Indiranagar said they have to see how things pan out. Meanwhile, they are taking all the required precautions. Lahe Lahe has organised a four-day creative summer camp on poetry, theatre, cooking and craft starting April 21. “We will start getting enquiries only after March. So we are not sure how it will be. For now, we are keeping the space sanitised,” she added.Working parents, meanwhile, are wondering how to keep their kids safe during the break season. Amit Das, a techie and his wife, Shama, a researcher, said they used to leave their six-year-old son at a daycare and had planned to send him for a summer camp. “We don’t know what to do now. It’s unsafe for him and impossible for us to take a long break,” said Das.Das isn’t alone. With the virus scare growing, many like him are at their wits’ end, trying to figure out how to balance work and childcare.

Title: HC to govts: Are steps in place to deal with corona?
Content: New Delhi: Delhi high court on Wednesday sought the Centre and the AAP government’s stand on a PIL seeking adequate measures to combat the novel coronavirus A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar issued a notice to Union health ministry and Delhi government seeking replies by March 30 on the PIL filed by an advocate.The petition sought directions to both the governments to ensure important and relevant information on access and availability of medical facilities for testing and treatment of the novel coronavirus was easily available. According to the Union ministry, there are over 60 confirmed cases of Covid-19 in the country.During the hearing, the Centre’s standing counsel Anil Soni told the bench that “state-of-the-art” medical facilities in the high court could also be put to use to check if people coming to the court were infected.In her plea, Triveni Potekar pointed out that India was under grave potential risk of mass infection due to lack of sufficient screening, testing and isolation facilities and trained health workers. The petitioner has also sought review and assessment of the facilities and infrastructure in a scientific manner.

Title: Madras high court upholds election of DMK MLA
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court on Tuesday upheld the of DMK legislator P Seethapathy from Tindivanam constituency in the 2016 assembly election and dismissed a plea moved by the AIADMK candidate who lost the election.

“When the petitioner comes out with the election petition to declare the election of the returned candidate void, he has to establish that improper receipt of votes or violation of the rules in counting of postal ballots and subsequent recounting, have materially affected the election of the returned candidate. The election of the candidate cannot be declared void unless there is clear and strong evidence compelling the court to accept the contention of the defeated candidate,” Justice V Bharathidasan said. In the above circumstances, the election of Seethapathy cannot be set aside believing the oral testimonials of the election petitioner and his witnesses. Further, in the absence of any strong circumstances, the contentions of the election petitioner cannot be accepted to hold the election as void, the court added.

According to the petitioner, before counting of postal ballots, the DMK candidate’s son handed over a bulk of postal ballot papers to the returning officer which was objected to by the petitioner. However, without considering his objections, the returning officer received the ballots and started counting the postal ballot papers after mixing them with the already available ballots.

Title: Why Tangedco is on a downward spiral
Content:
CHENNAI: It’s like pouring water into a leaking can. As the power utility is staring at one of its worst crisis, tumbling to operational losses from profits, conventional wisdom would suggest a cure by increasing power tariffs or lowering losses by pushing its own units to generate more power, a cheaper option. The third option is to privatise power distribution which will arrest leakages due to transmission and distribution losses. But the Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation (Tangedco) is doing none of these.

A major concern is the cost of power rising to 45 paise in the first half of the financial year of 2019 from 33 paise in the previous year.

A first notice has been served on the government utility, with a downgrade in December by India Ratings, with an outlook lowered to ‘negative’.

Sample this: At the Thalaiyuthu factory of The India Cements, the power plant is generating at 82% plant load factor (PLF) — a percentage of energy sent out by the power plant corresponding to installed capacity. Just 60km away in Tuticorin, the state owned Tangedco’s unit is working at just 57% PLF. For comparison, the state-owned NTPC operates its plants at a PLF of 76.7%.

The consequential impact of lower margins, almost stagnant power sales and widening losses per unit have resulted in its interest coverage ratio — a measure to determine how easily a company can pay its interest expenses on outstanding debt — to a precarious 0.1% in financial year (FY) 2019 from 0.26% in FY2018. It was under just under 1 during FY14-FY18. In simple terms, without the state government’s blank cheque a default is inevitable.

"In view of the numbers, Ind-Ratings expects the liquidity profile to stay strained over the next one or two years. Tangedco’s total debt increased to Rs79,630 crore in FY18 from Rs65,897 crore in FY17," S Rajaraman, associate director, India Ratings wrote in a note.

As the government is hesitant to raise tariffs in the agrarian sector, agriculture consumer subsidy proportions 48% of the overall subsidy over FY15-FY18. "Normally coal-based power plants can be operated at minimum 90% PLF without any issues, irrespective of the age of the facility. The only factor that can impact performance is poor coal quality. But all coal that is tendered for 6,000 GCV (gross calorific value), same as what private sector power plants buy. Yet if the PLF is so tragic, then there appears to be something more than meets the eye," a senior executive at an independent power producer told TOI, on condition of anonymity. The plant load factor for FY19 was at 68.7% while a year ago was 60.4%, a clear indication of the underlying malaise.

The math goes like this: The state has a thermal capacity of 4,320MW which means 10.36 crore units per day are generated a day. If the PLF drops by 1% then generation drops by 10.36 lakh units. And assuming the state utility is buying private power at Rs1 more per unit (actually it is much higher) Tangedco will lose Rs10.36 lakh per day for every 1% drop in PLF. And if the performance increases by 40%, it will mean saving Rs1,500 crore a year.

The Centre has been aggressively pushing privatisation of distribution. The Union government will encourage inefficient state power utilities to seek privatisation and other institutional reforms to turn around money-losing operations and ensure reliable supplies to consumers, according to the top bureaucrat in the Union power ministry.

Electricity utilities that lose significant revenue due to archaic networks, power theft and sloppy billing and collections would be pushed to seek private participation in their distribution network as part of the country’s planned second wave of power reforms, said union power secretary Sanjiv Nandan Sahai . "There is enough private capital ready to invest in distribution, provided the states ensure risk-free business," he said. "States need to pay subsidies on time, government departments need to make timely payments of their electricity bills and political interference in operations needs to go."

Title: Tamil Nadu, coffee growers brew a fresh cuppa
Content:
Tribal coffee growers are now getting a fair price for their produce

UDHAGAMANDALAM: Growing of traditional organic coffee beans by tribal communities in the Kilkotagiri area of Nilgiris is getting a fresh lease of life after the state horticulture department roped in Tamil Nadu State Rural Livelihoods Mission (TNSRLM) to cut out middlemen and procure processed coffee beans from the tribal growers directly.

The coffee powder by the horticulture department is marketed under the name ‘Neelcafe’. Tribal coffee growers say after being shortchanged by private agents for years, this initiative, launched a month ago, will ensure fair price for them and quality for the consumers. The department procures coffee at the rate of `120-`130 per kg of dried coffee beans, while it was sold at `80-`100 to private agents earlier.

S Natarajan, a tribal from Semmanarai hamlet in Kilkotagiri area said, "Earlier our produce was procured by private agents, who used to fix a price. We could not negotiate as we would not know how to market it. Moreover, we would lose a considerable quantity of the produce while weighing, as they would calculate a certain portion as wastage."

Around 130 tribal coffee growers from various hamlets in Kilkotagiri area have partnered with the horticulture department. Semmanarai tribal groups are trying to get other coffee growers in the area. It is a win for the state department as well, which now has a quality brand in its name. "When we came to know that organic coffee grown in tribal areas was procured at far below the market rate, we intended to pitch it in the interest of welfare of the tribal growers," said Shiva Subramaniam Samraj, joint director, horticulture department. TNSRLM was roped in for procurement and payment procedures. "We are paying 30%-35% more than private agents," he said.

Apart from better pay, the coffee growers are also given tips on modern techniques for coffee production. "The agents would not know the technicalities of coffee production, whereas the horticulture department advises us at various stages, right from the bloom. And if we need to more saplings, the department supplies coffee saplings free of cost. It is a double benefit for us with the horticulture department’s intervention", Natarajan said.

Refining, roasting and powdering of the coffee beans are done by the horticulture department at its unit in Ooty. It is packed in a tin of 200g under the brand Neelcafe. "Neelcafe is sold in all our outlets of Tamil Nadu Horticulture Development Agency in the Nilgiris.

In Kilkotahiri area about 40 tribal hamlets are located. With an average of two acres of land per family, most of the families grow tea, coffee and pepper, besides millets and vegetables. "It is just a month since the government took this initiative. Better price for coffee beans means higher earnings for us," said R Siva, another resident of Semmanarai village. The horticulture department has plans to initiate a marketing design for forest honey collected by tribals in the Nilgiris soon.

As of now, the horticulture department is concentrating on Kilkotagiri area. "Once all the tribal coffee growers are roped in under one umbrella for procurement, we will shift focus to Gudalur area, where a considerable number of tribal families grow coffee," said Samraj.

Title: Four held for murder of butcher
Content: Chennai: A four-member gang was on Tuesday arrested on charges of murdering a meat shop owner and escaping with his gold chain in Madurvaoyal. The accused were identified as E Prasanth, 28, of Porur, D Venugopal, 27, and E Kumar, 48, both of Alapakkam and D Essac, 31, of Maduravoyal. While Prashanth, Venugopal and Kumar have been booked for murder, Essac was booked for robbery as he took away the victim’s gold chain. Police recovered the body of Muniasamy, 35, of Alapakkam at Rajiv Gandhi Nagar with head injuries. After the image of the four people was found on CCTV footage, they were questioned. Investigation revealed that Muniasamy allegedly spoke ill of Prashanth’s wife after she separated from him. “It was Parasanth’s murder plan,” said an investigation officer. Prashanth invited Muniasamy to have liquor on Sunday night and beat him to death.

Title: Do fever and cough mean you need Covid-19 test?
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: Who should get tested for the novel coronavirus is a question that has left several people anxious. Anyone and everyone with flu symptoms are seeking to test themselves for Covid-19 To check the panic, India’s top health research body, Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), has come up with a guideline on who should get the test done and who shouldn’t. It stated that there was currently no community transmission of the virus in the country. “The disease is primarily reported in individuals with travel history to affected countries or close contacts with positive cases. Therefore, all individuals need not be tested,” the advisory said.According to ICMR, those who have travelled to high-risk countries — China, Japan, Italy and Iran — in the past 14 days need to first quarantine themselves for two weeks. If there are no symptoms —fever, dry cough and shortness of breath — during this period, tests are not required, the guidelines clarified.If someone hasn’t travelled to the high-risk nations but has had close contact with an infected individual, even then, ICMR suggested such persons should first home quarantine themselves for two weeks. If they develop symptoms during this period, then tests for Covid-19 may be required, it added.In case a person requires testing, the ICMR officials said directly visiting a designated hospital was not advisable as the person might infect others. “All the states have deployed ambulances at strategic locations across the cities. The person can call the Union health ministry’s helpline number — 011-23978046 — and the surveillance team will get in touch with them,” said an official.In Delhi, Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) and Lady Hardinge Medical College (LHMC) hospitals can collect samples, while testing facilities are available at AIIMS and National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC).There are 51 laboratories across the country equipped to test for Covid-19. In addition, NCDC Delhi is also engaged in testing. 56 Virus Research and Diagnostic Laboratories (VRDLs) and one facility at Leh have been designated to facilitate sample collection through government health facilities.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Now, track MTC buses on phone with ‘Chalo’ app
Content:
A screengrab of ‘Chalo’ app

CHENNAI: Just like Ola and Uber, passengers can now live track government buses in the city using ‘Chalo’ app.

The app provides details on nearest bus stops and next five Metropolitan Transport Corporation (MTC) buses scheduled to arrive at any selected stop in both online and offline modes. Users can also search timings of buses along specific authorised routes. For instance, for route 570 (Kelambakkam to Koyambedu CMBT), the app will show the source, destination and list of bus stops on the route. Also a live map, showing the present location of buses plying on the route, will be displayed for users. By selecting one of the buses, passengers may get to know when it would reach the nearest bus stop (based on GPS).

Another common confusion among passengers is route numbers. Unlike Madurai or Coimbatore, Chennai operates more than 650 routes. So, remembering route numbers is tricky. To eliminate this, the app provides the list of bus numbers between any two points. If a commuter is in T Nagar and wants to go to Nanganallur, all he/she needs to do is to enter the source and destination in the appropriate search boxes. Within seconds, the app will display information that 129C, 9M, 79 and 155A are the available options from T Nagar to Nanganallur along with approximate ticket fare in each of the buses.

By this, passengers may get to plan their travel better. “People need not rush to bus stops with uncertainty or fear of missing the next bus if we get to know when the bus will reach and where the bus is now,” said S Rengachari, a transportation activist. Also, they need not wait for a long time at bus stops. Instead, they can leave home or office after calculating the time taken for reaching the bus stop, he said.

A senior MTC official said the app is a beta version (or test-run) of the soon-to-be-launched government’s Locate My Bus App (LAMB). More than 90% of the total 3,300 MTC buses were fitted with GPS devices and brought under the app’s ambit. It will be expanded soon to other buses based on response from the public and correcting internal errors if any, he said and added, “We hope this will encourage more passengers to opt for MTC buses over cabs or share autos”. Accuracy will be within a margin of 1 minute or 10% of predicted time.

Title: Fresh tar for 9 Panaji roads, no digging for next 3 years
Content:
Panaji: The Corporation of the City of Panaji ( CCP ) has asphalted nine road stretches in the state capital. These include the road in front of the corporation’s office itself, which was in a bad shape.

Although the work order for carpeting was issued much earlier, certain agencies were given time to lay cables and wrap up any excavation work. Panaji mayor Uday Madkaikar said no digging of roads in the city would be permitted for the next three years.

“Tender estimates for roads in the rest of Panaji are being prepared,” Madkaikar told TOI.

The corporation, in October, had issued a public notice appealing to all agencies to complete road-cutting and reinstatement. It also stated that road-cutting would not be permitted for two years to public and private agencies, government departments, other organisations, and individuals.

The state capital’s internal roads have been in pathetic condition, particularly inconveniencing two-wheeler riders. Decrepit roads had even prompted citizens to file complaints with the Goa State Human Rights Commission last year.

Motorists got some relief ahead of the International Film Festival of India that was held in the state last November, due to which roads at the entrance of Panaji as well as D B Marg were asphalted.

Title: VMC officials cover up boards with Jagan’s face
Content:
Vijayawada: The state election commission and VMC responded to an article published in TOI about CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy ’s photos being printed on ward secretariats. VMC officials took measures to remedy this and covered the photos of the CM printed on the boards.

The TOI, in its columns on Tuesday, had published the opposition parties’ requests to officials to remove banners and boards which have the photos of state ministers, including chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, which explained the various government schemes.

City planning wing officials and special election officers, with directions from VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh, covered the chief minister’s photos on the board in 230 ward secretariats in the city. Venkatesh said that they would strictly follow the model code of conduct and not allow any form of material that could influence voters. VMC authorities also started removing the three colours representing the YSRC flag painted on the walls of ward secretariats.

A special election help desk has been established at the VMC head office in One Town to receive complaints regarding the model code of conduct.

Opposition parties welcomed the measures taken by the VMC authorities. “We hadn’t expected such speedy action from officials. We thank VMC officials for their immediate response. Officials covered all the boards overnight. They should act in such a way till completion of polls,” said Pothina Venkata Mahesh, Jana Sena local body elections in charge.

Title: Sonia was aware of problems, says neta in resignation letter
Content:
Bhopal: Jyotiraditya Scindia resigned from Congress on Tuesday – the 75th birth anniversary of his father, Congress stalwart Madhavrao Scindia – after 24 hours of stunning developments that plunged the Kamal Nath government into crisis .

AICC leader K C Venugopal said Scindia had been expelled from the party.

Scindia posted his resignation , dated March 9 and addressed to AICC chief Sonia Gandhi, on Twitter around noon, soon after meeting PM Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah in Delhi. In his letter, he said he was unable to work in the party anymore and suggests that Sonia was aware of his difficulties for the past year.

With his joining BJP, it fulfils the lifelong dream of BJP founder and his grandmother Rajmata Vijayaraje Scindia, who had wished Madhavrao would return to the saffron fold and Jyotiraditya join BJP.

Sources say BJP will nominate him to Rajya Sabha and give him a berth in the Union cabinet. Scindia had been feeling sidelined after his shock defeat in the 2019 Lok Sabha election and was desperate to stay relevant in Congress politics. Although he had repeatedly made his resentment clear, his rebellion, when it came, took his party by surprise.

A day ago, 17 MLAs and ministers of the Scindia faction had flown to Bengaluru, leaving the Nath government in MP teetering on the edge just when it felt that it had weathered an alleged poaching bid by BJP.

Scindia’s resignation letter said: “Having been a primary member of Congress for the last 18 years, it is now time for me to move on… As you well know, this is a path that has been drawing itself out over the last year.” He writes that he is unable to “serve people within this party (Congress).”

Scindia met Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi along with home minister Amit Shah around 10.30 am. Scindia was seen driving his vehicle into 7 Race Course Road where Shah was already present. The meeting lasted around 30 minutes after which Scindia drove to Shah’s house without speaking to mediapersons.

In Bhopal, the state Congress was hoping against what seemed inevitable. Scindia loyalist and state Congress working president Ram Niwas Rawat claimed that Scindia had met AICC president Sonia Gandhi late Monday night. “Congress national president Sonia Gandhi, AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra and Sachin Pilot were present. The Congress government will stay. Everything will be good,” Rawat, a former minister, said. Scindia’s resignation would come just a couple of hours after this.

Former CM Digvijaya Singh said: “It is a conspiracy to bring down the Kamal Nath government because of the action taken against mafia. Fifteen years of scams and the honeytrap scandal were getting exposed. They are frightened and, therefore, want to bring down the Congress government. Shivraj Singh Chouhan is lying if he says BJP has no hand in this.”

In New Delhi, Sonia Gandhi called an emergency meeting regarding the political turmoil in Madhya Pradesh.

Former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan returned to Bhopal week by an early morning flight and was accompanied by BJP chief whip Narottam Mishra, who is accused by Congress of planning last week’s political crisis.

Mishra, however, said: “As per my knowledge, this government is falling. I can personally see it going.” Asked if Scindia will join BJP, Mishra said, “Scindia is a big leader. Everyone is welcome to BJP.”

The state Congress has called a legislative party meeting at 5pm and BJP has also called its MLAs for a meeting at 7pm.

Title: Followed all norms for SC/ST reservation for teachers: JNU
Content:
New Delhi: Jawaharlal Nehru University administration has stated that it will not be halting the recruitment process, in spite of the allegations by its teachers’ association that the varsity was flouting reservation norms . The Jawaharlal Nehru University Teachers’ Association had written a letter to the Union ministry of human resource development, claiming that the administration was violating the reservation policy during the recruitment process for teachers.

In its statement, the administration hit back at the teachers’ body, saying that the JNUTA’s attempts “smack of a persistent drive by some teachers to tarnish the image of the university.”

It denied all claims that it undermined of the national policy of SC/ST reservation. “The JNU administration asserts that it has duly complied with the applicable reservation rules of the Indian government,” it said.

The administration further said that the reserved status for no teaching posts had been overturned, and the reservations for SC/ST category have been done as per their share within the available vacant teaching posts. “The university has a committee to make sure that the applicable SC/ST reservations are strictly implemented in the faculty recruitments,” the statement said. “An SC/ST cell prepares the roster of vacant positions comprising staff and officers of reserved category.”

Title: Desilting of drains commences in city
Content:
Panaji: Before the monsoon hits, desilting of drains and culverts has begun in the state capital. Two teams have begun desilting the drains near Cafe Bhonsle square and behind the Goa Pharmacy College.

When the drains near Azad Maidan were cleaned last week, workers took out a truckload of plastic bottles which were clogging drains. Panaji ’s flooding problem is partly attributed to drains blocked by plastic waste.

“Two teams have been put on the job. We began work on March 1. Last year, desilting work began mid-April,” mayor Uday Madkaikar told TOI.

Larger stormwater drains will be built between Bal Bhavan and Miramar circle as part of the Smart City project, the tender for which will be floated after the code of conduct is lifted, Madkaikar said.

The city witnessed one of the worst floodings during the last monsoon, when 18th June road had to be shut more than twice. Residents in low-lying Mala were also inconvenienced as water had entered their homes on multiple occasions.

The Goa Human Rights Commission received two complaints last year over flooding in Panaji, highlighting the complete failure on the part of the CCP to manage basic infrastructure.

The commission had called for reports from the chief secretary and commissioner of the corporation of the city of Panaji following the complaint where pictures were attached of the city including its commercial street 18th June road.

The complainant sought immediate directions to the CCP to immediately take steps to solve the problem on humanitarian grounds and save property in public interest.

Title: Three arrested for murder admit to another killing during probe
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Three people, including a man and his son, arrested on Monday for murdering a lift operator at Chithalapakkam have admitted during questioning that they had in November last year killed a woman. After they were booked in the two cases of murder, a court sent Xavier Arul, 45, his son Michael Vijay, 19, and Xavier’s friend Amalraj, 32, to jail.

On Sunday, a police offficer said, Xavier Arul and Michael Vijay of Medavakkam, and Amalraj of Perumbakkam invited Henry alias Little John, 38, a lift operator, to the banks of the Chithalapakkam lake for drinking. Henry often drank with Arul, the officer said.

After a while, Arul asked Henry to part with his one sovereign gold chain. When he refused, Arul snatched the chain and pushed Henry into the lake. Vijay and Amalraj preesed him down. After confirming he was dead, they escaped in Arul’s autorickshaw.

Some residents noticed the body on Monday morning and informed police. A team led by Pallikaranai inspector Alagu sent the body to Government General Hospital for postmortem.

After some residents said they saw an autorickshaw leaving the lake in the wee hours of Monday and gave the registration number, police traced the vehicle to Arul and picked him up. After he confessed that he murdered Henry to steal his gold chain, police nabbed Vijay and Amalraj.

Further questioning revealed that the trio had murdered 23-year-old Prabha (name changed), a native of Chengam in Tiruvannamalai district . An orphan, she was a saleswoman at a textile showroom in Velachery.

Vijay, who also owns an autorickshaw, often dropped his sister at the same showroom and befriended Prabha, four years older to him. They began a relationship and Prabha became pregnant. She insisted that Vijay marry her. He informed his father who asked him to bring her to the Chithalapakkam lake for a settlement. On November 18, Vijay brought the woman to a spot where the three men pushed her into the lake and she drowned.

Police came to know about the body only November 21 after being informed by some residents of the area. A team rushed to the spot and sent the to the Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital.

The body was already bloated and fully decomposed, the doctors who examined it said. Police personnel traced the identity of the woman and later they handed over the body to her relatives in Chengam.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Nilgiris hydel power projects may get green nod without public hearings
Content:
CHENNAI: Two major hydroelectric projects in eco-sensitive Nilgiris planned by the state government-run Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Company (Tangedco) are likely to get environmental clearances without the mandatory public hearings.

A central government-appointed sub-committee, which inspected the project site in December 2019, had recommended to the Union Environment Ministry to exempt hearings to avoid further delays and cost overruns. Recently, this suggestion was accepted by Expert Appraisal Committee (EAC), which advises the ministry on eco-clearances.

The decision was taken amidst heavy opposition from locals. Even on January 5, more than 2,000 people gathered at Balacola village to participate in a meeting against the project claiming that it will affect their agricultural fields, nearby forests and water bodies.

“At any cost, public hearing shouldn’t be cancelled. Already natural resources are depleted at unsustainable rate. We should pay at least minimum respect to the environment,” said T Bhojan from Nilgiris Small Farmers Association.

The hydroelectric projects, worth Rs 1,832 crore, were launched in 2007 to facilitate continuous supply of electricity and to meet peak power demands of the state grid.

The projects at Kundah and Sillahalla will have nine powerhouses with a capacity of 735 MW. Besides this, access tunnels, pressure shafts, penstocks and other components will be installed to generate power from existing reservoirs (Avalanche and Porthimund) there.

From 2007 to 2012, not much progress was reported due to paucity of funds and non-availability of surplus power.

Though adequate funds were released after 2012, announcement of GST and pending court cases caused further delay. New rates under GST forced re-evaluation of bids, show official documents.

Meanwhile, validity of the Environmental Clearance (EC) given to the Kundah project expired in 2017. Though it was extended, construction works were still pending.

So the Union environment ministry in October 2019 told Tangedco to initiate the process of obtaining fresh environment clearance and the EAC, in response, formed a new sub-committee to inspect the site in December 2019.

This sub-committee agreed to Tangedco’s proposal to exempt the projects from public hearings to avoid delays. “Whatever be the solution, it should be ensured that project works continue as further delay in hydro-power commissioning means not only cost over-run but also more thermal electricity by burning coal and environmental damage, the sub-committee said.

“However, in any case, sufficient opportunity is also to be given to so-called affected people and stakeholders for raising concerns on the project, if any,” its report said.

Tangedco stated that tentative commissioning schedule of the Kundah project is May 2023. Recently, tenders were awarded for electro-mechanical works and more than Rs 200 crore has been sanctioned in three packages.

Title: Anna Salai bomb attack aftermath: Police begin crackdown on gangs
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The city police have started a crackdown on the underworld after the uproar over the March 3 incident when gang war spilled on to Anna Salai with two bikers throwing country-made explosives at an SUV carrying two history-sheeters and triggering panic among other road users.

Eight special teams have been formed to arrest gangsters active in the underworld. In police records, the rowdies are categorised as ‘A-plus’, ‘A’, ‘B’ and ‘C’. There are about 40 ‘A-plus’ category rowdies active in the city, some of whom have gone underground or are now active in other parts of the state.

On Tuesday, police arrested ‘Pulianthope’ Ezhil, a close associate of history-sheeter ‘Arcot’ Suresh who was arrested in May last year and is cooling his heels in Puzhal prison. A team led by inspector Krishnamurthy cornered Ezhil alias Ezhilarasan at gunpoint at his house at Pulianthope, acting on a tip and laying a trap deploying plainclothes men.

Ezhil has a history sheet record opened at the Pulianthope police station and is accused in about a dozen cases including two murders, two attempts to murder and an extortion. He was earlier detained under the Goondas Act thrice.

Meanwhile, ‘Kakkathoppu’ Balaji and C D Mani, the two gangsters who were in the SUV targeted in the country-bomb attack, have gone to ground. Police sources said they suspect the two are hiding somewhere in Andhra Pradesh to evade arrest.

Police are also on the lookout for ‘Sambo’ Senthil, who they suspect ordered the hit in a bid to become head honcho of the Chennai underworld. In fact, a Madras high court lawyer, Thangaraj, who was driving C D Mani’s SUV when country bombs were thrown at it, and Mani, himself, have given separate complaints to the Teynampet police station demanding action against Senthil. Police arrested a college dropout D Mahesh and a juvenile in connection with the bomb attack. Four men, Johnson, Kamaluddin, Prashanth and Rajasekar, surrendered before a court in Madurai on March 5 and three more suspects, Tamil Selvan, Satish and Harish, surrendered before a court in Tenkasi.

Gang tensions are so high that Puzhal prison officials have shifted the people arrested for the bomb attack to the central prison in Salem to avoid clashes in jail.

Title: Tibetans in Chennai decry lack of transparency in China
Content: CHENNAI: Tibetans in Chennai on Tuesday raised the issue of coronavirus infection back home, decrying the lack of freedom of speech and transparency in China, which was an impediment to getting more information about the spread of the virus.“There may be more than a 100 coronavirus cases inside Tibet. However, we are unable to get confirmation. We pray that the virus is contained,” members of the community in the city said as part of a statement released on Tuesday.They took ou a rally at Besant Nagar on the 61st anniversary of the Tibetan National Uprising Day. This is observed on March 10 in the memory of the revolt by Tibetan nationals against what they claim is China’s illegal occupation of sovereign Tibet, which was met with ‘brute force’.The rally lasted about half an hour. A group of around 25 Tibetans including students held placards and walked, supervised by around 10 policemen who recorded the proceedings.As opposed to the close police supervision during the visit of the Chinese Premier Xi Jinping, the organisers said obtaining permission for the protest was easy and officials co-operated.The statement by the Central Tibetan administration said the 2020 Freedom House report, done by a USA-based non-governmental organisation, placed Tibet as the second least-free region in the world after Syria. This was the fifth year in a row where Tibet had this worrying rank, the group said. There was increasing and continuing oppression of Tibetans under Chinese occupation. Since 2009, 154 Tibetans have self-immolated with the latest being on November 26 last year.The group also expressed their appreciation for India and its people who stood in solidarity with their cause.

Title: No BJP infighting if Parrikar were alive: Dilip Parulekar
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Former tourism minister and BJP functionary Dilip Parulekar on Tuesday said if former chief minister Manohar Parrikar were alive, he would not have allowed infighting in BJP.

Parulekar was referring to some of former BJP MLAs who had recently protested the party’s decision to deny either them or their relatives a ticket for the upcoming zilla panchayat polls. Some had even taken offence to senior party functionaries promoting the kin of recently inducted Congress MLAs, he said.

Former Sanguem MLA Subhash Phal Desai had recently targeted Rajya Sabha MP Vinay Tendulkar for sharing the stage with Savitri Kavalekar, wife of deputy chief minister Chandrakant Kavalekar, at a function in Sanguem. Phal Dessai’s statement had drawn a sharp reaction from Tendulkar who said that as Rajya Sabha MP, he was free to attend any function he was invited to.

In another instance, former Tivim MLA Kiran Kandolkar had targeted the party leadership for not giving a zilla panchayat ticket to his wife for the Colvale constituency. He had also accused party functionaries of systematically targeting one particular section of society to end the political careers of those who represent it.

Parulekar told reporters that Parrikar would sit with the karyakartas and resolve issues. “If Parrikar were alive, no karyakarta would have approached the media to speak against the party,” he said.

Reacting to Kandolkar’s statement that party functionaries like Parulekar have been marginalised and suppressed, the former Saligao MLA said Kandolkar should not drag his name for political gains. He also said he has explained his position to the party over Kandolkar’s statement and maintained that he was strongly with BJP.

Former tourism minister was referring to some of BJP’s former MLAs who had recently protested the party’s decision to deny either them or their relatives a ticket for the forthcoming zilla panchayat polls

Title: Industries violating Air Act to be fined
Content:
Panaji: Industries operating in the state without the consent of the Goa State Pollution Control Board ( GSPCB ) under the Water Act and Air Act may soon face action, as the board has constituted an enforcement cell to bring such errant units under its consent mechanism.

GSPCB chairman Ganesh Shetgaonkar said that the board has formed the cell to act against those industries operating without consent to operate. “Once we find industries operating without consent to operate, we will issue them show cause notices and ask them to obtain the consent,” he said.

The decision to constitute the enforcement cell was taken at the last board meeting. The objective of the cell is to visit industries and units to verify whether or not they are operating with consent. If the cell finds that the units are operating without consent, it also has the power to issue show cause notices, closure directions, or to initiate criminal action and impose fines.

The board has already issued letters to municipalities and panchayats to give details of industries registered with them. Most local bodies have already furnished the details. The board will now scrutinise the data and issue show cause notices to erring units. Those units operating without consent will then have to apply for consent.

The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) has categorized industries as red, orange, green and white. ‘White’ industries do not require consent to operate, but have to inform the board about their activities. The other three categories require consent to operate. The board issues consent to red for five years, yellow for 10 years, and orange for 15 years.

Title: Water supply from Narmada dam to continue
Content:
Gandhinagar: In a major relief for the farmers in the Narmada and Kadana dam command areas, the state government has decided to supply water for agriculture for another 20 days and 15 days respectively. During a discussion in the assembly on Tuesday, deputy CM Nitin Patel said, “I was to announce supply of water from the Narmada and Kadana dams for irrigation during discussion on Narmada project, but when the issue was raised today, I consulted the CM over the issue.” Patel said that the government has decided that the water supply for the agriculture sector, which was discontinued on March 15, will now continue for more days keeping in view the unseasonal rains and the delay in sowing of crops.

“Narmada water will be supplied for 20 more days from March 16, and the water from Kadana dam will be supplied to Anand and nearby areas for 15 days from March 16,” he said.

The issue was raised by Savli MLA Ketan Inamdar. Inamdar during the discussion said that the farmers are already in distress due to unseasonal rains and change in weather and hence in order to save the standing crop the government should supply Narmada and Kadana water for agriculture.

Patel further said that in order to provide one million acre feet water to Kutch, the government has decided to create a network at the cost of Rs 312 crore. This will create irrigation facility for 57,850 hectares of land. He said that the second phase Sauni project is on the verge of completion and in ten districts, 57 dams will be filled creating irrigation facility for 3.78 lakh acre area. Projects worth Rs 2,403 crore are in progress under phase-II of Sauni Project.

Title: School reopens, but kin of victim call for action
Content:
New Delhi: Even as police permitted the Rajdhani School in Shiv Vihar to reopen on Wednesday, the family of Rahul Solanki — who was shot dead allegedly by people firing from the terrace of the school — staged a protest demanding that all building used as vantage points by rioters in northeast Delhi recently remain sealed. A forensics team lifted evidence from the school on Wednesday. Given the disturbances, the school has postponed the imminent exams.

Rajdhani School was in the news after the arrest of its owner Farooq Faisal, whose lawyer, Shams Khwaja, said on Wednesday, “Without an explanation on why they sealed the school, the cops sheepishly reopened the building.”

On Wednesday afternoon, Hari Singh Solanki, whose son was shot dead during the communal riots, led a protest outside the school and demanded to see the order permitting the school to reopen. The father of the deceased said, “I lost my young son in the violence and they have opened the school from where the violence originated. How can they do this when there is clear evidence of rioters gathering on the school roof?”

Another area resident, Sonu, added, “Police sealed every building whose roofs were used as vantage points by rioters, including that of councillor Tahir Hussain. So, why is seal on the school being removed? Shouldn’t they then also should open all the sealed properties?”

Police officers, however, denied having sealed the school. “We had only cordoned off the crime area. After the visit of the forensics team on Wednesday, we freed the area for use,” said Ved Prakash Surya, DCP (Northeast).

Farooq Ahmed Nawab, Faisal’s father and co-owner of the school, said the atmosphere was not conducive to the school functioning. “We cannot hold exams when people are protesting.
