The safety of the children is our first priority,” said Nawab. “Keeping in mind the safety, security of the students and the prevailing environment we have decided to not hold the exams for students.” said Farooq.

A catapult used by the mob to pelt stones was recovered from the terrace of the school. It is alleged that violence spread from the school to the surrounding localities. Shiv Vihar was among the worst hit by the communal violence and resembled a ghost town with houses vacated in a hurry by traumatised people.

Title: For elusive CZMP, another deadline set to whoosh past
Content:
Panaji: The state government is set to yet again miss the National Green Tribunal’s (NGT) deadline to complete the long-pending coastal zone management plan (CZMP) for the state, since the National Centre for Sustainable Coastal Management (NCSCM) is yet to submit a draft CZMP and hold the public hearing.

The NGT had directed NCSCM, the Chennai-based agency entrusted with drawing up the plan, to submit the final draft after a public hearing to the Union environment ministry by March 31, 2020. It also said that the final notification has to be issued before April 30, 2020.

“The deadline cannot be met as a notice of one month has to be issued for public hearing once the draft CZMP is received,” said a senior official in the environment department. He said that once the hearing is conducted, the government again has to accept or reject the objections and suggestions given by the public at the meeting.

The state government has written to NCSCM to know the status of the draft CZMP, an official said. The centre also has to incorporate the new high tide line (HTL) in the CZMP.

The state government had directed the department of survey and land records (DSLR) to map all the bunds and sluice gates across the state and furnish the details to the NCSCM.

Recently, the National Coastal Zone Management Authority (NCZMA) accepted the state government’s request to demarcate the high tide line (HTL) along bunds and not around mangroves in khazan lands for CZMP. It, however, rejected the state’s plea seeking reduction of the no-development zone (NDZ) for headlands to 10 metres.

A number of village panchayats and municipalities had earlier demanded that the HTL be demarcated along bunds and not around mangroves. They had even submitted their respective CZMPs to the Goa Coastal Zone Management Authority (GCZMA).

During a presentation to the national authority, the GCZMA had highlighted the impact breached bunds have had on CRZ boundaries in khazan lands that are eco-sensitive, low-lying areas traditionally not influenced by tidal action.

It had consequently demanded that the demarcation of HTL in khazan lands that have been inundated due to breach of bunds be dropped, and that the HTL be restricted up to the bunds and be mapped as such.

In August 2019, the government sought three months extention to complete the CZMP but could not complete it.

In November 2019, it sought another extention.

The first CZMP for Goa was prepared in 1996. However, this was done without survey numbers, and was considered a base plan for the 2011 CZMP.

But when the public began getting notices for demolition of houses, then chief minister Manohar Parrikar took the plan up seriously and asked the NCSCM to prepare the 2016 CZMP.

Title: This picture of Salman Khan's niece Ayat in mom Arpita Khan Sharma's arms will melt your hearts!
Content: After the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Forensic Medical Board ruled out the murder angle in Sushant Singh Rajput’s death report, an audio tape of Dr Sudhir Gupta has been leaked wherein he reportedly claims that the late actor was ‘murdered’. When ETimes reached out to Sushant Singh Rajput’s family lawyer Vikas Singh for his reaction on the same, he stated, “To be honest, I tweeted my stand yesterday but I would like to speak to him before I take a final call. He is not answering my phone, what if he changes his stand, one doesn’t know. I will wait till I can talk to him.”

Title: After 3 teens die, voice to cordon off Verna plateau grows stronger
Content:
Panaji: The issue of three teenagers losing their lives in a car accident in Verna figured at the South Goa consumer protection council meeting held in Margao on Monday where members called for immediate solution to tackle underage driving.

“This is a clear wake-up call because three teens have died in a single incident,” said , the Goa Consumer Action Network ( GOACAN ) convener Roland Martins.

Three minors — Joshua Barreto, 15, Rowan Sequeira, 14, and Ethan Fernandes, 15 — died in the accident involving a four-wheeler at the Verna plateau near the industrial estate on Sunday. Police said the car was speeding, and it veered out of control while the driver was manoeuvring the difficult terrain, leading to the vehicle hitting the rocks, leaving the car a mangled wreck. As all the three occupants died, it is not known where the teenagers had gone.

GOACAN has written to various stakeholders to cordon off the area where the accident occurred and to come up with immediate solutions to tackle underage driving.

It raised the issue at the meeting of the sub-committee on road safety at the South Goa consumer protection council was held on Monday.

“We have written to the managing director of the industrial developmental corporation (IDC), the chief engineer of the PWD and the Goa traffic police to involve the Verna industries estate association and take a quick decision to cordon off the area,” Martins said.

He further said that there are roads in the area being developed for the expansion of the estate. The area is very private and isolated, making it conducive for youngsters to engage in drag races. “The road must therefore be barricaded until there is surveillance or CCTV cameras are installed there. We want all authorities to have a joint meeting and come up with solutions as fast as possible,” Martins said.

GOACAN has also written to the South Goa district collector highlighting the issue of underage driving and requested that a meeting of heads of institutions in South Goa be convened. Martins also suggested that the Goa board of secondary and higher secondary education, SCERT and education department conduct road safety awareness programmes in schools.

“Enforcement is one thing, but the larger question is to impart education to students and their parents,” he said.

Title: Three tonnes of chicken waste manure seized, three held
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Nuzvid police seized over 3.2 tonnes of chicken waste manure , which was being ferried illegally in a lorry, near Yanamadala village under Nuzvid Mandal in Krishna district on Monday night. The manure was being transported illegally from Hyderabad in Telangana to Eluru in West Godavari district in AP.

The police said that they have nabbed three persons P Prabhu Kishore (the lorry driver), BR Babu (the assistant driver) and M Srinivasa Rao (owner of the vehicle) and booked them under relevant sections of IPC. “Chicken manure was being transported to be used as food in fish ponds in West Godavari district,” the police added.

P Ramachandra Rao, inspector of Nuzvid police station, said that the use of chicken waste for feeding is banned as the consumption of such fish will be harmful to humans. “Despite the ban, some farmers in Krishna and West Godavari districts have been using it for feeding the fish,” Rao said.

The police said that they are planning to nab the suppliers of the chicken waste manure and also the farmers who are procuring the waste at the cost of the health of fish consumers, they added.

Title: Delay in issue of orders to recover govt’s lost revenue
Content:
Panaji: With the change in the directorship of the directorate of mines and geology (DMG), there has been a delay in issuing orders for the recovery of money in illegal mining cases, as the director has to start fresh hearings in the cases, a senior official from the department said. The orders are now expected to be passed next month.

In December 2019, the mines department had completed the hearings, and the orders were supposed to be passed in January.

The government recently transferred Ashutosh Apte as mines director and brought in Arvind Bugde to head the department.

The DMG had issued notices to 42 lease-holders to file their final replies in the matter and commenced final hearings in October 2019. Prior to that, it had evaluated replies from the holders of 118 mining leases to the audit report.

In 2015, the state government had appointed 15 chartered accountants to undertake audit of lease holders and traders of mineral ore in Goa for a five-year period, when exports peaked.

They were asked to examine the exact quantity of ore extracted and exported, the amount of royalties paid, export duty, and ore (if any) sourced from other states to ascertain the exact loss of revenue. The accountants had submitted an audit report of 118 mining leases to the mines department. However, the chartered accountants are yet to begin the audit of 260 iron ore traders.

Title: Traffic violations: Will lower certain fines, says Mauvin Godinho
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: People may get some relief from high fines after the implementation of the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019, as the state government has decided to reduce fines for certain traffic violations. A file has been moved to the law department for vetting purposes, said transport minister Mauvin Godinho on Tuesday, adding that the act will be implemented before April.

Godinho told TOI that he has prepared a list of offences for which fines can be reduced. It will be put before the cabinet for a final decision. He also said that the implementation of the new M V (amendment) act has been delayed because the code of conduct is in force.

Godinho said the file which is with the law department has not been sent back to the transport department due to the model code of conduct. Former transport minister and MGP senior member Ramkrishna ‘Sudin’ Dhavalikar on Monday had demanded Godinho resign over not implementing the M V (amendment) act in the state and blamed it for fatal accidents.

“Once the file is back from the law department it will be placed before the cabinet to decide on reduction of fines and the implementation,” he said. Godinho also said that during the last meeting with Union minister Nitin Gadkari he had discussed what fines can be reduced and what cannot. He also said that the state has some leverage to reduce fines in certain violations but not all.

Godinho said that for riding a bike without a helmet the Union government has increased the fine from Rs 100 to Rs 1,000, but the state wants to restrict the fine to Rs 500. “In no parking cases, fines have been increased from Rs 100 to Rs 1,000, but we will try to restrict it to Rs 500. But the cabinet will take the final decision,” he said.

The new legislation came into force across the country from September 1, 2019, onwards. However, after some state governments raised concerns regarding some of the hiked fines, they were permitted to impose lower penalties for certain traffic violations. Godinho said the state cannot touch fines for drunken driving or driving without a licence.

Reacting to Dhavalikar over races taking place in the state, Godinho said that the department takes action from time to time and will implement the law strictly. Once the new M V act is implemented, we have told parents that there will be a heavy fine, and vehicles would be compounded in racing cases.

Title: Hawkers get wheels to start their lives afresh
Content:
New Delhi: Happiness brightened the faces of fruit hawkers in Bhajanpura on Wednesday when they got new handcarts from volunteers of Khalsa Aid India , which has been engaged in rehabilitation activities in the riot-hit localities of northeast Delhi . The carts had been set afire by an angry mob on February 24, leaving the fruit vendors without a means of livelihood.

Mustafabad resident Mohammad Ikram has been selling fruit on the Bhajanpura main road for the past two decades. “On February 24, I lost my cart, my goods and all that I had earned for the day to the rioting. When violence broke out we ran away, and on returning found only the charred remains of our carts. At least 30 of us used to gather there with our fruit carts,” said Ikram.

Arif, who also worked in the same area, said, “We have been out of work for two weeks. The mob burnt our carts and took away the fruits.”

On Wednesday, when he got a new cart from Khalsa Aid India, Ikram was beside himself with joy, both relief and happiness evident in his huge smile. Asked how he felt now that he had a cart again, the fruit vendor said, “God is helping these Sikh people and they are helping us in turn. They are assisting us in beginning our lost lives again. We can once more earn the money we require to survive.”

The rehabilitation volunteers had finalised a list of 50 vendors after verifying their claims. Most of them sold fruit, others snacks and chicken soup. Each cart costs around Rs 12,000.

“For the street vendors, their only source of income is their cart. We met each of the affected vendors,” said Amarpreet Singh from Patiala, Asia Pacific director of Khalsa Aid. “So far we have identified 50 who lost their carts. Our contractor got carts made for them. We will continue distributing the carts in phases to enable the people to begin life anew.”

Khalsa Aid has also been providing food every night since February 26 to the riot-affected families in northeast Delhi.

Title: Sonia was aware of problems, says Scindia in resignation letter
Content:
https://t.co/DWSKdYO0jG — Jyotiraditya M. Scindia (@JM_Scindia) 1583822401000

BHOPAL: Jyotiraditya Scindia resigned from Congress on Tuesday – the 75th birth anniversary of his father, Congress stalwart Madhavrao Scindia – after 24 hours of stunning developments that plunged MP's Kamal Nath government into crisis.AICC leader K C Venugopal said Scindia had been expelled from the party.Scindia posted his resignation, dated March 9 and addressed to AICC chief Sonia Gandhi, on Twitter around noon, soon after meeting PM Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah in Delhi. In his letter, he said he was unable to work in the party anymore and suggests that Sonia was aware of his difficulties for the past year.With his joining BJP, it fulfils the lifelong dream of BJP founder and his grandmother Rajmata Vijayaraje Scindia, who had wished Madhavrao would return to the saffron fold and Jyotiraditya join BJP.Sources say BJP will nominate him to Rajya Sabha and give him a berth in the Union cabinet. Scindia had been feeling sidelined after his shock defeat in the 2019 Lok Sabha election and was desperate to stay relevant in Congress politics. Although he had repeatedly made his resentment clear, his rebellion, when it came, took his party by surprise.A day ago, 17 MLAs and ministers of the Scindia faction had flown to Bengaluru, leaving the Nath government in MP teetering on the edge just when it felt that it had weathered an alleged poaching bid by BJP.Scindia’s resignation letter said: “Having been a primary member of Congress for the last 18 years, it is now time for me to move on… As you well know, this is a path that has been drawing itself out over the last year.” He writes that he is unable to “serve people within this party (Congress).”Scindia met Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi along with home minister Amit Shah around 10.30 am. Scindia was seen driving his vehicle into 7 Race Course Road where Shah was already present. The meeting lasted around 30 minutes after which Scindia drove to Shah’s house without speaking to mediapersons.In Bhopal, the state Congress was hoping against what seemed inevitable. Scindia loyalist and state Congress working president Ram Niwas Rawat claimed that Scindia had met AICC president Sonia Gandhi late Monday night. “Congress national president Sonia Gandhi, AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra and Sachin Pilot were present. The Congress government will stay. Everything will be good,” Rawat, a former minister, said. Scindia’s resignation would come just a couple of hours after this.Former CM Digvijaya Singh said: “It is a conspiracy to bring down the Kamal Nath government because of the action taken against mafia. Fifteen years of scams and the honeytrap scandal were getting exposed. They are frightened and, therefore, want to bring down the Congress government. Shivraj Singh Chouhan is lying if he says BJP has no hand in this.”In New Delhi, Sonia Gandhi called an emergency meeting regarding the political turmoil in Madhya Pradesh.Former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan returned to Bhopal week by an early morning flight and was accompanied by BJP chief whip Narottam Mishra, who is accused by Congress of planning last week’s political crisis.Mishra, however, said: “As per my knowledge, this government is falling. I can personally see it going.” Asked if Scindia will join BJP, Mishra said, “Scindia is a big leader. Everyone is welcome to BJP.”The state Congress has called a legislative party meeting at 5pm and BJP has also called its MLAs for a meeting at 7pm.

Title: Govt plans long-term rehab, may launch next phase soon
Content:
New Delhi: With relief work in the riot-hit northeast Delhi “streamlined,” the AAP government will now shift its focus on long-term rehabilitation measures, including psycho-social counselling, livelihood and peacebuilding .

Senior Delhi government officials said deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia , who is closely monitoring the relief work, is likely to officially launch the Phase-II of relief and rehabilitation work in the next few days.

At least 53 people were killed and nearly 500 injured in the communal clashes that took place in the last week of February. A large number of people reported loss of properties with their houses and shops set afire and kiosks, carts, rickshaws, etc., burnt. A trade body pegged the total loss in violence at Rs 25,000 crore.

Delhi government set up camps, involved not-for-profit organisations, volunteers, civil society and AAP workers to provide shelter, basic amenities and compensation to hundreds of people.

Abhinandita Mathur, who led the relief work, said collective efforts were made to reach out to victims and provide them relief. “For the next phase, non-government organisations may be roped in for their specific expertise,” she said.

Sources said Sisodia has directed the officials to wind up the disbursement of compensation claims at the earliest and move on to the next stage of rehabilitation.

The peacebuilding effort will involve the government, police, local authorities, officials of government departments and volunteers, who will hold peace marches across the riot-affected areas and work on confidence building among the victims.

“The focus of the government is to bring people back to their houses. The victims are scared and that is why they have been reluctant to return. We will try to rebuild the trust of people and provide the victims long-term rehabilitation. The government agencies, along with NGOs, are setting up spaces and even repairing damaged properties to help the people resume a normal life,” said an official.

The government has also decided to provide the victims with psycho-social counselling to get over the trauma. The sight of their friends or kin getting injured or dying, and properties and vehicles being set on fire in front of their eyes has left a deep scar on the minds of the victims, which will take a lot of time and efforts to go.

“Agencies that have expertise in dealing with such cases will be involved. A detailed plan will be prepared soon,” said an official.

Sources said the government may even consider providing rickshaws, carts and machines to help the affected people rebuild their businesses and start earning a livelihood. “Many people have lost everything to the violence. We will have to find a way to help them so that they could start earning again,” said another official.

Title: ED files case against PFI, Tahir Hussain
Content:
New Delhi: The Enforcement Directorate has registered a case under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act against Popular Front of India (PFI), an organisation dedicated to “Islamist causes”, which has been under probe for the past few months for alleged funding of anti-CAA protests . The agency also booked suspended AAP councillor Tahir Hussain.

Hussain has been arrested by Delhi Police and is an accused in the murder of Intelligence Bureau official Ankit Sharma during the Delhi riots which broke out over protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act.

During questioning, senior PFI functionaries are learnt to have admitted to certain transactions linking the outfit to funding of anti-CAA protests in the capital and some other places, sources said.

The agency had questioned several people connected with PFI at its Delhi headquarters and found evidence of collection of Rs 120 crore, at least Rs 50 crore of which came as cash donations for which the source was not disclosed. The PFI is headquartered at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi.

The ED has also seized a tab from PFI’s Delhi unit president Parvez Ahmed which it claimed has records of a chain of conversations between him and a Rajya Sabha MP of a leading Delhi party, allegedly coordinating anti-CAA protests at Shaheen Bagh and the separate violence at JNU earlier.

The ED has questioned office-bearers of PFI and another outfit linked to it, Rehab Foundation of India (RFI). Those spoken to include Parvez Ahmed, RIF trustee Shahid Abookacker, PFI Delhi secretary Abdul Muqeet, RIF general secretary Remiz Muhammed, PFI national secretary Anis Ahmed, RIF secretary Afsel Chandrankandy and PFI’s national headquarters accountant K P Jaseer.

The AAP councillor and PFI office-bearers are likely to be arrested by the ED in the next few weeks, sources said.

Title: Vijayawada News - Times of India
Content:
Tirupati: A school headmaster, who misbehaved with a girl student, was arrested by the police at Gudupalle mandal in Chittoor district on Tuesday.

According to Gudupalle SI, Maheswara Reddy, the headmaster of a primary school—identified as Gopal Pillai (55)—allegedly misbehaved frequently with one of the girl students at the school. It was after the girl complained about the headmaster’s behaviour to her parents, that they lodged a complaint with the local police.

Acting on the complaint, Gudupalle police registered a case under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act and arrested the accused headmaster on Tuesday. Police are further investigating the matter and the accused was sent to remand.

Title: Coronavirus in Goa: Ask for mask, pay through nose
Content:
Representative image

COLVA: Panic over coronavirus and the resultant demand for masks has opened a new avenue for pharmacists to cash in on with some creating artificial shortage.

In Margao, pharmacy owners under the garb of rationing sales are selling two masks per person, and that too at a higher price.

A disposable face mask which is available under normal circumstances at Rs 15 is being sold at Rs 20 to Rs 40, while the reusable N-95 and 3M versions, which generally costs, Rs 80 to Rs 100, are offered in the range of Rs 100 to Rs 350.

The reusable masks contain filters and can be used over a week with a simple rinse in water. Some pharmacies in the commercial capital of Goa have already exhausted their stock and those who have inventory, are jacking up the prices.

A customer at a pharmacy seeking six masks had to remain content with just two, and that too at Rs 35 per piece. She told TOI that just last week she had paid Rs 20 for the same mask.

Another pharmacist said that before the outbreak of coronavirus, his sale of disposable masks was just 2-3 a day and the target group was two-wheeler riders. But now, he makes daily sales of 30-50 reusable masks.

The sale of sanitizers and liquid soaps has also increased three-fold.

One of the pharmacists who has run out of stock disclosed that her order for fresh consignment is pending since last week.

A senior citizen said when demand competes with supply, then unethical business practices come into play.

Title: Villagers lose sleep as leopards stalk cattle
Content:
Poinguinim: Residents of New Vaddo and Dupeamol in Gaondongorim, Canacona, are spending sleepless nights trying to keep their domestic animals from being snatched away by leopards prowling the area. Over the past month, residents of the wards, located near Bhatpal and Ozrem, have sighted the leopards multiple times.

With no help coming from forest authorities, the villagers have now resorted to forming groups to keep guard over their dogs, pigs, poultry and calves, well into the wee hours of the morning.

A resident Damiao Fernandes told TOI that the big cats are sighted late in the evenings and sometimes around 6am. “We are forced to keep our dogs indoors, but the other animals have to stay outside. Since the big cats come in anytime after 8pm, the residents have a tough time guarding their domestic animals,” said Fernandes.

Another resident Brigito Coutinho, who has pigs and Jersey cows, has to be vigilant throughout the night as a female leopard has been sighted around his farm, with two cubs.

“After several pigs were attacked, I started keeping them in the pig enclosure overnight. Recently, the leopards have become more daring and even attempted to attack the calves ,” said Coutinho.

Title: Cyclones follow unconventional tracks, may be a challenge: Navy
Content:
PANAJI: A study conducted by the Indian Navy on cyclones from 1999 to 2019, including three cyclones in the past year, found that in most of the cases, the cyclones did not follow conventional paths, thus making navigation at sea a challenge.

The study, conducted by the Directorate of Naval Oceanology and Meteorology (DNOM), also found that rapid intensification of cyclonic storms is going to pose a challenge in the foreseeable future , though the forecast accuracy has increased.

“The study on the cyclones in the month of November from 1999 to 2019 has revealed an important fact that in majority of the cases, the classical track of the cyclone was not followed strictly,” said the DNOM report titled ‘Unconventional Tracks of Tropical Cyclones in Northern Indian Ocean’.

According to the ministry of shipping, 90% of India’s external trade is carried out through the seas.

The Navy’s oceanographers studied the three cyclones—Kyar, Maha, and Bulbul—that formed over the north Indian Ocean between October 24 and November 9 last year. The Navy, along with other disaster relief agencies, were called in to carry out Humanitarian and Disaster Relief (HADR) operations.

The Navy felt the need to analyse the cyclones to see if there is a change in pattern or the cyclonic paths. It also wanted to check if the guidelines for avoidance and navigation through a cyclone needed to be reviewed.

“The perceived ‘unconventional’ paths of the cyclone do not warrant any change in the standard operating procedure for navigation as long as the tracks of the cyclone can be predicted with a fair degree of accuracy. However, it is to be noted that rapid intensification of storms may leave shorter reaction times even if the paths are accurately predicted,” the Navy’s top researchers said in the study.

The Navy’s study said that with tremendous improvement in satellite imagery and early warning systems, the ability to forecast with accuracy a cyclone’s intensity and its projected path, has increased. “The issuance of timely warnings shall be of crucial importance,” the naval report said.

Title: TTD additional EO says ‘best arrangements’ for devotees
Content:
Tirupati: Anticipating heavy influx of pilgrims to the sacred abode of Lord Venkateswara during the summer holidays this year, Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams additional EO AV Dharma Reddy said the temple administration would make the best of arrangements this year to ensure an uneventful pilgrimage for devotees .

Speaking to reporters following a a coordination meeting with senior officials of various departments of TTD at Tirumala on Tuesday, additional EO AV Dharma Reddy said the temple administration would maintain a buffer stock of ‘Tirupati Laddu’ prasadam to cope with the increase in demand during the summer.

He pointed out that during last year’s summer vacations 21.92 lakh devotees visited Tirumala in April, 25.07 lakh in May, 25.05 lakh in June and 24.15 lakh devotees in July. At that time, TTD distributed 1.15 crore laddus in April, 1.14 crore laddus in May, 1.16 crore laddus in June and 1.16 crore laddus in July.

The number of devotees who tonsured their heads last year was 9.47 lakh in April, 12.73 lakh devotees in May and 12.88 lakh devotees in June.

Mentioning these statistics, TTD’s additional EO Dharma Reddy said the temple administration expected a minimum of 2-3% rise in figures this summer.

In view of heavy influx of devotees expected during the summer vacation, the temple wing, annaprasadam wing, Vaikuntam Q complex, reception, medical health and sanitation have all been instructed to make additional arrangements in terms of anna prasadams, laddus, queue lines and the like.

“Most of the devotees walk barefoot at Tirumala. To reduce the inconvenience caused to them walking barefoot in the scorching summer, we are painting cool paints at key roads across Tirumala,” Dharma Reddy said.

Pointing out that packaged drinking water was prohibited at Tirumala, TTD’s additional EO appealed to the devotees to carry steel or copper water bottles along with them during their pilgrimage. “We have set up 150 plus RO plants across Tirumala ,” he added.

TTD also appealed to devotees suffering from coronavirus symptoms to postpone their visit.

Title: Man booked for sexual assault
Content:
Saligao: Anjuna police on Tuesday registered an offence against a man from Kattem-Baina, Vasco, for sexually assaulting a woman on the pretext of entering into a legal marriage with her.

Police said the woman complained that the accused, after marrying her as per Hindu rituals at Sasoli, Maharashtra, assaulted her at her residence on several occasions on the pretext of getting legally married to her.

She stated that he later refused to register the marriage and make it legal. Police said the accused is expected to marry another woman on Thursday.

The woman alleged that the accused took around Rs 3 lakh in cash from her after assuring her that he would return it, but failed to do so. A case has been registered under IPC sections 376 and 420. Further investigation is in progress by PSI Mahesh Kerkar.

Title: Tension prevails as devotees clash over rights to perform rituals at Balli temple
Content:
Police restrict the 400-strong group from entering the temple premises

QUEPEM: Tension prevailed at the Bhumipurush and Mahamaya temples at Khadem in Balli on Tuesday morning after a section of devotees were denied entry to perform rituals based on an order issued by the deputy collector of Quepem.

This is the first time after 12 years that rituals were performed at the temple.

Activities had come to a standstill after dispute had broken out between two groups of devotees headed by Guno Velip and Ram Gaonkar , respectively, with each claiming exclusive rights over performing of the puja and other observances. Both parties had approached the court, which had directed the deputy collector to decide on the matter.

Tuesday saw a heavy police force deployed near the temple. Two IRB platoons, including Margao DySP Serafin Dias and his Colva, Fatorda, Maina-Curtorim and Vasco police teams were stationed on site since Monday night. Quepem deputy collector Rohit Kadam, mamlatdar Ramesh Gaonkar and joint mamlatdar Rosario Fernandes arrived in the morning. Tension brewed post 9.30am when the Gaonkar group arrived. Devotees headed by Velip had already finished with the rituals and left. Police stopped the over 400-strong group and informed them of the deputy collector’s order that only entitles the Velip group to retain possession of the temple and allows only their representatives to be appointed temple priest in charge of carrying out all rituals.

The devotees, including women, had come with their ceremonial umbrellas and tried to enter forcibly. Kadam informed them that as per his order they cannot enter with their umbrellas. He directed those bearing the ceremonial insignia to complete their circumambulation outside the cordoned area and told the rest that they could enter the temple. Arguments ensued.

The order allows the Gaonkar-led devotees to enter the temple premises only to pray and disallows them from offering any puja or rituals to the deity.

The group had challenged the order in the district and sessions court, but failed to get a stay.

Gaonkar told TOI that the deputy collector had done them injustice. He said that South Goa collector Ajit Roy had verbally told them that they could enter the temple to perform puja when they approached him on Monday evening.

The Gaonkar group left around 12.30pm without entering the temple.

Title: MSME losses skyrocket sharply over one quarter
Content:
Panaji: In a worrying sign for Goa’s economy, the number of micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) running into losses and unable to repay loans jumped sharply from 1.9% in June 2019 to 13% in September.

Data shared by banks on the flow of credit to MSME showed that out of the 51,077 units which took loans, 6,663 were classified as ‘ sick ’ on September 2019, with outstanding loans to the tune of Rs 424.2 crore.

In the quarter ending June 2019, the number of sick units in Goa stood at 949, with outstanding loans of just Rs 86.7 crore.

The data was shared with various stakeholders at the empowered committee for MSMEs convened by the Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) financial inclusion and development department.

“The rehabilitation of sick industries in the MSME sector was discussed in detail. RBI exhorted all bankers to put in their sincere efforts to nurse these viable units back to activity,” said an industry representative.

According to the Sick Industrial Companies Act, a sick industrial unit is a company which at the end of any financial year incurs accumulated losses equal to or exceeding its entire net worth.

“There were 1,662 units considered to be potentially viable which were put under nursing, and their loans were restructured, amounting to Rs. 134.2 crore,” said a source present at the meeting.

The bank data on credit to MSMEs also showed that 8.95% of the total lending to the sector remained outstanding with the 6,663 sick units.

The RBI’s general manager for Goa, N J Nampoothiri, chaired the meeting and reviewed the status report on the performance of banks on the flow of credit in the MSME sector for the July-September 2019 quarter.

In 2011, Goa government had framed guidelines to identify, revive and rehabilitate sick industrial units, but it did not gain traction.

The number of new units serviced for the July-September quarter rose by 8.6%, from 3,822 units to 4,150 units, and the flow of credit also increased by 31.5% to Rs 179.6 crore from Rs 136.6 crore in the quarter ending June 2019.

Title: Even cancer can’t checkmate his passion for chess
Content:
Purushottam Kantak

PANAJI: For over two decades, Purushottam Kantak never missed his daily routine: Wake up at 5am and for three hours without a break, solve problems, read books and study the game online so that he could become a better chess player and train youngsters to become champions.

But for the past 10 days, Kantak—the only Goan to win state chess championship in junior, senior and veteran categories—has slowed down a bit. He cannot wake up at the scheduled time, and even if he does, his wife Geeta, also a chess player, won’t allow him to put his body through the rigour.

Having just underwent the third surgery for cancer , his punishing schedule could prove fatal. After all, this 58-year-old has been battling the illness for seven years.

Kantak is unfazed. “Chess is like a virus. Once it enters your body, you cannot get rid of it. My personal belief is that chess helps you take your mind off everything, even personal problems,” a frail-looking Kantak told TOI at his Margao residence.

He was first diagnosed with oral cancer in 2013, got operated and was back on his feet. In 2018, he was found to have colon cancer, so another cycle of chemotherapy and recovery session started. Just when it seemed like he can breathe easy, the cancer showed up again early this year, this time weakening his fight.

What hasn’t diminished is his love for the sport and the ambition to produce a champion. It is this desire that has kept him going at his Brain Power Goa Chess Academy, where he conducts advanced coaching and helps shape the future of Goa’s next champion.

“He cannot live without chess. On the bed, while chemotherapy is in progress, he would hold a chess book and study, forgetting what he is going through. While travelling in the car (to the hospital in Panaji), he either solves chess problems or uses the magnetic chess board that he has, to play,” says Geeta.

Till three months ago, he was an active chess player too. He travelled to Dharmasthala in Karnataka where he picked up an award for the best veteran chess player. In December, he finished a creditable eighth from among 200 rated players at the All Goa Chess Championship in Margao, and more famously the same year, he finished fourth at the All Goa State Fide Rating chess tournament-cum-selection trials and was among the selected players for national championships.

“I miss playing. When you play, players (who you coach) respect you more. They say, ‘you beat me and show’. I do just that, despite all of them having the latest computers and software,” he says.

Even today, Kantak has not given up and is waiting for May when the Goa International Open Grandmaster Chess—to be named after former chief minister Manohar Parrikar—will be played here and he’ll pit his might against the best.

“Chess keeps my mind active and you can control all your diseases with your mind. There’s a new immune system in the body which you have to activate,” says Kantak, who won his first junior title in 1980 and became a state champion in 2001.

What Kantak, a lawyer by profession and grandson of Goa’s famous poet Padma Shri Bakibab Borkar, would also miss is the visits to government primary schools in the vicinity, or to the slums where he can teach chess to those who cannot afford to pay the high fees.

In the eyes of Kantak, a seven-year-old at the academy is the latest chess prodigy in Goa. He’s seen that spark and the talent. For someone who bunks school three times a week and trains at the academy, the youngster is tailor-made for success and Kantak is doing the best he can.

“Every Dronacharya dreams of having an Arjun. My dream is to find someone who will say that Kantak taught me and made me a champion. This is my only dream,” says Kantak.

Title: Mutiny reveals dangers of sidelining young turks
Content:
New Delhi: Jyotiraditya Scindia ’s rebellion set off rumblings in Congress about many ticking bombs within, as much a result of the leadership vacuum at the top as of a ‘generational clash’ that has wrecked the party over the last year.

The loss of an important leader and a state government in the middle of an intense debate on CAA-NRC and a Parliament session can be demoralising for the opposition party. Though Jyotiraditya Scindia has been gradually drifting away from Congress, he has been seen as close to Rahul Gandhi, usually sitting next to him in the previous Lok Sabha. The failure to accommodate his ambition and, in fact, cut him out of the power equation in MP has cost Congress dearly.

As Scindia left Congress and joined arch rival BJP , murmurs were rife in Congress over many other young leaders brimming with aspiration but being set back by elders in their states. Scindia’s resignation letter where he told Sonia Gandhi that “this path has been drawing itself out over last year” made evident that his gripe was against CM Kamal Nath and Digvijaya Singh, who had joined hands to stall him.

Though unstated, the buzz that no young leader would get his due given Rahul Gandhi’s pre-eminence in the scheme of things, has only grown louder.

Kuldeep Bishnoi, Haryana MLA, tweeted that Scindia’s exit was a big loss and many other capable leaders were feeling alienated. It triggered alarm about upcoming Rajya Sabha elections in Haryana. While Congress can win a seat in the state, it has a buffer of just one MLA with one member appearing unable to vote because of health concerns, and the situation is likely to embolden the ruling BJP to make a bid for the second berth. A senior leader said the party would have to be careful about the choice of candidate as well as management of votes in Haryana.

But apart from immediate issues, the longer term problems, masked somewhat by BJP losing out in Maharashtra, post-poll, and failing to retain Jharkhand and falling short in Delhi, have been brought to the fore by Scindia’s successful revolt.

Rajasthan Congress chief and deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot has warned the leadership that nomination of a money bag to the Upper House, as is being speculated, will send a negative signal to the electorate and party cadre. Pilot is well-ensconced, where he has a stake, but leaders like him may well expect their voices to be heard more respectfully.

Scindia’s rebellion also started with attempts to thwart his bid for Rajya Sabha as also state leadership. However, the larger worry in Congress is about the leadership vacuum that has resulted from Rahul Gandhi’s refusal to take back the organisational reins in the wake of Lok Sabha poll debacle.

Scindia’s exit, said a party member, reflects that Rahul has given up or is indifferent to extreme steps by his colleagues that can set back the party. The social media was rife with claims that he refused an appointment to Scindia last week. The drift at the top is best reflected by the failure to select new leaders for state units. DK Shivakumar’s name was apparently finalised for Karnataka PCC, but has been in a limbo for over two months, due to objections of senior leaders. The leadership for Maharashtra and Mumbai units is also up for grabs.

As reported by TOI, a group of young leaders have been discussing among themselves about the threat that continuing vacuum at the top poses to state units, and are planning to speak out sometime in future.

Full report on www.toi.in

Title: Holi amidst coronavirus
Content:
Panaji: Brightly-coloured powders and water balloons were launched by revellers celebrating the festival of colours at Azad Maidan, Panaji on Tuesday, amidst fears of the coronavirus. Goa, so far, has not tested a single positive case, and this seems to have motivated people to take to the streets to celebrate Holi. However, many of the celebrators were non-Panjimites with most of the city’s residents choosing to opt out of the festival this year.

“Every year, we see a crowd of over 2,000 people, but this year there were only 1,000. People were cautious and many Panjimites stayed away. Migrants and people from beyond city limits showed up and participated,” festival organiser Shantaram Naik said.

Announcements were being made at the venue informing attendees to leave the festival if they have a cough or cold. Some volunteers even kindly escorted people who were seen sneezing, out of the premises.

“We were aware that there would be lukewarm response to the festival since there were fears about the spread of coronavirus. People who regularly come for this festival may not have turned up with their families, but the celebrations overall took place devoid of any fears,” advocate Gunwant Juneja, resident of Panaji for 35 years, said.

“The crowd was smaller this year, and those that did participate did so owing to their attachment to the tradition of celebrating Holi at Azad Maidan. My children Prithvi and Poorwa, especially wanted to come and enjoy this festival since this is how we celebrate it as a family annually,” Pramod Naik Sardesai said.

There were volunteers at all entrances to inform people that they must not enter if they are not healthy.

Besides locals, volunteers were keeping foreigners informed as well.

“There were about 25-30 foreigners who were enjoying the event. They were not forbidden entry into the festival. But the organisers made announcements about the dos and dont’s to avoid the virus infection,” another regular attendee Parwinder Singh said.

Title: Ensure purchases for ESI adhere to GMP: Jaganmohan Reddy
Content:
ViJAYAWADA: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy said that the Andhra Pradesh government would strictly adhere to Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) rules to ensure that products purchased by the Employee’s State Insurance (ESI) are consistently produced and controlled according, per quality standards.

Reviewing workers’ welfare and healthcare here on Tuesday, the CM said that there should be no room for anomalies in the purchase of medicines for the workforce.

It may be recalled that irregularities in the purchase of medicines and medical equipment for ESI hospitals during the TDP regime were exposed. The vigilance and enforcement department has unearthed an ESI medicine scam worth over Rs 400 crore in the state.

“All standards for the implementation of health services should be strictly followed,” Jagan said, adding that ESI should release bills on the spot. He sought proposals for the improvement of services in ESI hospitals and directed officials to make sure that hospitals function smoothly.

As it was already decided to increase the number of teaching hospitals to 27 from the existing 11, thereby ensuring that each parliamentary constituency has a teaching hospital and a nursing college, the services of the new doctors from these colleges should be utilised in ESI hospitals, the CM added.

Jagan also said that concerted efforts should be made to curb pollution in the state. He said pollution at sea was leading to severe environmental degradation.

Efforts should be made to fill all the vacancies in the labour department, Jagan said, adding that he would write a letter to the Prime Minister about the pending LIC claims to the workers.

Title: Goa Coronavirus: Jobs on the line as Indians cannot enter Doha
Content: PANAJI: Qatar’s temporary suspension of entry to travellers from 14 countries, including India, from March 9 onwards has left several Goans in a lurch.The advisory, issued as a preventive measure due to the spread of coronavirus worldwide, came as a shock to Goans working in Qatar who were on holiday and emergency leave in Goa.A food and beverage supervisor, Ainslie from Margao, who arrived from Qatar in Goa last week to get his medicals done for his new job now fears losing the once in a lifetime opportunity with a handsome pay package. “I’m in shock. I didn’t expect this to happen. I would have never made the mistake of leaving the country so soon had I known,” he told TOI.“Police clearance is done, and our visas are ready too. The company is only waiting for our medicals. Now I’m afraid I’ll lose my job. If the suspension continues, they may just decide to leave us out and hire locals instead. I hope this doesn’t happen,” he said, adding that his visa and work permit have both been cancelled.Goans in Qatar have also had to shelve their plans to visit the state, some for business and others to be reunited with their families.A mother of two working in Qatar who was set to spend time with her husband and two children in Mapusa next week has decided not to take the risk of getting stuck in Goa and losing her job.“I broke the news to the children. They can’t express their feelings, but you can tell from their faces. They always look forward to their mother coming down, bathing them and tucking them into bed at night,” the father told TOI.He added that his wife recently got her unused annual leave sanctioned by her company in Qatar to travel to Goa to be with the family. “She is now forced to take the leave and sit at home in Qatar, away from family,” her husband said.A long-time resident of Qatar scheduled to travel to Goa for three days this week to buy real estate had to postpone his trip after the advisory was issued. “Everything was set but now it will have to be postponed. Luckily the selling party said they will wait for me,” he told TOI from Qatar.In addition to India, Qatar temporarily suspended entry for those travelling from Bangladesh, China, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Lebanon, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Syria and Thailand.The statement from the Qatar government adds that the decision affects all individuals intending to enter from these countries, including visas upon arrival, those with a residence or work permit, and temporary visitors.

Title: Jyotiraditya Scindia: Congress failed to gauge Scindia’s loyal following
Content:
New Delhi: Driven by the ruling faction in Bhopal, led by CM Kamal Nath and Digvijaya Singh, Congress utterly failed to gauge the support commanded by Jyotiraditya Scindia and the resentment among its MLAs, a miss that is set to bring down the 15-month-old Congress-led government in MP .

Though Scindia had adopted a rebellious tone over the last couple of months, the state Congress was convinced that he would not be able to garner support of more than five MLAs, that too from his turf of Gwalior-Guna. That prompted Nath and Singh to push Scindia to go for the broke, an extreme step that he may not have taken in normal circumstances.

The calculation was that even if he left the party, he would not be able to bring down the government and the loss of a few MLAs would be compensated by the turncoats from BJP who were in contact with the chief minister. What actually transpired — with over 20 MLAs set to quit Congress now along with Scindia and join BJP — has shocked the state unit.

There was also complete confidence in the Congress brass, starting from the AICC, that Scindia could grumble and create problems but would not jump the ship for arch rival BJP.

That Scindia could muster support beyond his recognised clout — and also decide to join BJP — left Congress red-faced with embarrassment on Holi.

The problems started right after the Congress victory in the December 2018 elections. Scindia was overlooked as choice of party mascot for the state polls, as Digvijaya Singh threw his lot behind Nath in the deeply factionalised state unit.

While Scindia was smarting all along, his defeat in 2019 Lok Sabha elections made him desperate. He staked claim to a Rajya Sabha berth and state leadership.

But the Nath-Singh combine shut him out completely and the disappearance of some party MLAs last week was seen as a bid to thwart his claim for the RS berth. The proposal that Priyanka Gandhi Vadra become an RS candidate from the state was also seen as the ruling group’s bid to cut out Scindia.

The absentee leadership at the top, following Rahul Gandhi’s resignation as Congress chief, only helped the state satraps get a free run without having to worry about the diktats or concerns of the AICC.

For the young leader, this was a recap, and extension, of the rivalry that these senior leaders had with his late father Madhavrao Scindia, which thwarted the latter from becoming the CM. His complete shutting out drove him to the extreme step of quitting Congress and joining the BJP.

The episode has an echo of what Jyotiraditya’s late father did in 1996. After his name figured in the infamous Jain Hawala diaries during the Narasimha Rao government, in which he was a minister, he was denied a ticket for Lok Sabha elections.

Miffed, Scindia senior left Congress and contested under his newly floated party and defeated the official Congress candidate. He went on to support the Deve Gowda government but returned to Congress in 1998 when Sonia Gandhi assumed leadership. He remained in Congress till his death in an air crash in 2001.

Title: Four more arrested in northeast Delhi riot cases
Content:
Police have recovered several bodies from the northeast Delhi drains since the riots.

NEW DELHI: Earlier arrested in connection with the murder of four people in northeast Delhi , Lokesh Kumar Solanki allegedly told the police that during the riots, he had joined a mob that was on an attacking spree. He alleged that his friend, Pankaj, was also with him when four people were killed and their bodies were dumped in a drain. Pankaj was arrested on Tuesday.

Three others who were throwing petrol bombs from the terrace of suspended AAP councillor Tahir Hussain have also been arrested. “Solanki and Pankaj joined the mob and with help from others, killed four people and dumped their bodies in the drain. They don’t have a criminal record. They were not working anywhere at present.” said an officer privy to the investigation.

On March 5, four cases of rioting that had happened in northeast Delhi on February 24 were transferred to the Crime Branch. They were registered under sections of rioting, murder and destruction of evidence. During manual and technical investigation, it was found that a group of people was involved in these incidents. Solanki was arrested on the basis of evidence collected.

Police also arrested three aides of suspended AAP councillor Tahir Hussain for indulging in violence from the terrace of Hussain’s house. Police said they have been identified as Irshad, Abid and Shadab. During the riots, they were also allegedly throwing petrol bombs from the terrace.

Police said both the special investigation teams were working on the cases and on the basis of their findings, more arrests would be made on Thursday.

Title: Maintain quality of items given to students, says Jaganmohan Reddy
Content:
Chief minister at a review meeting on school education held at the camp office in Tadepalli on Tuesday

VIJAYAWADA: As part of the Nadu-Nedu programme, a target of modernising 15,715 schools was set, apart from the digitalisation of education with the introduction of English as the medium of instruction from Class 1 to Class 6 from the next academic year.

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy , at a review meeting with officials on Tuesday, directed officials to complete the modernisation works of schools by the beginning of the academic year by June.

“Regarding the introduction of English as the medium of instruction at the primary school level from June, every school must be given a smart TV for digitalised learning,” chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy said. He also added that the quality of items being offered as part of Jagannanna Vidya Kanuka programme should be maintained at the highest level.

Officials displayed the uniforms, belts, bags, notebooks, textbooks, shoes and socks that would be given to students.

When the chief minister asked about the implementation of the Jagannanna Gorumudda mid-day meal programme and the maintenance of toilets in schools, the officials informed him that they were regularly monitoring that through the app introduced for the programmes and that water tankers were being arranged for the schools which do not have water facility.

Title: Babush backs Madkaikar for second term as mayor
Content:
Panaji: Panaji MLA Atanasio ‘Babush’ Monserrate, who controls the Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP), has decided to let CCP mayor Uday Madkaikar continue to hold the post for another term.

Deputy mayor Pascoela Mascarenhas, however, will not continue for another term as Monserrate has selected Vasant Agshikar for the post. Agshikar represents ward 25.

Madkaikar and Agshikar will file their nominations on Tuesday. Madkaikar has been representing Bhatulem ward for many years. Elections are scheduled to be held on Thursday. As per the Corporation of the City of Panaji Act, the mayor and deputy mayor are to be elected every year. Last year, Monserrate did not continue with Vithal Chopdekar as mayor and brought in Madkaikar. The last CCP election was held in March 2016 when the panel backed by Monserrate wrested control of the corporation in a bitter tussle with the BJP-supported panel. The Congress-backed panel had fielded 20 candidates

In the 30-member corporation, Monserrate’s panel had won 17 seats while BJP had to be content with 13. Sidharth Kuncalienker was the Panaji MLA at the time as Manohar Parrikar was the Union minister for defence. The result was considered a big setback to the BJP as the party was ruling both at the Centre and in the state.

In July 2019, Monserrate along with nine other Congress MLAs joined the BJP. Two months earlier, he had trounced Kuncalienker in the assembly bypolls after Parrikar’s demise in March last year. Monserrate does not have any opposition panel to contest against after he joined the BJP last year.

Title: Indian-origin man dies of virus in UK
Content: LONDON: A British Indian Krishna devotee who regularly visited Bhaktivedanta Manor in Watford has become the sixth person in Britain to die from coronavirus. Manohar Krishna Prabhu , in his eighties, passed away at Watford General Hospital on Monday night.Professor Chris Whitty, the chief medical officer for England, said: "I am sorry to confirm a sixth patient in England who tested positive for Covid-19 has sadly died. The patient, being treated by West Hertfordshire Hospitals NHS Trust, had underlying health conditions. It appears the virus was acquired in the UK and full contact tracing has begun."Manohar is the first Indian-origin person known to have died of the virus in Britain. His son is still being treated at the hospital. A Krishna devotee, Parasuram Das, said that Manohar, a Sindhi, had contracted the virus from an Italian man who has come to his house to buy some audio equipment from his son. The Italian man was unwell, he said. "Manohar fell ill soon afterwards and went into hospital about 10 days ago. Four of our temple guys who went to visit them last week have been put in quarantine." The devotees who went to visit the duo in hospital did so before the coronavirus was diagnosed as initially they thought he had pneumonia.Manohar's family issued a statement through the trust saying: "We have lost a loving, caring father, grandfather and brother. His age and failing health did not stop him from living a full and complete life and always doing things for other people. He was guided by his innate kindness. Our father will be sorely missed, not just by us but by those whose lives he touched." The estate of Bhaktivedanta Manor was donated to Iskcon by George Harrison of the Beatles after he developed an interest in Indian spirituality after the band's tour of Rishikesh in the 1960s.

Title: MP political crisis: Will keep fighting, says CM Kamal Nath after 98 MLAs attend meet
Content:
Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: With the Kamal Nath government teetering on the edge, the mood was grim but combative at the Congress legislative party meeting at chief minister Kamal Nath’s residence.

Sources said Nath has said they will fight on, and dare BJP to a floor test. Former PR minister P C Sharma claimed the resignations are fake. “Don’t worry. Picture abhi baki hai,” he said. According to sources, former minister Sajjan Singh Verma is flying to Bengaluru on Tuesday night.

Sources said 94 party MLAs and four Independents attended the meeting along with Rajya Sabha MP Digvijaya Singh. Discussions went on for more than two and half hours.

After the meeting, deputy Speaker Heena Kavre said, “We have been asked to stay united and fight together. The situation may be adverse but no one should have any fear. A senior party leader has betrayed us.”

Asked about Jyotiraditya Scindia , she said, “Jyotiraditya Scindia will not be discussed in Congress meetings any more. There was no talk about Scindia. He has been expelled from primary leadership of the party.” Outside the chief minister’s residence, emotions ran high. Congress workers shouted slogans in favour of Nath and against Scindia. At the party HQ, some of them ripped out Scindia’s nameplate and crushed it underfoot.

MLA from Kala Peepal constituency and state Youth Congress president Kunal Choudhary said Scindia has “betrayed every Congress worker who fought for Congress during 15 years of BJP rule”.

Congress leaders kept up a fighting front. “We will prove our majority on the floor of the House. All these resignations, the MLAs were told, is to pressurise for Rajya Sabha nomination,” said state Congress media department chairperson Shobha Oza after the CLP meeting.

Title: Draft feni policy lacks true spirit, fails to give stakeholders a kick
Content:
PANAJI: After three years of deliberations, the state government’s draft feni policy is finally ready, but it doesn’t seem to have aged well. The draft, prepared by Goa University for the government, was roundly criticised by stakeholders, who said that it lacks the true spirit required to take feni forward and make it a competitive drink.

“It can’t be accepted. We want it to be reworked,” said Hansel Vaz, secretary of the Goa cashew feni manufacturers and bottlers association. Vaz, who runs the premium feni brand Cazulo, said that the association is “disappointed” with the draft, which is silent on various aspects that are of paramount important for distillers.

The stakeholders got especially irked by the fact that the draft policy, prepared by GU ’s Goa Business School, doesn’t focus on or highlight better agricultural practices for cashew farmers to enable their cashew apples yields. To their dismay, it talks about cashew nuts.

One stakeholder said that it should have focused on the cashew apples. “Cashew nuts are not the source of feni,” he said.

The draft policy states that 42 varieties of cashews are grown in Goa, and recommends Goa-1, Vengurla-1, Vengurla-4, Vengurla-6, Vengurla-7, Vengurla –8 as high-yielding varieties to be cultivated by farmers. The series of Vengurla varieties developed by the Indian Council for Agricultural Research (ICAR) at Ela Farms, Old Goa, have wide adaptability and good nut size.

“Vengurla variety is the worst when it comes to cashew apples. Why aren’t they talking about indigenous varieties,” a stakeholder said, adding that farmers needed to be guided in choosing which variety is the best in terms of cashew apples.

“They (researchers) have collected data without scrutinising, analysing or even verifying the same,” said another stakeholder, who feels that the draft document contains “no policy material”.

One stakeholder said that the draft mentions processes involved, but it shies away from clearly showing directions to distillers, who are facing challenging times. “Who wants to know that cashew juice is extracted by stomping cashew apples, a primary process involved in distilling?” he asked.

“Traditionally, copper vessels were used for distilling, and earthen pots for fermenting cashew juice,” he said. “Today, big copper vessels are not available and it is difficult to procure large earthen pots. Many traders have replaced copper vessels with steel. Juice is fermented in plastic drums. This modification is not in sync with the original method of distilling.”

What could be the alternative? The draft is mum on this. Feni experts say that it is meaningless as it doesn’t addrress basic questions as these, which are paramount to securing and standardising the age-old practice of distilling feni.

When pointed out that stakeholders were unhappy with the draft, excise commissioner Amit Satija said that it was prepared “in consultation with all stakeholders involved from time to time”.

Satija said the policy aims at setting standards for distilling that distillers need to follow. Those confirming with set standards will be issued certification or labelling. This, he said, “will weed out operators who do not conform to quality and hygiene”.

Title: Two held for murder in Tirupati
Content:
Representative image

TIRUPATI: Tirupati east police arrested two persons for the murder of a youth. Circle inspector B V Sivaprasad Reddy said Siva Kumar and Subramanyam were arrested for killing Ganesh, their acquaintance on March 6.

The police said Siva Kumar, Subramanyam and one Ganesh used to collect waste paper and sold them to a local vendor at Renigunta. They also used to steal from people sleeping on roadside. “On March 6, they quarrelled over sharing the stolen money and Siva Kumar and Subramanyam stabbed Ganesh. They smashed his head using a boulder and killed him and fled away,” said the cop.

Meanwhile, A middle-aged woman was found murdered near Chelimibanda near Pakala mandal in Chittoor district on Tuesday. The identity of the woman is yet to be ascertained. Preliminary investigation showed that the woman was bludgeoned to death with an heavy object.

Title: 3 held for bid to extort Rs5cr from jeweller in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch on Tuesday arrested three persons for their alleged attempt to extort Rs5 crore from the owner of a city-based jeweller.

The police identified the arrested trio as Ashish Pawar (27), Ramesh Pawar (32) and Rupesh Chaudhary (45). The police said they had demanded the money after threatening the jeweller (name withheld) that they would make a video clip of his family member viral on the social media.

Ashish, who hails from Sahakarnagar, had earlier worked with the jeweller as the latter’s bodyguard. Ramesh is a resident of Market Yard and was working as a house helper at the jeweller’s bungalow. The police said Rupesh, a resident of Tulshibagwale colony in Sahakarnagar, was a small-time developer.

The police will produce them before a magisterial court on Wednesday for securing their custodial remand.

Deputy commissioner of police (crime) Bachchan Singh told TOI, “We are further investigating the case with regards to the motive, modus operandi and also to find out if any more accomplices are involved in the crime.”

When contacted, the jeweller, who did not wish to be named, told TOI, “This all started on Saturday afternoon after one of our house helpers called me and asked for a ransom of Rs5 crore. He claimed to have some video of our family, which later turned out that he had nothing. He was helped by two of his colleagues from outside. We took help of the police and all three of them were nabbed quickly by Tuesday evening."

Crime branch senior inspector Rajendra Mohite said, “After getting the first extortion demand for Rs50 crore on March 4, the jeweller initially tried to negotiate with the suspects to settle for a lesser amount. He even offered them gold worth Rs1.5 crore. But the suspects would settle for nothing less than Rs5 crore. The jeweller then decided to approach us and submitted a complaint application on Monday night, naming the three suspects. On verifying the contents of his plea, we got an FIR registered on Tuesday. The three suspects were arrested from their residences.”

Mohite said, “The jeweller said in the complaint application that Ramesh was the first to call him and claimed that he had secured a video clip of his (jeweller’s) family member. Ramesh asked for money for not making the same viral on social media. The plea further stated that Ramesh and his two accomplices individually met the jeweller at various places on March 7 and 8 for negotiating an amount to settle the matter. The jeweller then sought time till Tuesday to consider their demand.”

Another crime branch officer, who did not wish to be named, told TOI that during negotiations, Ashish had twice threatened the jeweller with a licenced pistol belonging to Rupesh. He said, “We will now go for the recovery of the firearm as well as the video clip claimed by Ramesh.”

An offence of extortion and provisions under the Information Technology Act has been registered.

(With inputs from Satyanarayan Iyer )

Title: Remove recovery hoardings: HC to UP govt
Content:
Prayagraj: The Allahabad high court on Monday ordered the UP government to immediately remove hoardings carrying names, addresses and photographs of 57 people, allegedly anti-CAA protesters , against whom recovery notices had earlier been served for allegedly damaging private and public properties.

It called the government’s action an “unwarranted interference in the privacy of people” and said “the placement of personal data of selected persons reflects colorable exercise of powers by the executive”. While admitting that the state can always take necessary steps to ensure law and order, the HC said, “But that cannot be by violating fundamental rights of people.”

“It is in violation of Article 21 of the Constitution, which clearly provides that no person shall be deprived of his life and personal liberty except according to procedure established by law,” the high court said.

Rejecting the government’s contention that the hoardings were aimed at deterring people from participating in illegal activities, a division bench of Chief Justice Govind Mathur and Justice Ramesh Sinha said, “The advocate general has failed to satisfy us as to why personal data of a few persons has been placed on banners when there are lakhs of accused persons who are facing serious allegations pertaining to the commission of crimes whose personal details have not been subjected to publicity.”

It directed the state government not to place on the roadside such banners containing personal data of individuals without the authority of law. “Under the CrPC, the power is available to a court to publish a written proclamation requiring the appearance of a person against whom a warrant has been issued and such person is concealing himself to avoid execution of a warrant. No other power is available in the code to police or the executive to display personal records of a person to public at large,” it said.

“So far as legality part is concerned, suffice to state that no law is in existence permitting the state to place banners with personal data of the accused from whom compensation is to be charged,” the court added.

While justifying its decision to take suo motu cognizance of the matter, the court observed, “Where there is gross negligence on the part of public authorities and government, where the law is disobeyed and the public is put to suffering and where the precious values of the constitution are subjected to injuries, a constitutional court can very well take notice of that on its own. The court in such matters is not required to wait for a person to come before it to ring the bell of justice. Courts are meant to impart justice and no court can shut its eyes if a public unjust is happening just before it.”

The Lucknow divisional commissioner and district magistrate were asked to execute the order and file a compliance report in court by March 16. On Saturday, the high court had taken suo motu cognizance of the hoardings put up on Thursday night by the Lucknow district administration.

Title: Disabled Jagtial man seeks Rs 1L from recruiting agency
Content:
Hyderabad: A worker from Jagtial, who came back two months ago after suffering paralysis at his workplace in Dubai, wants the licensed agency, which sent him to the Gulf two years ago, to pay him Rs 1 lakh compensation for deceiving him.

As per rules, all recruiting agencies should take Pravasi Bharatiya Bima Yojana (PBBY) for all labourers they send abroad for work. However, this was not followed in the case of Kokeni Posanna (38). His wife Kokeni Gangajala said the agency cheated them by not subscribing to the rules and by not opting for insurance on her husband’s name.

In a letter to Jagtial district collector, Gangajala said the agency collected Rs 65,000 from them towards service charges. Two persons running the agency sent Posanna on a visit visa to Dubai in June 2018 but allegedly skipped the eMigrate system and did not provide for PBBY as promised. Posanna hails from Jaina village in Dharmapuri mandal. He returned to the state on January 13 this year after suffering a stroke paralysis. He has been stuck to the bed ever since.

Posanna would have been eligible to get Rs 10 lakh under PBBY had the insurance been taken on his name by the recruiting agency. The scheme provides for Rs 10 lakh in case of death or permanent disability.

“If my husband was sent through eMigrate system, he could have availed PBBY benefit,” she said, alleging that they were deceived by the agency. A complaint was also lodged with the Protector-General of Emigrants in Delhi in this regard.

Title: Bird flu: Dist admin holds meeting with stakeholders, reviews preparation
Content:
Coimbatore: A meeting of poultry farm owners, animal husbandry department officials and health department officials regarding avian influenza prevention measures was conducted at the district collectorate on Tuesday.

Poultry farm owners were instructed to find out how to prevent spread of bird flu in their farms. In the case of an avian influenza outbreak in their farms, the owners have been instructed to contact the animal husbandry department immediately.

In the event of the flu reaching Coimbatore borders, the district administration has arranged equipment like culling machines and preventions shields to prevent the spread of the flu.The district administration has also established 12 checkposts that to be manned by 36 teams along the border. They will carefully check vehicles coming from Kerala carrying poultry birds and feed. They will spray disinfectant on all the vehicles. The administration also formed 60 rapidaction teams to handle any outbreak if it occurs. tnn

Title: NIA gets 5-day custody of Maddileti
Content: Hyderabad: A local court on Tuesday granted the National Investigation Agency (NIA) five days of custody to interrogate Telangana Vidyarthi Vedika (TVV) president Bandaru Maddileti in connection with a case of his association with frontal organisations of CPI (Maoist) party. The VI metropolitan sessions judge court of Nampally granted the custody of Maddileti to NIA. “The court has specified certain conditions while granting the custody. NIA officials will take Maddileti into custody on Wednesday,” defence counsel V Raghunath said. NIA had moved a petition in the court a few days ago seeking custody of Maddileti. In December 2019, NIA re-registered a case based on an FIR booked by Hyderabad police against activists of TVV. tnn

Title: Pune airport customs seizes foreign exchange worth Rs 38 lakh from duo
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Customs officials arrested two persons at the airport on Sunday for attempting to smuggle foreign currency of different countries, worth more than Rs 38.71 lakh, to Dubai by concealing it in the inner waistline of their trousers.

“British pounds, Qatar and Saudi riyals were recovered during a body search and thorough screening of the check-in luggage of 43-year-old Ansari Feroze Abdul Hamid and Sheikh Mohammed Tarique Iqbal Ahmed (33). Both these passengers were slated to fly from Pune to Dubai on a SpiceJet flight (SG51),” a senior customs official told TOI.

Ansari is a resident of Guruwar Peth in Pune while Sheikh is a resident of Kasba Peth .

“They had concealed the currency in a clever way. They undid the stitches on the inner waistline of their trousers and stitched it back to perfection after concealing the currency there. Currency had been hidden in other parts of their trousers in the same manner. They are surely wilful carriers. While investigations are underway, we are trying to find out how they came across the foreign currency. We are trying ascertain who the person or persons were, with whom they were in contact with. The reason behind them attempting to take the currency to Dubai, is also being probed,” the official added.

“The customs officials at the airport have been on full alert to foil attempts of gold-smuggling and regarding the Covid-19 outbreak. Checks on foreign travellers have become more stringent than ever. The officials found the duo’s behaviour to be suspicious and a proper search led to the recovery of the currency,” the official pointed out, adding that the entire operation was carried out under the guidance of Motilal Shete , the deputy commissioner of customs.

“Further investigations as per the Customs Act 1962 is in progress. Passengers are appealed to report to customs if they spot any suspicious persons or baggage at the airport,” the official said.

The customs officials arrested two persons for trying to smuggle out Rs35.41 lakh in foreign currency to Dubai from the Pune airport, in July last year. This incident occurred just over a fortnight after the customs officials recovered foreign currency worth Rs38.5 lakh from a passenger in a similar catch where the flyer was on his way to Dubai on an Air India flight. On August 8, 2017, two persons were arrested after they were found carrying foreign currency worth Rs1.29 crore in the form of Euros and US Dollars in four casseroles filled with upma, a Maharashtrian snack.

Title: Arrests of Bread, Butter and Egg lead to drugs-money laundering racket
Content:
(From left) Butter Nnamani, Eze Naduka Bonaventure — also called Egg — and Kelvin Mansary, called Bread

NEW DELHI: While trailing members of a methamphetamine cartel , Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) has stumbled upon a nexus among jailed criminals , bank officials and drug traffickers who were allegedly running a major money laundering racket .

The gang was apparently in possession of a list of dormant accounts in which several crores had been parked by unknown entities. It was planning to transfer the money to accounts owned by them and their shell firms, police said.

The revelations were made after three drug traffickers codenamed Bread, Butter and Egg arrested with a consignment of meth, cocaine and heroin worth over Rs 5 crore. They have also led NCB to their aides one of whom works with a private bank branch in Karnal while another, Vishal, is lodged in Tihar jail. The NCB has now written to Enforcement Directorate to probe the money laundering angle.

The arrested men have been identified as Butter Nnamani (35), Eze Naduka Bonaventure (36) and Kelvin Mansary (30) who belong to Nigeria. While Bonaventure was fondly addressed as Egg by his associates, Mansary was referred to as Bread or Ben. Nnamani was living in Khirki extension, while Bonaventure in Chhatarpur and Mansary in Gurugram. The alleged mastermind is a US citizen named Robert Planco.

DG NCB Rakesh Asthana had formed a special team to probe the money laundering aspect of drug trafficking given the high value of drugs seized in the last one year. “The suspicious transaction record originating from international accounts was a matter of enquiry with NCB. While working on this information, a reliable input was received regarding an international syndicate which was tipped to be involved in drug trafficking as well as money laundering,” deputy DG, RN Srivastav, said.

“A raid was conducted and the three traffickers were arrested with 255 gram cocaine, 350 gm heroin and 100 gm Methamphetamine. Forensic examination of their technical gadgets shed light on the other characters involved in the racket,” said K P S Malhotra, zonal director of the agency.

Further probe led the cops to the bank official codenamed Ice, Vishal and Polanco. Ice, who is a cocaine addict, came in touch with the gang during a drug deal with Mansary.

“As per their plan, they wanted to transfer the money from the dormant accounts to various new accounts. Polanco came to India in January and discussed the plan with others.
