He also met Ice at a hotel in Gurugram and paid him Rs 10 lakh as advance for helping them transfer the money,” zonal director Malhotra added.

Ice allegedly promised to arrange the necessary clearances and approvals for transactions. Vishal was arranging the necessary documents and logistics.

Title: Clean Ghazipur landfill fast, stresses Parl panel
Content:
New Delhi: Taking note of slow progress to tackle the mount of garbage at Ghazipur landfill site in east Delhi, a parliamentary committee has recommended expeditious remediation of the site on lines of Indore Municipal Corporation and convert it into a park.

The standing committee on urban development has recommended the agencies concerned to begin biomining at the site to reduce the waste. Bio-mining is a technique of extraction and segregation of minerals and useful material from mounds of waste. This can be used to extract materials like plastic, rubber, metals and gases.

East Delhi Municipal Corporation ( EDMC ) had informed the committee that efforts were being made to remediate the Ghazipur landfill site on line of Indore Municipal Corporation. But the legacy (old) waste at Indore was only 13 lakh tonnes whereas at Ghazipur it is over 140 lakh tonnes.

In its report, the panel said: “The committee from the post evidence reply finds that as desired by them a visit of commissioner, EDMC, joint secretary in-charge of SBM (U) in MoH&UA along with local MP took place and it was agreed to continue bio-mining of landfill site and use of output for RDF and construction and demolition plants with NHAI agreeing to take initial 5,000 tonnes of soil for road construction. The committee recommend that work be started expeditiously on the pattern of Indore.”

The panel headed by BJP MP Jagdambika Pal also took note of a survey which had highlighted how as high as 80% of public toilets in East Delhi were unusable for want of proper maintenance. “In view of ground reality, the committee does not subscribe to the views of the EDMC and recommends that all-out efforts be made on the part of MoH&UA under sanitation component for required level of maintenance in the affected area,” it said.

The panel also found that out of Rs 5,026 crore worth of funds released for solid waste management in urban areas, barely Rs 3,470 crore were used. It also criticised lower utilisation of funds under Atal Mission and Rejuvenation of Urban Transport scheme, which focusses on water supply and sewage connections.

It also flagged the slow pace of work done on the implementation of reform agenda like replacement of energy efficient lights. The report said that 74 lakh such lights were installed, which is less than the target of 100 lakh.

Title: Four mountaineers set to climb Mt Annapurna I, flag-off ceremony held in Pune
Content:
A team of four mountaineers to climb Mt Annapurna I — the world’s 10th highest peak.

PUNE: A team of four mountaineers from the city-based mountaineering club Giripremi will leave from Kathmandu on March 14 to climb Mt Annapurna I — the world’s 10th highest peak.

The flag-off ceremony for the same was held recently at Nehru Auditorium, Ghole Road. Brigadier Suneel Limaye, (VSM) Group Commander NCC, Pune Division, was the chief guest. The team was handed over the Indian tricolour during the ceremony. The team will hoist the tricolour atop the peak following the successful completion of the expedition.

“Mt Annapurna I stands tall at a height of 8,091 meters and is known as one of the toughest to scale across the globe in the 8,000er cluster. The difficulty level is because of the peculiar conditions at the elevation of 8,000m. Since there is very little oxygen at that level and the temperature could drop to -60 degrees celsius at the peak, the mountain is a difficult one to scale, ” director of Guadian Giripremi Institute of Mountaineering Umesh Zirpe told TOI.

“The team is expecting to summit between April 20 and 25. This is the period with ideal weather conditions with lowered wind speed,” Zirpe added.

Title: Hajipur killer appeals against death penalty
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Hajipur serial killer Marri Srinivas Reddy filed an appeal challenging the death penalty awarded to him by the trial court.

The trial court too referred the judgment seeking confirmation of its capital punishment order.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy admitted both pleas and issued notices to the respondents. The bench appointed senior counsel T Niranjan Reddy as amicus curiae in the case. Srinivas Reddy was convicted in the rape and murder of three girls. He was awarded death in two cases and life in one case.

Title: Delhi: Expect rain this week, but mercury to touch 30°C soon
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: By next week , the mercury may touch the 30 degree-Celsius mark in the national capital.

“Impact of the western disturbance, which hit Delhi-NCR on March 10, is expected to remain till March 14. From March 15 onwards, the temperature will start rising. We are expecting it to touch 30 degrees by March 18,” said Kuldeep Srivastava, a senior scientist at India Meteorological Department.

“The maximum temperature touches the 30-degree mark around March 17-18 every year,” he added.

“Till March 15, the maximum temperature will remain around 26-27 degrees Celsius, while the minimum will be around 14-15 degrees. Some rain is expected in the city, while some places in NCR might experience hailstorm. On Wednesday evening, Jind witnessed hailstorm, while rain was recorded in parts of Haryana,” Srivastava said.

While Safdurjung recorded 1mm rain till 8.30am on Wednesday, Palam witnessed 0.6mm rain. Among other stations, Ayanagar recorded 1.4mm, Lodhi Road 0.7mm and Ridge saw 0.6mm rain.

The maximum temperature on Wednesday was 27.4 degrees Celsius, two notches below normal, while the minimum was 14.8, one degree Celsius above normal.

On Thursday, partly cloudy sky is expected with very light rain or drizzle towards the night. The maximum and minimum temperatures would be around 28 and 15 degrees Celsius, respectively.

In terms of pollution levels, it was a “moderate” day in the city as the air quality index (AQI) touched 116. An AQI between 101 and 200 is considered moderate on the Central Pollution Control Board’s index.

Delhi-NCR’s average PM2.5 levels were recorded at 54.5 micrograms per cubic metre at 7pm on Wednesday, which was within the safe standards. The average PM10 levels were recorded at 113.4 micrograms per cubic metre, just outside the safe standards. The “emergency” benchmark for these pollutants under GRAP is, respectively, 300 and 500 micrograms per cubic metre, while the safe standards are 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre.

High wind speed and fairly widespread rainfall is likely to push AQI into the satisfactory or the good category on Thursday.

Title: Pune: Engineering colleges look to shift focus to IT streams
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: About 21 engineering colleges in Pune division have applied to the Directorate of Technical Education, either for the closure of a division entirely or to transfer the intake of one course into another.

In most cases, DTE officials said, the colleges have asked for transferring a portion of their intake in the mechanical department to the computer science or IT department.

A lack of placement offers in the mechanical department is the main reason for fewer students applying for that programme, which results in colleges wanting to close down that department, said officials.

“The number of students taking up engineering is coming down, and even among the various courses being offered, students want only computer (science) and IT and, to some extent, electronics. Further, due to a slump in the automobile sector and other such core areas, the recruitment process in the mechanical department is also down,” C Kunjir, assistant technical director, said.

But the statement that there are no jobs for mechanical students is also not completely true, say placement officers — while there is a demand-supply gap, it is the comparison with pay packages offered by IT companies that affects them.

“If an IT company recruits 30-35k freshers per year, the mechanical vertical of the same group will have a requirement of just 200-250 freshers a year. Hence, the supply is higher as compared to demand,” said Shitalkumar Rawandale , training & placements officer, Pimpri Chinchwad College of Engineering .

“There are jobs available for mechanical students in industrial zones, in small and medium industries, but students nowadays don’t want to work in these places, especially when they see their counterparts in IT working for higher salaries in much better offices,” Rawandale added.

Optimization of resources is also another reason for colleges to shut such divisions, or at least cut down their intake. “Infrastructure required for mechanical students is larger than that for computer science or IT. Secondly, mechanical engineering being an older branch, most colleges have an intake of 60-120. But if only 10 or fewer students apply, private colleges lose out proportionally on fees. The longer the seats lie vacant, the higher the losses, leading to teachers being paid less. This has a detrimental effect on quality and placements,” said an official in the field.

Title: New bus shelter at Town Hall gets positive response
Content:
Coimbatore: With additional features like a LED board that list out government welfare schemes and a chart which displays bus timings, a recently opened bus shelter near the public works department (PWD) office at Town Hall in the city has received positive responses from commuters.

Welcoming the move, R Pradeep, a commuter, said, “Earlier, we used to ask fellow passengers about the bus routes and timings. But now, all important information is displayed on the board. Besides, the shelter looks clean and different from the rest of the shelters.”

Unlike a few bus shelters that lack lighting, the new shelter has adequate lights and passengers are content that they don’t have to wait in the dark for the buses, he said, adding that he hopes that the city corporation maintains it properly.

The bus shelter has been set up at the cost of Rs 9 lakh using MLA funds. “We have been asking MLAs to choose different models while constructing bus shelters with their funds. The better model would give a better look to the city,” said a senior official from the corporation. New bus shelters in different models are expected to come up in other zones too, the official added.

Title: Woman constable molested in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Wanowrie police on Sunday booked two men for allegedly molesting a woman constable on the evening of March 7.

The constable, posted with the Pune rural police was staying in an apartment belonging to her brother-in-law, who is also a policeman with the State Reserve Police Force (SRPF).

Assistant inspector Bhagwan Kamble from the Wanowrie police station said, “The woman’s brother-in-law and father-in-law had met the constable and appealed to her to evict the flat because the accused and his family members wanted to shift there. However, she refused to leave the premises.”

The FIR filed by the woman stated, “The brother-in-law beat her, demanded sexual favours, molested her and threatened her with dire consequences while her father in-law helped him in the crime.”

“The woman’s complaint was registered under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code. Our investigation in underway,” Kamble said.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Pune: 2002 murder convict held 14 years after he jumped parole
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch of the Pune police arrested a murder convict, just over 14 years after he jumped parole, from Ranjangaon in Shirur taluka on Tuesday.

In 2002, the Pandharpur police had arrested dada Mahadeo Naiknaware (then 42) from Solapur district for the murder of his sister. A year later, the Solapur district and sessions court sentenced Naiknaware to life imprisonment. The Bombay high court and Supreme Court later upheld the conviction.

“Naiknaware was lodged at Yerawada Central Prison. He was released on parole on October 18, 2005. He failed to return to the jail when his parole lapsed three months later. The Pandharpur police lodged an FIR, but he continued to evade arrest. His whereabouts too were unknown,” senior inspector Rajendra Mokashi of the crime branch stated.

Police naik Wilson D’Souza received information that the convict had changed his name to Santosh Sathe and was living at Ranjangaon in Shirur taluka. He was taken into custody and handed over to the Pandharpur police for taking action.

Title: Two car dealers booked for selling stolen SUV to business man in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Kondhwa police booked two car dealers for cheating a Chakan businessman of Rs 10.91 lakh by selling him a stolen sports utility vehicle in February last year.

The car, valued at Rs14 lakh, was later seized by the Pune police crime branch.

The man received a telephone call from the Pune police crime branch on March 27, 2019, to take the vehicle to the station for inspection. “We had our suspicions that he had purchased a stolen vehicle,” police said.

Police said the businessman later brought the vehicle to the crime branch in the presence of the car dealers on April 1. “An inspection revealed that the vehicle was stolen. The car dealers repaid Rs4 lakh to the businessman and sought time to pay the balance of Rs10.91 lakh,” an officer said.

After the car dealers failed to repay the money, the businessman lodged an FIR against them on Monday and accused them of cheating him, a Kondhwa police officer said.

Police said the businessman, dealing in footwear, contacted the car dealers through a friend. He had selected the SUV and struck a deal with the suspects after getting the vehicle checked from an automobile showroom.

The businessman made the payment in instalments after the vehicle was transferred to his name, the police officer said.

Sub-inspector Santosh Shinde from the Kondhwa police is investigating the case.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: Non-coronavirus outbreak adds to medical concerns
Content: KOLKATA: Even as the Covid-19 scare looms large over Kolkata, other non-novel coronaviruses have been stalking the city and has led to a cough-and-cold outbreak. Along with the spread of the nCoV across the world, thousands have been infected with the other common viruses that have symptoms, which are worryingly similar to the one that has taken more than 3,500 lives over the last one month. But doctors maintained that these viruses are far more innocuous since they are not easily transmitted like nCoV, though they recommend caution and immediate medical action.Adeno virus, rhinovirus, influenza virus and non-novel coronaviruses are on the prowl in Kolkata, warned experts. These viruses routinely strike at this time of the year when temperatures fluctuate, leading to the onset of summer, they added. “They trigger a bout of cough and cold, body ache and, sometimes, fever. But the difference this time is the fear of nCoV, which has led to a big concern among people. So far, however, no one from Kolkata has been diagnosed with Covid-19. But it is better to stay at home in case your symptoms are severe,” pulmonologist at Fortis Hospital Raja Dhar said.Most patients have contracted dry cough this time. The cough has worsened in many patients, leading to body ache and fever, said internal medicine specialist Rahul Jain. “We are being forced to seek every such patient’s travel history to rule out the possibility nCoV. So far, I haven’t come across a suspect, but it’s now mandatory since every patient can’t possibly be tested for nCoV. We are also advising patients to make sure that they don’t get close to people who have travelled from the affected countries, at least for some time,” Jain said.The common viruses will now thrive and spread as the weather is ideal for their survival, pointed out RTIICS consultant Arindam Biswas. It’s getting warm but the maximum temperature has continued to hover around 30°C, which isn’t enough to kill the viruses, he pointed out. “But what makes these viruses less harmful is that they don’t get transmitted as easily or as fast as the nCoV,” Biswas said. He added that nothing has changed about the seasonal viruses other than the fact that they are leading to a scare. “Even though many are insisting on an nCoV test or hospitalization, it is the elderly who are at some risk. Due to their low immunity and comorbidities — like diabetes, renal failure, asthma and cardiac ailments — they are more susceptible to infections,” Biswas added.There is little to distinguish between nCoV and the rest, though, said experts. “Symptoms are identical and the incubation periods are long. Most nCoV as well as non-nCoV patients remain symptomless for several days. The only difference could be a runny nose and more pronounced upper respiratory tract infection,” said Jain.Once the mercury climbs, the viruses could die out, said Jain. “While there is no specific temperature, at which circulating viruses die, respiratory viruses generally die when the mercury climbs. So, we can expect the viral outbreak to end once it gets a little warmer,” he said.

Title: Pune: 3 engineering students held for flinging man from 11th floor of society building
Content:
Man pushed off 11th floor, 3 engineering students arrested

PUNE: The Kondhwa police have arrested three engineering students on charges of assaulting and murdering a 23-year-old man by flinging him into an open duct area from the 11th floor of a society building on Pisoli road near Khadi Machine chowk around 2.45am on Tuesday.

A quarrel over a money transaction has been prima facie established as the cause of the murder.

Kondhwa police inspector (crime) Mahadeo Kumbhar told TOI, “We have recorded the initial statement of an eyewitness (name withheld), who saw the three men pushing victim Sagar Chilaveri into the duct from the passage of their 11th floor flat. We will record the eyewitness’ statement before a magistrate under Section 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.”

Pintoo Kumar, one of the two security guards on duty at the Kul Utsav society, where the incident occurred, told TOI that they had seen the students running away from the parking gate at the rear of the premises moments after the victim had fallen to the ground floor.

Senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad of the Kondhwa police told TOI, “An hour-and-half later, the three suspects — Abhinav Jadhav (23), Akshay Gorde (22) and Tejas Gujar (20) — reported themselves to the Khadi Machine police chowky and admitted to their involvement in the crime. We have arrested them for offences under sections 302 (murder), 323 (assault) and 506 (criminal intimidation), among other charges, of the Indian Penal Code.”

Omkar Chandrakant Yenpure, a security guard of the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s godown adjacent to the Kul Utsav society, had witnessed the suspects assaulting the victim and registered an FIR in this connection.

The police said Sagar and the three suspects were staying together in an 11th floor flat in the ‘C’ wing building of the society. He came in contact with the three through a friend, who was also staying in the same room.

Sagar, a school dropout, was from Solapur district. After his parents’ death, he had shifted to Pune a few years ago in search of a livelihood. One of his two sisters, who stays in Pune, told the police that he recently left his work at a bakery and was working with a friend on event management jobs.

The police said Abhinav, who is from Pathoda in Beed district, is a final-year civil engineering student. Akshay is from Shegaon in Ahmednagar district and is a third-year mechanical engineering student. Tejas is from Shivajinagar in Beed city and is a first-year civil engineering student. All are enrolled with an engineering college in Kondhwa. “They are from families with farming backgrounds,” police inspector Kumbhar said.

Preliminary investigation revealed that Sagar had taken a loan of Rs15,000 at 10% per annum interest from Abhinav in January and was unable to repay the amount on time. Abhinav had been pursuing him for the money and had called Sagar on the phone late on Monday night to ask about his whereabouts.

When Sagar told him that he was at Swargate, Abhinav and the two others drove there triple seat on a bike. They forced Sagar to accompany them back to the society on the same bike, the police said.

Complainant Yenpure said in the FIR that he and the society’s guard, Pintoo Kumar, were having a chat near the main gate when the four arrived on a bike around 1.45am. Soon, the three students started punching Sagar with bare hands and he cried for help, the FIR stated.

The three then took Sagar to the parking area of the “C” wing building and again assaulted him there, Yenpure said. When he tried to stop them and asked why they were beating up the man, Yenpure said Abhinav told him that it was their personal matter and that Sagar was not returning his money.

The FIR stated that the three suspects took Sagar to their 11th floor room, where another young man was already there. They again assaulted the victim. Yenpure and the society’s other guard, Akash Devkar, who had followed them to the 11th floor, intervened and brought Abhinav, Akshay, Tejas and Sagar back to the main gate, the FIR added. Here too, Akshay slapped Sagar when he repeatedly told the three that he would return the money on Wednesday, the FIR added.

Yenpure, Pintoo and Devkar convinced the trio not to beat up the man. As the matter appeared to be sorted out, they advised Sagar to stay with them as the latter was reluctant to go back to their room, the FIR stated. Abhinav and the two others assured the guards that they would not beat up Sagar anymore and forced him to accompany them back to their room, the FIR added.

Yenpure and Pintoo then stayed back near the main gate and Devkar proceeded towards the “C” building. Around 2.45am, Devkar came running towards Yenpure and Pintoo and told them that the three students have thrown Sagar from the 11th floor passage, the FIR stated. Soon, the three guards rushed to the spot where Sagar was found lying motionless and profusely bleeding. They immediately alerted the police.

An advance postmortem report stated that Sagar died of multiple injuries, police said.

Title: 3 children norm may upset many electoral calculations
Content:
Amaravati: With the ‘three children norm’ being followed strictly in the elections to local bodies, candidates have started digging into the antecedents of their rivals. As per rules, any person with three children or more is ineligible to contest municipal polls as also elections to the posts of sarpanch, MPTC and ZPTC.

However, a few power hunger leaders have in the past managed to work around the rule and enter the fray. Candidates, this time round, are busy ensuring that their ineligible rivals don’t find their way in.

The three children norm, however, does not stand if the third child of the aspirant concerned was born before 1995. Taking advantage of this clause, a few leaders have produced fake birth certificates for their children and contest polls.

Yalavarthi Srinivasa Rao, who served as municipal chairman of Gudivada in Krishna district between 2014 and 2019, was called out for having three children, after which an official enquiry confirmed he was indeed ineligible to continue as councilor and chairperson.

When the TDP government made an attempt to disqualify Srinivasa Rao, a close confident of local legislator Kodali Nani (now minister), he swiftly moved to TDP in 2016 and was spared the axe.

Since removing elected leaders is a lengthy legal and political tussle, candidates are taking care to lodge complaints against rivals right at the time of scrutiny of nominations. Having a third child through a second wife either after the death or divorce of the first wife after the cut-off date is no exemption to contest polls. However, the woman, who has one child after 1995 with a divorcee or widower with two children, is eligible to contest the election. The rule is that the candidate should not have three children biological children.

In some cases, particularly in rural areas, people who make woman live-in partners do not make their bond official to avoid legal complications from the first wife or family. However, they would get caught when the live-in partner gives birth to children as their names would be registered as father in records. A person is ineligible to contest even if his wife is carrying a third child.

Title: Kolkata: Manja slashes 2 bikers on Maa flyover
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Two bikers on the flyover sustained severe injuries from kite strings when they were on the flyover. One of the incidents occurred near the Biswakarma building and the other near Boat Club. While one of the injured was admitted to Apollo Hospitals with cuts on his throat, the other was discharged from CNMC Hospital after being treated for injuries to his right hand.

In the first incident, Pramit Dutta (32), a resident of Netaji Subhas Road, was injured when a kite string cut through his chin around 4.55pm on Monday. He was admitted to the emergency ward at Apollo. Doctors said that he had a narrow escape.

In the second incident, Aktar Hossain (48), a resident of Salt Lake, received cut injuries on his right thumb when a kite string got wound his head on Maa flyover near Boat Club and he tried to remove it. The police said that they were trying to use CCTV footage from the area to identity the spot from where the kites were being flown.

Earlier, the Kolkata traffic police had proposed the installation of nets, view cutters or even 4ft high wiring on the southern flank of the Maa flyover that has, so far, witnessed over two dozen accidents to reduce chances of alloy-coated kite strings injuring bikers.

With the most common non-fatal lesions were found to be of the jugular veins, larynx and trachea. Cops also proposed that regular raids be carried across Kolkata — and not just southeast Kolkata — to seize such alloy-coated strings.

Title: Two from Kolkata die in Sikkim accident
Content:
Representative image

SILIGURI: Two tourists, including a girl, from Kolkata and a car driver died around 1:45pm on Tuesday after the vehicle fell into a gorge at Keew Khola near Lingtam in east Sikkim . Seven persons were injured in the accident. The accident was triggered by a landslide .

Police identified the deceased as — Jharna Saha (54), a resident of Barasat, Kalikapur, Hrishpriya Ghosh (13), a resident of Murari Pukur Road, and driver Suraj Chhetri from Manzing Lingmoo in south Sikkim. The seven injured have been identified as Taposh Saha (46), Narayan Ghosh (52), Kunjala Saha (35) Debjani Saha, Mithu Ghosh , Rishi Ghosh (8) and Raja Saha — all residents of Barasat.

DIG (law and order) Sonam T Bhutia said, “Boulders suddenly fell on the road and hit the vehicle, pushing it down the hill about 100 feet below. The three persons who died were thrown out of the vehicle.” The injured are undergoing treatment at Rongli Hospital. The family was returning from Zuluk in East Sikkim.

Title: ‘Diabetes, hypertension are most common cause of kidney ailments’
Content:
Madurai: Some of the high risk factors for chronic kidney disease are diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, obesity and family history and early diagnosis is key to prevent it, director and chief nephrologist of Madurai Kidney Centre and Transplantation Research Institute, Dr T Dhinakaran has said.

Addressing reporters on Tuesday ahead of the ‘World Kidney Day’ to be observed on March 12, Dhinakaran said, “The symptoms of a kidney disease don’t appear promptly, so getting tested is the only way to know if your kidneys are healthy. This is why there needs to be more awareness. Some of the symptoms of chronic kidney diseases include swelling of feet, ankles or legs, fatigue, consistent hypertension and bone damage.” For screening of kidney ailments, simple tests once in 6 months or 1 year like urine analysis, creatinine and eGFR, checking of blood pressure and sugar is recommended.

“Early diagnosis is key for good and complete recovery from chronic kidney disease. Early treatment can avoid need for dialysis and transplantation. During treatment, it is highly important to follow medical advice as prescribed by doctors when it comes to food and medicine intake,” he said.

Experts suggest reducing salt intake, eating a low-fat diet, a 30 minute exercise every day and regular health check-ups to prevent the onset of kidney disease. “Many think drinking lots of water can prevent kidney ailments. This is not completely true. An average adult needs around two litres of water per day. Both drinking water less than 600 ml or more than six litres can be detrimental to kidney health,” Dhinakaran said.

Title: MHRD panel finds lapses on part of MCC administration
Content:
Kozhikode: The national monitoring committee on minority education under the ministry of human resources development ( MHRD ) on Tuesday intervened in the suicide case a student of Malabar Christian College ( MCC ) after he was barred from writing exam following attendance shortage, and demanded an independent inquiry into the incident after placing the principal and teachers concerned under suspension.

A Vinod Karuvarakundu, member of the committee who visited Malabar Christian College and the house of the deceased student Jaspreet Singh on Tuesday, said prima facie there were lapses on the part of college authorities in taking required steps to enable the student write the exam, despite him having genuine reasons for the attendance shortage.

“The ongoing internal investigation by the committee appointed by the management and the police probe are not looking into the factors which led to the suicide like the mental torture the student had to face. What is needed is a probe into the allegations raised by the family of the deceased student by an independent committee of the varsity and it should happen after placing the principal and the class teacher under suspension,” Vinod said.

He said the committee would submit report with recommendations to the MHRD and UGC and also the state higher education department and the university.

Vinod said the principal was handling the incident in a casual manner and added that it is a lapse on the part of the college that they did not visit the family of the deceased student. Also the family of the student has raised serious charges involving racial discrimination that a teacher asked the student to go to Punjab and write the exam.

“The student had a genuine reason for the attendance shortage and the college authorities should have given it due consideration,” he added.

Title: Univ’s move to change name of CU centre in UT flayed
Content:
Kozhikode: Hamdullah Sayeed , former MP and son of late Union minister and 10-time MP from Lakshadweep , P M Sayeed, has asked Calicut University to desist from moves to change the name of P M Sayeed Calicut University Centre in Lakshadweep.

Hamdullah, who visited the varsity on Tuesday, took up the issue with vice-chancellor Anil Vallathol and said Calicut University had named the centre after P M Sayeed in 2005 in recognition of his contribution to the overall development of the UT and in particular to honour his role in setting up of the centre at Andrott in Kavaratti and Kadmat islands.

In a letter to the vice-chancellor, he said it has been learnt that Lakshadweep MP Mohammed Faizal had raised the issue of changing the name of the centre during a meeting of syndicate members held recently.

UDF-affiliated syndicate member Rasheed Ahammed said the demand from some quarters to change the name of the centre was raised at the previous meeting of the syndicate and it was decided to ask a syndicate panel to look into the matter. “It will be highly deplorable if the name of the centre given to honour a late veteran leader from Lakshadweep is changed to suit some vested interests. The varsity centre was renamed after P M Sayeed in 2005 on the basis of a syndicate resolution. Changing the name now would lead to protests in the islands and the university should reject such requests,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Stay away from gatherings, collector urges citizens amid coronavirus fear
Content:
Anxiety increases as the cases shoot up in Pune.

PUNE: Collector Naval Kishore Ram on Tuesday issued a strict advisory against any kind of gathering, while warning of legal action against those flouting these norms.

The advisory came after the count of novel coronavirus patients climbed to five in the city on Tuesday evening, from just two a day before.

The collector urged citizens to refrain from attending any kind of event or even going to cinema halls for any screening. While there is no closure of cinema halls or movie screenings, as done in Kerala, he said people should exercise caution. “It (cinema hall) is a place which can be avoided for a few days,’’ he said, adding, “My team will be reaching out to those holding events. If they do not adhere to the stringent advisory, legal action will follow.”

On school closure, he said strict guidelines would be issued if required. “We will take decision after consulting the government,’’ he said.

The collector said five squads had been formed to gather information about the contacts of the coronavirus positive patients. “The squads will verify if contacts of the patients are showing any symptoms of Covid-19. They will also keep a track of places the patients visited,” he said.

Appealing to all the doctors of the district through the Indian Medical Association (IMA), the collector said the doctors should keep the information of all the patients who are coming to India from foreign lands, separately.

Pune divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar said a video-conferencing with the chief minister and others was expected on Wednesday.

Till March 10, a total of 1,29,448 passengers have been screened at Mumbai, Pune and Nagpur airports. According to the Union government’s new notification, passengers arriving from all over the world are being inspected at these three airports in the state.

Title: Holi traffic violations downto one-eighth of last year
Content:
New Delhi: The traffic police booked 2 ,176 people for traffic violations during Holi on Tuesday. This is about one-eighth of the total challans — 16 ,000 — last year . More than 600 of these were booked for drunken driving .

Police officers say that the number of violations were visibly less this year. PCR calls too dipped sharply to 8,667 as compared to 18,798 last year. The cops are attributing it to increase in police presence. Police commissioner S N Shrivastava and other top cops monitored the functioning of their men on the ground all through the day. The traffic police had deployed more than 170 teams across the city at major intersections besides 131 joint teams of local police, PCR and traffic maintaining vigil. About 1600 men were on the ground.

One of the reasons could also be the fact that this time because of the coronavirus scare, the Holi celebrations were subdued and fewer people were driving on the road. According to traffic police, 647 people were booked for drunken driving; 181 people for triple riding; 1,156 for riding without helmets and 156 for dangerous driving.

The cops had sent out messages about safe driving during Holi. They had asked RWAs not to allow minors drive. Special teams with alcometers and others to chase down violators were present on roads. The PCR calls, according to the cops, were related to petty arguments and fights during Holi, most of which were resolved on the spot.

Vigil had also been stepped up in the riot-affected areas of north-east Delhi to prevent any confrontation between communities. The police had roped in aman committee members from all these areas to counsel people and conduct peace marches.

Meanwhile, three fatal accidents were reported on Tuesday. Two of these involved two-wheelers, while in the third, a man was mowed down by a speeding car. Police say the first accident was reported near Kanjhawala where a biker died after falling off his two-wheeler allegedly while speeding. A similar accident was reported near Civil Lines around the same time. The third accident was reported near Bijwasan where a man was mowed down by a speeding car.

Title: World Hearing Day awareness campaign held at Rajaji hospital
Content:
Madurai: Awareness on hearing ailments particularly affecting children and senior citizens marked the culmination of the week-long campaign as part of the World Hearing Day at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) on Tuesday. The campaign was organised by the ENT department of GRH as part of the World Hearing Day, observed on March 3.

“There is not much awareness, especially for the need to screen infants and children early to diagnose if they have any hearing ailments by birth. Hearing ailments are more common especially in cases of children born in consanguineous marriages or those born prematurely,” said Dr N Dhinakaran, head, department of ENT.

He added that they have been trying to create basic awareness to prevent hearing ailments by discussing about the use of mobile phones, damaging ear drums while cleaning ears and others.

The concluding event, in which GRH dean Dr J Sangumani was the chief guest, saw the participation of beneficiaries of hearing aids and cochlear implants at the hospital. Free hearing aids were also distributed to both hearing-impaired children and adults.

“During the last three years, 138 cochlear implants have been done at GRH. Screening and treatment of the latest technology for people of all ages for all kinds of hearing ailments is available here. In case of any symptoms of hearing ailments, the child or adult must come for check-up,” said Dr Dhinakaran.

Title: Civic bodies ready app for collecting penalties digitally
Content:
New Delhi: Paper slips and manual booking by civic bodies may soon become a thing of the past. A unified web-based payment system via an app and central management information system (MIS) is being created for payment of all the fines/penalties for the local bodies in Delhi.

A meeting in this regard was held by the chief secretary, and integration with an existing app of a private bank is being mulled. The same gateway can later be used for collecting garbage collection user charges, an official present in the meeting said.

“A presentation by ICICI Bank regarding the web and app-based solution for levying penalties for waste management was made in the meeting,” he said.

“The meeting also discussed certain gaps and legal hurdles in the implementation of digital pathways for levying the fines and charges. There are no provisions for levying penalties to offenders not complying with some provisions as per NGT directions and some sections of waste management rules. There is also an issue regarding appointment of appellate authority,” he added.

Municipal corporations are also in the process of imposing fines for not segregating waste while plans are afoot to start levying garbage charges. “We have been instructed to keep the household databank ready for every ward so that there is seamless transition and no problems are faced in user charge collection,” another municipal official said.

All the local body representatives in the review meeting agreed for a common payment gateway and management information system for levying penalties. “This will help in the monitoring of penalties at the common platform and shall display the requisite information to all the supervisors. During the meeting, ICICI Bank also agreed to proceed by integrating common payment gateway and MIS with the existing app by working in coordination with NIC,” the official added.

Title: Saseendran urges pvt bus operators to call off strike
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Transport minister A K Saseendran on Tuesday urged private bus operators to call off the indefinite strike, would begin from Wednesday, considering the unfavourable situation prevailing in the state.“Private bus operators are requested to corporate with the government as the state is under the threat of Covid-19 . Considering the present condition of the state those who are working in public transport sector should be alert. Various examinations are going on and it will be difficult for students as well as passengers. So, private bus operators should withdraw the indefinite strike declared from Wednesday,” said Saseendran.The joint action committee of bus owners had announced strike last week demanding hike the minimum fare to Rs10. They claimed that revenue collection was not enough to meet the expenses such as insurance, purchase of spare parts and fuel charges. The bus owners had earlier declared strike on February 21, which was withdrawn after meeting from transport minister.Mentioning some measures such as reduction in vehicle tax of stage carriages to strengthen the public transport system, Saseendran said, “The government has taken sympathetic approach towards the demands of private bus owners. Also, measures have to be taken regarding the demand for fare revision. Justice Ramachandran Committee has started a study on the demand and is taking opinion of various stakeholders. The government is yet to receive the committee report."

Title: Mayor seeks councillors’ support in culling birds
Content: Kozhikode: The mayor, Thottathil Raveendran has sought the cooperation of the councillors to carry out the effective culling of the poultry and pet birds . Mayor informed the council meeting on Tuesday that the collector and chief veterinary officer called him on Tuesday morning informing of the non-cooperation of the councillors.Mayor also urged the need for proactive support and involvement of councillors for effective containment of bird flu and in case positive coronavirus cases are reported in the corporation limits. Mayor said that all the public programmes organized by the city corporation will be postponed in the wake of total shut down enforced by the state government across the state following confirmation of coronavirus cases.M C Sudhamani of Congress urged the mayor to deploy special squads to check the shifting of poultry and pet birds at the time of culling operations.City corporation health officer Dr R S Gopakumar informed that public protests against culling of poultry and pet birds were reported in ward 12 of the city corporation, which falls within 1km radius of the bird flu-hit area at Vengeri. Corporation health officer informed that the issue occurred when a pet bird owner resisted saying that he will allow his birds to be culled only after the test report on the birds confirms bird flu. Collector Sambasiva Rao convened a meeting in the evening to resolve the issue. Corporation health officer Dr R S Gopakumar, in his reply, said that the poultry and pet bird’s sale and transportation have been banned within 10km radius of the bird Flu-hit areas during the culling process. Health officer added that this existing ban will be lifted once the on-going culling process is completed.Raveendran informed the council that the issue on drinking water scarcity due to recurring pipe bursts will be brought to the attention of the minister for water resources K Krishnankutty. Mayor also informed the council that he will also talk with the KWA superintendent engineer to resolve the issue to ensure the supply of drinking water to scarcity hit areas.Councillor K T Beeran koya of IUML and N Satheesh Kumar of BJP urged the mayor to repair the streetlights at the earliest.Raveendran in his reply said that Karnataka State Electronics Development Corporation Ltd (KSEDC) has already installed around 12,000 streetlights in the corporation limits. The streetlights installation is progressing at Kovoor and Karaparamba KSEB electrical sections on war footing. He said a total of 18 squads have been engaged in installing the streetlights and the work will be completed by April 31.Thomas Mathew of JD(U) urged the mayor to take steps to clear traffic block during the weekend on Kozhikode beach. Mayor said that a traffic regulatory committee meeting will be held on March 16 to take a decision.

Title: Corpn gets clearance for two more packages of drinking water project
Content:
Cleared/255 words

Madurai: The Madurai Corporation has received clearance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for two more packages (first and third) of the drinking water project being implemented at a cost of Rs 1,020 crore. The civic body has already received the clearance for the second package a few months ago.

Officials said that it is a major progress in the project, which aims at bringing 125 million litres a day (MLD) more. Corporation officials will hand over work orders to shortlisted contractors after getting approval from the state tender award committee.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan told TOI that while approval for the package one came recently, the third package was approved on Monday. They are monitoring the progress of the project on a day-to-day basis and ensure that it is implemented at the earliest. Once completed, water shortage faced by the city will be solved for years to come.

The Rs 1,020 crore project comprises drawing 125 MLD water from Mullaperiyar, treatment at Pannaipatti in Theni district and bringing to the city through giant pipes.

A corporation official said that construction work for package two, which is establishment of a treatment plant, began two weeks ago.

Recently, the corporation approached the ADB for two more projects for distribution of water brought to the city - one for 57 wards in core city and one for 28 newly-added areas. The remaining 15 out of total 100 wards are being taken care of under the Smart City project. The estimated cost including the recently proposed project is Rs 1,790 crore.

· Package I-Construction of a check dam and pumping water from the Lower Camp to Pannaipatti at a cost of Rs 320.

· Package II- Construction of a water treatment plant at Pannaipatti at an estimated cost of Rs 110 crore.

· Package III – To provide a giant water line from Pannaipatti to city covering 75 km at an estimated cost of Rs 590 crore.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: PMC on alert, sports event put off as safety takes hold
Content: PUNE: On the heels of the first few confirmed cases of novel coronavirus infection in the city, mayor Muralidhar Mohol on Tuesday appealed to citizens to avoid public places and large gatherings.Mohol further urged Puneites to hold festive celebrations at home and said there was no need to panic; that the civic body was prepared to handle the situation. “Pune Municipal Corporation will ensure there is no negligence in dealing with the situation. All necessary steps are being taken to handle the infection. I am appealing to citizens to take utmost care and not believe in rumours,” Mohol said.The civic administration has already directed its health department to work in coordination with state government machinery, including the district administration.People should remain alert and visit doctors in case of any symptoms, he said .The mayor said the citizens should avoid large gatherings and crowded places for the next few days as precautionary measure. “The civic administration will have daily follow-ups about the preparations on dealing with the virus spread,” he said.Mohol announced the suspension of the ongoing sports event — Mahapour Chashak. “ We have taken the decision to suspend the events. About 36 types of sports competitions have been planned under the event, of which about 50% have been conducted so far,”he said.

Title: For better LIFE, corp opts for equality
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The city corporation has decided to prioritize harmony and equality over space and comfort in implementing the first LIFE tower under state’s housing mission in the state capital.

The corporation planned to construct the first apartment complex under LIFE mission at Karimadom which was earlier chosen for another housing scheme under basic services for urban poor ( BSUP ).

Officials brought to the notice of the administration that 320 dwelling units have already been constructed under BSUP at Karimadom and the dimensions of flat in terms of plinth area, number of bedrooms varied for BSUP and LIFE mission. Officials learned that having two set of flats with different dimensions to house people in the same area would create social inequality and could lead to problems that would derail the objectives of LIFE mission.

In BSUP, the plinth area unit is 40.30m2 and it has one bedroom, multipurpose hall, kitchen, toilet cum bath and a balcony/ verandah. While in the LIFE mission project, the plinth area of the flat is 46.45m2 and with two bedrooms, a hall, kitchen, balcony and separate toilet & bath.

Corporation mayor K Sreekumar informed LIFE mission that implementing dwellings of differing facilities may cause social issues among the residents of the colony. Hence, he requested to give sanction to Thiruvananthapuram Corporation to take forward LIFE Tower project of executing 52 dwelling units comprising 20 units of 37.75m2 and 32units of 40.01 m2 instead of 44 dwelling units at a maximum estimated cost of Rs.4.62 crores.

The corporation has identified 50 cents of land for construction of LIFE towers in Karimadom colony. A total of 560 dwelling units are proposed to be built under BSUP scheme, of which 320 units have been completed and 112 units are under construction.

LIFE mission CEO wrote to the state government that the deviation request by corporation can be considered favourably and LSGD has now given sanction to alter the approved dimension of flats in LIFE tower which will be constructed at Karimadom.

Project officials with housing mission had to deal with numerous instances where beneficiaries continuously alleged complaints regarding selection, shifting to interim shelters and even grievances that flats had been awarded to ineligible beneficiaries. It is in the light of these previous experiences that the officials recommended cutting down on space and rooms to ensure peace and equality in the housing colony.

The city corporation is set to purchase nine acres for the construction of apartment complexes under LIFE housing mission after a series of botched attempts to find plots for housing complexes.

Title: Party chief’s faith changes fate of Pilli, Mopidevi
Content:
Amaravati: Luck, they say, plays a pivotal role in politics. Who better than veteran leaders Mopidevi Venkata Ramana Rao and Pilli Subhashchandra Bose to exemplify that. In the last one decade, both leaders have thought of quitting active politics several times and each time they have been thwarted. One of the prime reasons for their wish to quit was that they were not wealthy enough to continue contesting even after biting the dust in back to back elections. But as luck would have it, the party chief never lost faith in them.

Let us look at Rao for instance. He has set a new record as the first MP from the fishermen community in the state. Rao entered public life at a young age. He worked for Congress students’ organisations, National Students’ Union of India, and youth Congress before becoming mandal parishad president in 1984 when he was only 21. He grabbed an assembly ticket in 1989 but lost his first battle despite Congress sweeping the elections. He faced defeat in the subsequent 1994 election as well.

But given his following among the Backward Classes in the constituency, Congress retained him as candidate in 1999 and he tasted luck the very same year. After winning the 2004 election, he joined the YSR cabinet. By winning the 2009 elections he delivered a hat-trick of victories and continued in the cabinet.

Post the bifurcation of the state in 2014, Rao joined the YSRC and stood by Jaganmohan Reddy. He was the first prominent leader to be arrested by the CBI in connection with Jaganmohan Reddy’s disproportionate assets case. After facing jail term, Rao suffered health issues and eventually lost the 2014 election. But again, the party leader did not lose faith in him. Jaganmohan Reddy fielded him from Repalle in 2019.

Surprisingly, Rao lost the segment with a massive margin even when YSRC virtually swept the state. Party colleagues were of the opinion that the poll debacle must be the end of his political journey. Surprisingly, Rao was named as part of Jaganmohan Reddy’s cabinet even before becoming MLC. But now with the governemnt set to abolish the council, Rao is set to join the Rajya Sabha. “It is my leader Jagan who has always stood by me. Entering the Rajya Sabha has been a dream for me,” Mopidevi told TOI.

The story has been almost similar when it comes to the fate of Bose, one of the five deputy chief ministers. He parted ways with the Congress and joined Jaganmohan Reddy in 2010.

Later, he lost the byelections in 2012 and general elections in 2014 from Ramachandrapuram constituency. YSRC then nominated him to the legislative council in 2016. Despite being an MLC, the party fielded him in the 2019 elections from Mandapet. However, Bose lost his third consecutive election. Yet, Jaganmohan Reddy made him a party of the state cabinet and deputy CM. “Jagan is the first CM in the history to send a BC from East Godavari district to Rajya Sabha,” said Bose.

Title: Pune: Cluster containment plan to check spread of coronavirus
Content: Pune: State health officials will implement the cluster containment strategy in the city to check the spread of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19).Four of the five positive cases of Covid-19 found in Pune are from two housing socities on Sinhagad Road. The strategy entails carrying a survey of people living within a 3km radius of the housing society where the couple and their daughter, who tested positive for Covid-19, live on Sinhagad Road. Another co-traveller, who tested positive for the contagion, stays in a another housing society on the same road.Agra was the first city in India to implement the strategy after six residents contracted the infection from their relative who had returned from Italy. The five positive cases of Covid-19 in Pune — four travellers and a private cab driver — in two days have underscored the need to curb the spread of the virus in the community in the city as well.Union health minister Harsh Vardhan on Monday called upon states to adopt the cluster containment strategy making district collectors more accountable and laid emphasis on contact tracing and strengthening district surveillance teams to avoid widespread community transmission."In the cluster containment approach, we immediately start checking and sensitising every household within the 3km radius of the house of an infected person and also those who have come in contact with the affected to prevent the community spread of the virus. We will implementing the strategy in the city through the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s (PMC) health officials,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate told TOI.“The couple and their daughter, who tested positive for the contagion, live in a housing society on Sinhagad Road in Pune. The PMC health officials will carry out house-to-house surveillance of all the households falling within the radius of three kilometers around the society,” he said.A team of paramedics hasbeen formed to carry out the survey. ‘Every team will have a doctor, along with four paramedics. If a resident is found to have influenza-like-illness (ILI) symptoms, he or she will be assessed and treated. If need, the person can be isolated and tested them,” a civic health official said.“The cluster containment strategy is aimed at containing the virus within a defined geographic area by early detection, breaking the chain of transmission and thus preventing its spread to newer areas,” said senior public health expert Subhash Salunke, former director general of the state health department.

Title: Double murder: Aide of key accused held
Content:
New Delhi: Vikrant Nagar , who was arrested for the murder of a mother- daughter duo in Vasundhara Enclave, had woven a web of lies to woo Samrita (25). He had not only scripted a false story about being an orphan, but also claimed to be a drug abuse survivor.

Nagar had called his friend Shanky Sharma to Delhi to help him execute the murder. Sharma was arrested on Tuesday. Police said when they arrested Sharma it came to fore that he had reached Delhi from Mumbai via a GoAir flight around 10.30pm on Sunday. He went straight to Mansara apartments where the victims resided.

Nagar told the police officers that Samrita and her mother, Sumita Mary, had started to ignore him for the last few weeks. “He said he loved the girl and did everything for her in the last four years of their relationship. Later, she started getting close to someone else. Samrita initially ignored him, and later her mother too. He claimed to be upset by this,” said a cop privy to the investigation.

“On Sunday, Nagar brought a new SIM card. The accused duo entered the building around 2.30am. Nagar called up Samrita and asked her to come to the gate to meet him. As soon as she left home, the duo entered the house and killed her mother using the kitchen knife, which has been recovered. In the meantime, Samrita returned home and she too was stabbed to death. The duo then left the house, along with their cash, jewellery and Maruti Suzuki Baleno car ,” said the officer.

“They did not know how to drive properly and hence left the car near Trilokpuri in east Delhi . From there, they booked a cab and Nagar left for his house and Sharma to a hotel in East of Kailash,” the police officer added.

Nagar then gave the SIM to his mother and told her that he was going to meet his friends in Jaipur. Police officials traced the number and reached the mother who informed them that her son had left for Jaipur. He was arrested midway from near Manoharpur.

Sharma resided in the area close to Nagar’s house and supplied tiffins to different guesthouses in south Delhi area five years back. He had later moved to Mumbai to pursue his modelling career. The two had become friends as they shared a common interest for modelling. Police said the two are drug addicts.

Sharma had also purchased two mobile phones from the robbed money, which were recovered by the police.

Title: MV Act rules to be in place for spot payment
Content:
New Delhi: Motorists caught violating traffic rules may soon be able to pay fine for some of the offences on the spot .

Delhi government is likely to notify the amended Motor Vehicles (MV) Act, which was implemented in September last year, by Friday. Sources said the government has not made any changes in the amount of penalty and agreed to implement the same fine as prescribed by the Parliament in the amended Act. The lieutenant governor has already approved the proposal and the file is awaiting final clearance from the law department of Delhi government before notification.

Though motorists violating the traffic rules are still paying enhanced penalties as prescribed in the amended act, they are forced to go to court since the Act has not been notified by Delhi government.

Section 200 of the MV Act authorises the state government to fix the quantum of penalty for some offences that are compoundable and traffic police and the state transport department have the power to collect the fine on the spot. The amended MV Act prescribed penalties for 61 offences and out of these, the state government doesn’t have any discretion in the case of 27 offences.

Delhi government has the discretion of keeping the penalty 100% as prescribed in the Act or reduce it in the case of 34 compoundable offences.

For instance, the penalty for talking on mobile phone while driving is Rs 5,000, but if the government decides, the quantum of the penalty can be fixed at Rs 2,000 if the offender is paying the fine on the spot.

The MV Act is in the Concurrent List and the Centre brought the Act. The Delhi government, however, kept the notification in abeyance and let traffic violators pay enhanced penalty in courts.

Sources said special commissioner of police (traffic) Taj Hasan in a meeting with Delhi transport minister Kailash Gahlot and other officials of the department had requested for the notification of the Act at the earliest as it led to increased workload on courts.

Title: Roads fill with waste as sanitary workers’ protest enters 2nd day
Content:
Coimbatore: The quantity of solid waste that reaches the city corporation’s dump yard at Vellalore has come down by 100 tonnes per day after over 1,000 temporary sanitary workers boycotted their work and staged protest for the second consecutive day on Tuesday.

A corporation source said, “The dump yard receives about 1,050 tonnes of solid waste every day. But in the last couple of days, the quantity has come down by 100 tonnes per day.”

Pointing out that more than 5,000 sanitary workers are working in the city, the source said that the protest has not created any major impact on the waste collection system of the city.

More than 1,000 temporary sanitary workers boycotted work and staged a protest at the corporation office in Town Hall on Tuesday. They condemned the corporation for failing to provide them first preference while recruiting people for the posts of permanent sanitary workers.

Municipal administration minister SP Velumani on Friday handed over appointment orders to close to 350 candidates who were selected for the posts of permanent sanitary workers.

“Most of the sanitary workers are working for more than 10 years on temporary basis with the corporation. It is unfair to neglect them and recruit fresh candidates when the temporary workers had been demanding regularization of job,” DMK MLA N Karthik said. Karthik held talks with corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar on behalf of the workers on Tuesday.

He said close to 700 temporary workers were recruited and posts of permanent workers were filled when the DMK was in power.

“There is a provision to make them permanent. The corporation has not tried,” he said. There is no transparency in the functioning of the corporation in the absence of council, he added.

Explaining how sanitation condition of the city is already at stake, he said that the condition would degrade further if the corporation fails to convince the workers to get back to work. The corporation should hold talks with the workers and give assurance to make them permanent, he added.

Title: Tamil Nadu minister warns against rumour mongering on eating chicken
Content:
Udumalai K Radhakrishnan (Image credit: Twitter)

MADURAI: There is no harm in consuming chicken and egg, minister for animal husbandry Udumalai K Radhakrishnan said on Tuesday. He warned stringent action against those spreading rumours about Covid-19 and bird flu and linking them with poultry consumption.

The minister was talking to reporters in Kovilpatti after taking part in some functions at Kalugumalai and Kattalankulam in Tuticorin district .

“Thousands are working in the chicken and egg industry. The industry fetches revenue to the tune of several crore rupees for Tamil Nadu,” the minister said and appealed to consumers not to believe in rumours.

The minister said the bird flu situation had been brought under control in Kozhikode district of Kerala where the outbreak was reported last weekend. Elaborating on the measures taken by the department to prevent bird flu in Tamil Nadu, the minister said 26 disinfection camps had been established at check posts on the Tamil Nadu-Kerala border.

A majority of these to disinfect trucks and vehicles entering Tamil Nadu are established in The Nilgiris (8) and Coimbatore (12) considering their proximity to Kozhikode. “Teams are also disinfecting trucks at Tirupur, Tenkasi and Kanyakumari ,” he said. The minister said that poultry farms in the western districts (poultry hubs of the state) are under round-the-clock surveillance.

To a question on filling up posts of veterinarians in the state, the minister said that 650 have been appointed by the government. He added that 200 more vacancies created due to opening of more branch hospitals and dispensaries will be filled up in the coming year. A government order (GO) has also been passed for building 120 dispensaries at Rs 43 crore.

Title: Storm of allegations breaks out over pre-poll ordinance
Content:
Vijayawada: With the announcement of local body elections, liquor seems to have taken political centre stage.

While the state government has brought in an ordinance, which disqualifies the candidates and sentence them to up to three years in jail if it were to be proved that they distributed money and liquor to voters.

This would be appplicable even if the election is over and the candidates have won them. But the opposition has alleged that it is only a way to deter their candidates from contesting.

The opposition parties have alleged that while on the one hand the ruling party has been distributing liquor through village volunteers, on the other hand, cases are being booked against other party cadres for ‘illegal possession of liquor’.

The YSRC, however, has condemned the allegations and retorted stating that the opposition is scared of losing the election with curbs put in place on distribution of liquor during elections.

A case in point would the incident, which took place at Edupalli of Nagaram mandal in Guntur district, on Tuesday. Tensions prevailed at Edupalli after police arrested a man identified as Alla Chowdary on charges of possessing 87 bottles of liquor. However, the TDP has alleged that the police are foisting false cases against their cadre.

Following the arrest, Telugu Desam Party Repalle MLA, Anagani Satya Prasad, staged a dharna demanding the release of Chowdary and suspension of Nagaram sub-inspector who booked the case against Chowdary.

“When buying a single bottle of liquor has become difficult these days, how can a person buy 87 bottles,” he questioned, adding, that even if it has happened it was the failure of the government in preventing a man from buying 87 bottles of liquor.

He said the YSRC is trying file false cases against potential TDP candidates so that they are unable to contest the elections” he said. Meanwhile, TDP MLC Buddha Venkanna has demanded that liquor shops be shut till the elections are completed.

Advisor to the government on public affairs, Sajjala Ramakrishna Reddy hit, has back at the TDP on the allegations and said instead of feeling happy with the government’s ordinace, the opposition complaining about it. “The opposition has accepted defeat even before the elections have been held,” he claimed.

But there is no clarity on whether liquor shops will be shut down till elections are completed. Although the minister for irrigation Anil Kumar Yadav has said that liquor shops will be closed from March 12, sources in the excise department said they have not received any direction from the government with regard to the issue.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: Civic body to use its properties as quarantine hubs
Content: PUNE: The increased international arrivals and demand for quarantine has prompted the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) to look up houses on rent across the city.The civic administration is currently using vacant municipal properties as quarantine facilities. Nearly 3,000 travellers can be accommodated at the residential facilities during the observation period. The visitors will be asked to stay put at the houses as a precautionary measure to avoid the spread of coronavirus.“The PMC has zeroed in on 10 municipal facilities, including halls and residential flats that are in the possession of the civic administration. The civic body will check the demand and increase the number of properties that can be converted into quarantine facilities,” said Rajendra Muthe, head of PMC’s land and estate department.Muthe added that the vacant properties are maintained and made useful for residence. Beds and other facilities will be provided at these places so that suspected patients and international travellers can be shifted here.Civic officials also plan to approach private property owners if the need arises. Currently, however, the demand has been fulfilled by civic properties. The municipal hospital at Rajyog Society and a municipal building near Sanas Ground has been equipped with medical facilities as well as beds. Nearly 200 citizens can be accommodated here for observation.PMC has already roped in private hospitals for augmentation of the observation facility for coronavirus. Quarantine rooms, ICUs and screening facilities have been set up at the hospitals.“The quarantine and screening facility have been set up at Naidu hospital, where 100 citizens can be quarantined. We have also made arrangement at civic properties. If the number increases, they will be shifted to these rooms,” said a senior official of PMC’s health department.The decision of sending every foreign tourist visiting Pune into quarantine has not been taken as yet.

Title: Pune: Isolation wards for coronavirus patients in Command hospitals
Content: PUNE: The Southern Command has established two isolation wards for screening and providing emergency medical care to suspected coronavirus patients.The facilities have been created at the Military Hospital Khadki and Military Hospital-Cardio Thoracic Centre. “The move has been taken after issuing a series of directives from the Army headquarters a few days ago in the wake of rising cases of coronavirus in the country. The isolation wards will be utilized for screening of symptomatic cases to prevent transmission. The hospitals will work in tandem with local medical authorities and the designated Indian Council of Medical Research laboratories,” a senior Army officer, who did not wish to be named, told TOI on Tuesday.Moreover, regular health education and counselling activities are being carried out at all military stations.“We have told our personnel to utilize the shopping complex facilities within the stations and cantonments as precautionary measures. They have been told to avoid crowded areas like shopping malls and movie halls,” the officer said.

Title: After 15 years, trial begins in Shyamal Mandal murder case
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The trial of the accused in the sensational murder case of BTech student Shyamal Mandal commenced before the CBI special court here on Tuesday, almost 15 years after the alleged crime was committed. Mohammed Ali hailing from Andaman and Nicobar Islands is the accused.

The case pertains to the abduction and murder of Mandal, who was a student of College of Engineering Trivandrum at Sreekaryam in October 2005. He was also a resident of Andaman and Nicobar Islands. Besides Ali, there is one more accused in the case, Durga Jeg Bahadur from Nepal. He remains an absconder to this date.

The trial commenced on Tuesday by examining Mandal’s 75-year-old father Basudev Mandal. He identified the accused Ali as the one who had contacted him on phone demanding ransom of Rs 10 lakh to spare his son’s life. Mandal also identified the mobile phone of his son that was recovered from the accused following their arrests.

On October 13, 2005, Mandal was abducted by Ali with the help of his accomplice Bahadur. They called Mandal on his phone pretending as a friend from Andaman and Nicobar Islands and then abducted him. In the following days, they contacted Basudev over phone and demanded a ransom of Rs 10 lakh, which the latter deposited in a bank account as per the directions of the accused. But, on October 24, 2005, Mandal’s body was found in a sack abandoned among bushes near Kovalam. He was apparently killed by his throat slit.

The case was initially probed by the local police. In 2008, it was handed over to the CBI. The CBI investigators tracked down and arrested Ali by probing the transactions of the bank account in which the ransom amount was deposited. They also arrested another man, Kesav Kumar Katwal. Katwal was arrested after the investigators found Mandal’s phone in his possession. Later, it was revealed that he was innocent, and he bought the phone from Ali unaware of the crime.

The prosecution case is that Ali planned and executed the crime to extract money from Basudev. Ali knew that Basudev, despite being a school teacher, was into the business of moneylending and had huge amounts of money with him.

The chargesheet in the case was filed in the year 2010. The trial got delayed after it was transferred from CBI court in Kochi to the CBI special court in Thiruvananthapuram, which was established in 2012.

Title: 2-day mela for tree growers begins
Content:
Coimbatore: The two-day mela for tree growers got underway at the Institute of Forest Genetics and Tree Breeding here on Tuesday. On display are high yielding varieties of fast growing trees like teak, casuarina, eucalyptus and tamarind. Latest farming techniques and other forestry products like biofertilizers, growth boosters are also on display.

The mela, organized along with the state forest department, showcases high yielding varieties developed by the IFGTB and other varieties like kadamba and bamboos that the institiute is working on.

“We are also exhibiting various concepts of plantation technology, availability of improved clones, pest and disease management techniques and marketability of major identified species through interactive seminars & exhibition,” said a scientist. The mela has also called on a few successful tree growers to share experiences.

The focus of the seminar was on timber, with a special session on timber marketing and trade featuring in the schedule. “The sessions will focus on the need for choosing appropriate tree species, improved planting and clonal materials, package of practices for increased production and higher financial returns and possibilities of better wood marketing,” said a statement from the institute.

Besides several tree growers from the western region, representatives of wood-based industries like Tamilnadu News Print and Papers Ltd (TNPL), Sharon Plywood Industries, Century Plywood, KVK MYRADA, Gobichettipalayam, Vanam India Foundation, Palladam, VETRY, Tirupur and private nurseries are participating in the event.

Title: Leading electronics dealer directed to pay Rs 20K to consumer
Content:
Madurai: The district consumer grievances redressal forum in Tirunelveli has directed Vasanth & Co, a leading dealer of consumer electronics and home appliances across the state, to pay Rs 20,078 to a consumer, for deficiency in service. The firm was accused of charging Rs 78 for a gift bag that bears a big picture of the firm’s owner along with advertisements for the firm on either side.

Counsel A Brammah who appeared for T Narayanan, 75, of Maharaja Nagar in Tirunelveli city, said that his client purchased an LED TV and a stabiliser for Rs 29,500 at the Palayamkottai branch of the store on April 29, 2018.

The consumer was assured a small travel bag as gift for the purchase but the bill had a price tag of Rs 78.12. Annoyed with the billing for a gift bag that had the advertisement of the shop, the customer approached the store manager where he was humiliated by the staff. They also asked him to donate the bag if he was not interested, after which he contacted the office of the owner of the chain, but in vain.

Narayanan approached the forum in July 2018. On completion of the trial, the forum president F Devadas and members M Muthulakshmi and S Sivanmoorthi on Monday gave the direction to the dealer.

This included refund of Rs 78 charged for the bag, Rs 15,000 for mental agony caused to the consumer and Rs 5,000 towards legal expenses incurred for the case. On failing to make the payment within one month, an interest of 6% has to be paid, the forum said.

Title: Coronavirus Pune: Three Sinhagad road schools play it safe, will stay shut till Saturday
Content: Pune: Three schools in and around Sinhagad Road have decided to stay shut till March 14 as a precautionary measure against coronavirus spread. Those staying open have urged students with flu-like symptoms to stay at home.The management of Vidya Pratishthan Nanded City Public School and Pawar Public School, both in Nanded City, sent out a message to students’ parents on Tuesday evening, saying, “The school would remain closed from March 11-14. Further notification will be sent out on March 14.” The DSK School in Dhayari also issued a notification, stating that it would remain closed till March 14.Other schools, including pre-primary and day-care centres, confirmed of receiving panic calls from parents. Shubhada Paknikar, owner of a pre-school, said, “We were flooded with calls from parents on Tuesday. We have informed all the parents to send their children to school if they are fit and fine. The students showing flu-like symptoms should be kept at home.”The Bishop’s School, in a precautionary notice to all the parents, said if any student was found suffering from cough, cold, runny nose and fever, their parents would be called to school to collect the child. The school has also instructed children to wear N-95 masks for the time being and carry a personal alcohol-based sanitiser to school. Besides, the school has also suspended the sale of ice cream or cold drinks on its premises.The Mansukhbhai Kothari National School also issued a general notification to parents and advised children not to share utensils, water bottles and towels. The Sanskriti School issued an e-mail to parents, advising students to avoid handshakes and instead do “namaste” to greet each other.Masks not compulsory for students: Education deptThe state education department on Monday clarified that wearing of masks was not compulsory at schools. The clarification followed after the department received letters from parents stating that schools were making their wards wear masks on a mandatory basis. Commissioner of education Vishal Solanki, said, “Schools should not make wearing masks must for students.”

Title: New passenger-cum-tourist boat service launched in Alp
Content:
Alappuzha: PWD minister G Sudhakaran has said the state government is executing development projects of Rs 10,000 crore in the district.

The minister was speaking after launching the passenger-cum-tourist boat service of the state water transport department (SWTD) in Alappuzha on Tuesday.

“This boat will help the people to enjoy the beauty of Kuttanad . It will be a major attraction to tourists arriving at Alappuzha and Kumarakom,” he said.

Sudhakaran said that the state government would construct a new headquarters building of SWTD at Alappuzha and fund has been allocated under KIIFB. The minister also said that to increase the travelling water facilities, the department kicked off steps to launch water taxi and water bus services.

SWTD director Shaji V Nair said that the twin engine catamaran type boat would have a total of 120 seats. “Of it, 40 seats are in AC section. The boat will operate regular passenger services connecting Kottayam and Alappuzha. After that the boat will hold conducted tours,” he said.
