Such bonds issued by other banks are witnessing a price slide, which is expected to continue, bond players said.

Title: Mumbai: No bail for 'wife-swapper' businessman three months after arrest
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Three months after a 46-year-old city-based businessman was arrested for indulging in "wife-swapping" and allowing three of his friends to rape his 39-year-old wife on different occasions, a sessions court has rejected the businessman's bail plea. The court observed that it appeared that the businessman had used his wife to fulfil his fantasies and made her a victim of his lust in ways that no ordinary husband would have.

Referring to the woman's allegations, the court said that these things show it was the husband had initially made his wife watch porn videos and then made her have sex with two of the other accused. "Later, he appears to have made her keep relations with Tarun [name changed]," the court said.

The woman had opposed the man's bail plea through her lawyers Swapana Kode and Shruti Mundargi. Kode also explained that the FIR was lodged more than two years after the first alleged incident in 2017 as the woman was not in the right mental frame. She said that after the woman lodged the complaint, the police sat over it.

The court refuted the man's defence that his wife had chosen to be with other men as she was dissatisfied with him. It observed that in comparison to a woman, the man's nature is generally more aggressive, particularly in respect to sexual equations. "If the wife is not satisfied with her husband, as alleged by him, she could have chosen her secret way to satisfy herself and could not have told her husband to find another man for her," the court said.

The court found that he had even made a video of her and accused Tarun's relations. "This shows that either it was the fantasy of the husband to satisfy his lust or it was a tact to keep the wife under pressure. Had it been only her wish and he had consented to do so, he could not have taken their video," the court said.

The court also rejected Tarun's bail plea. On Monday, one of the two absconding accused was arrested.

The FIR filed in December said he indulged in swapping wives with his friends.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Teacher gets six years' rigorous imprisonment for sexual abuse of nine-year-old
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: A special Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) court on Monday convicted and sentenced a 49-year-old maulvi (religious teacher) to six years' rigorous imprisonment for sexually abusing his 9-year-old student several times over a month in 2018.

The matter came to light when the child confided in her classmates. The children got together and wrote a letter to their class teacher about how he was attacking the survivor. During a school meeting, a teacher informed the child's mother. Special public prosecutor Geeta Sharma said among those who deposed were the child, her friend, teacher and mother. The mother told the court that after the teacher informed her on March 28, 2018, her husband and she confronted the accused. The child had identified him from among three teachers present.

An FIR was lodged and the accused was arrested . The accused claimed that he was falsely implicated as there was a dispute between the child's parents and him over her studies. The court had rejected his bail pleas. The accused was also fined Rs 15,000, which will be given to the survivor as compensation.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Thane man bites off bus driver's ear
Content:
Representative image

THANE: A water valve operator from Thane allegedly bit off a private bus driver's ear on Tuesday, when the latter refused to give him a tip for Holi.

The accused, Someshwar Paphal, and his accomplice, Pankaj Ingle, were arrested, and the victim, Arvind Giri (28), admitted in hospital. Chitalsar police said the two operators clean parked buses in Gandhi Nagar locality.

Title: Global contagion sinks Kolkata foreign exchange business
Content: KOLKATA: Foreign exchange trade in Kolkata has come to a grinding halt with the coronavirus outbreak prompting widespread travel bans and cancellation of international flights. There is little or almost no demand for the US dollar, euro, Thai baht and UK pound and units registering minor transactions have made use of sanitizers mandatory for those handling currency and are demanding to see the self-reporting forms issued to arriving flyers by the health ministry.The drop in sale of foreign currency is more than 90%, says Anil Punjabi, chairman of Travel Agents Federation (east) and director of Ares Travels that has been in the money-changing business for the past 15 years.“It has been 20 days since we have had any buyers. Indians and NRIs are also getting rid of foreign currency. Earlier, they would hold on to foreign currency but now, they don’t want to since they are unsure of the future,” said Punjabi.Debasish Dutt, director of the 133-year-old RN Dutt & Sons, says there has been very little trade in the past month. “In my career of 22 years, I have never seen such a slump in business. I will put the dip to 70%. We are registering insignificant number of queries from travellers and very little currency exchange is happening. Some are approaching us for encashment. Our front office people are using sanitizers to deal with such clients,” he said. Biswajit Dutta, vice president of Edix Cash, earlier known as Centrum Direct Limited, claimed there was “at least a 50% dip in business” at his outlet while Subir Kumar De, general manager of Vicky Tourism Private limited, said the drop was 70%“The number of people returning to Kolkata from abroad has gone down drastically. In the past 15 days, we have had no foreigners coming over to exchange currency. For regular customers with no known symptoms, we are exchanging currency only after they have shown us their self-reporting forms issued by the ministry of health and family welfare,” said De.Biswajit Das, zonal head east of Zenith Leisure Holidays Limited, said there are hardly any enquires for foreign exchange and his unit it only encashing currency from travellers who have returned to India before the outbreak. “Even in their cases, we have their departure tickets and are well aware of when they returned. Now, we are also advising people to use travel cards instead of currency,” said Das. To be on the safe side, the procured currency is also being stored kept in separate plastic packets. “Those who work at the counter have been told to maintain a minimum distance from the person who comes to exchange the currency,” Das added.Instead of procuring dollars, pounds and euros from travellers, most units are now relying on banks to get their stock of international currency. “We understand that the situation is tricky there as well. We are also hoping that the banks are providing us with old stock of currency,” said Vicky Tourism’s Subir Kumar De.

Title: hookah parlours: What ban? Behind the smokescreen, it’s Hookahbad
Content:
Behind the smokescreen, the hookah culture is alive and kicking

The Chakravuyha: How to go beyond the doors

‘Customers are selective about flavours and the type of coal used in the hookah pot’

Will come down heavily on offenders, smoke at illegal hookah bars at your own risk: Police

How hookah became illegal in city:

Police raid in illegal Hookah parlours in 2 years :

Male 40% Female 60% :

A ride up the elevator to an unmarked floor leads you to a dark alleyway. There’s not a soul in sight; no signboards or door numbers; no activity whatsoever. Soon, you see a thick cloud of smoke with an unmistakable sweet note of green apple wafting out from under a door, which is shut and has a heavy lock outside. There’s no sign of life, but if you strain your ears hard enough, you’ll hear the faint thump of music. Sounds like a scene from a horror film? No, it’s just a scene outside one of the many underground hookah bars in Hyderabad. Once you get through the door (that’s a skill in itself), it’s a completely different world inside. It takes a while for your eyes to get adjusted to the dim mood lighting, but once they do, it all becomes apparent. there are smoke pipes, colourful pots, sound of bubbling water and smoking hot coal — all assembled on tables. groups of people sit around, some puffing away while others eagerly await their turn. “Welcome to the best underground hookah bar in the city of Nawabs,” our host exclaims, laughing at our flummoxed faces.Underground hookah parlours have gained popularity ever since a blanket ban on smoking under the Prohibition of Smoking in Public Places Rules, 2008 and COTPA was imposed. As the rules became even more stringent after the amendment of the Prohibition of Smoking in Public Places Act, 2008 in July 2017 issued by Ministry of Health and Family Welfare that states that no tobacco products can be consumed in public places, serving hookah in cafes became illegal and warranted severe penalties. But in Hyderabad at least, hookah-loving youth have found a way to puff away. Though the city police have in the past conducted several raids on hookah joints in the city, they have, mysteriously, managed to thrive. “And that’s because the game has changed over the years,” say regulars. Today, hookah bars are inconspicuous; only loyal and regular customers whom the management trusts gain entry to these joints; strangers are not welcome unless introduced by a trusted, regular client —all this to avoid complications like raids and arrests,” says our source, who managed to get us an entry into a hidden hookah parlour right in the heart of Banjara Hills .Talking to Hyderabad Times, Inayat Khan, who works at another underground hookah bar in Jubliee Hills , says, “For the past eight years, we have had customers who often visit us for hookah. But in 2017, police asked us to stop serving hookah. Now, we are only allowed to serve food and beverages. Our regular customers (between the age group of 20-35), who used to smoke hookah kept calling us and demanding for it. So, we started serving hookah again, but on the sly. It’s restricted to our special customers only. To get inside our hookah bar, customers need to know the exact location. Once they arrive, we identify them and ascertain their identity with the help of cameras.”Just like the dens of drug lords and mafias in films, these cafes too are tricky to enter. Most of these joints, located on the top floor with an open roof. There is no sign board, no decoration, and usually no sign of life, so they go unnoticed by casual visitors. “The owners of these cafes also control the elevator, so an individual who isn’t a known customer can’t get access to their floor,” says a source from a Banjara Hills joint. If you choose to use the shady, under lit staircase to reach the floor, you will still be left high and dry, unless you know how to get in. “To an unsuspecting individual, the door looks locked from outside but one who knows, knows how to getbeyond the doors,” explains Amzad Ahmed, another worker at a hookah parlour. “Earlier, we had a code system where our clients had to knock hard thrice and then once, softly. But that became common knowledge, and everyone gained access so we had to scrap it. Now, we have a new system in place, which includes a CCTV camera in front of the main door so we can see who is entering. We also have the contact numbers of our regular customers and they usually call us once they are at the door. We check if they are the right people with the help of the monitor and only then we open the door.”‘Underground’ they may be, but all these places are spacious and can accommodate up to a 100 people easily. Surya Kiran, a 22-year-old student who’s a regular at a Punjagutta hookah bar, says, “I still remember the first time I was taken to this fancy hookah place. It looked so shady from outside. We had to access it via a dark stairwell that smelled musty. It was scary and if I wasn’t with friends, I’d have never ventured in. But once I got inside, I was amazed at how plush the place was. From starters to milkshakes, everything is served along with hookah. Now I hangout here quite often.” Vijay Anirudh, another college-goer adds, “The owners make the rules. If you have five friends and only two of them want to smoke hookah, one needs to order at least two hookah pots. But you can sit and chill here in peace,because these people are always alert and ready. If police is anywhere around, they hide all the pots immediately. These are quite organised that way.”After all the trouble they go through to gain entry, hookah connoisseurs are not about to settle for just about anything. They have specific demands about everything from flavour to the kind of charcoal, say cafe owners. grape, kiwi, orange, mint to strawberry flavour… you name it and these cafes have it. The coal is of two types — natural and regular. Amzad says, “Most people prefer natural coal as it lasts longer and gives a clean hit that does not interfere with the flavours. It is also assumed thatnatural coal doesn’t affect one’s health.” Though natural coal costs more, it seems people are ready to shell out the extra money. A hookah pot with natural coal starts from `1000 and goes upto `1400, depending on flavours chosen but hookah with regular coal costs `700. The youngsters always find a way to spend their time in these parlours. Ratan Raju, a city-based businessman says, “Three years ago , there were multiple hookah cafes attached to coffee shops in the city. There were close to 50 hookah places in Jubliee Hils and Banjara Hills alone. But after the implementation of the ban, the number has decreased drastically. My friends still visit a few private cafes which still serve hookah. All these places only allow you if you are their registered customer.”When contacted, Radhakishan Rao, DCP of City Task Force wing said, “In the last two years, we have filed 113 cases on individuals running hookah parlours. Not only in Jubilee and Banjara Hills, we also banned places in Madhapur, Kompally and few other areas in the old city. We are leaving no stone unturned in eliminating this hookah culture from the city.” Admitting that they are indeed aware of the underground hookah parlour scene, Rao added, “Organisers are running these cafes even after we have raided them. We have arrested the owners who are running these cafes in the past too and will do so again, if we find any such cafes in the city. Customers also beware. if anyone is found inside such cafes, they too will be detained immediately. We request the public to alert the police if they come across such illegal cafes. We guarantee that the identity of our informers will not be disclosed.”2 Years: .In July 2017, Hyderabad City Police announced a total ban of hookah parlours in the city as per the order issued by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare by amending the Prohibition of Smoking in Public Places Act, 2008113 Cases registered: According to Hyderabad police officials, a whopping 113 cases have been registered against hookah parlours, who have been operating illegally in the twin citiesAccording to those who run hookah establishments, the number of women who frequent underground hookah bars is marginally higher than men

Title: Trinamool plans to connect with old-timers ahead of civic elections
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Trinamool Congress has planned a unique public outreach programme after ‘Didi Ke Bolo’ and ‘Banglar Gorbo Mamata ’ to win back old-timers who have distanced themselves from the party. The exercise will begin on March 15 from ward 73, on the home turf of the chief minister’s Bhowanipore assembly seat where TMC trailed in the 2019 Lok Sabha polls.

The purpose is to activate TMC sympathisers and activists who have chosen to opt out of active politics. “There are many Trinamool activists who have become less active or inactive these days. They may have reservations about party functioning and also with the new entrants. I am not saying that old is gold and the entire fault lies with new-generation leaders. But we want to give these Trinamool old-timers a chance to pour out their hearts at a meeting scheduled at Jai Hind Hall on March 15,” Trinamool Bengal president Subrata Bakshi said on Tuesday.

Bakshi, prodded by Trinamool chief Mamata Banerjee , wants to take these disgruntled sympathisers along in the battle ahead. Trinamool seniors plan to hold such meetings across the city based on the experience of the March 15 meeting. The target is to reach as many as 10 lakh people in Kolkata.

Kolkata mayor Firhad Hakim, Trinamool councillor from ward 73 Ratan Malakar and councillor from Kolkata Port area Md Anwar were present at Tuesday’s informal discussion. Bakshi made no bones about the fact before the media that TMC lost 18 Lok Sabha seats mainly because of “organisational shortcomings”.

Bakshi, while elaborating on the programme, said: “We could not reach out to people at the desired level. Learning it from the Lok Sabha polls, we have taken up a slew of organisational programmes such as ‘Didi Ke Bolo’ and ‘Banglar Gorbo Mamata’ to plug this gap. As on date, we could connect with 36 lakh people in West Bengal. The programme on March 15 is part of the outreach programme.”

Trinamool seniors will also hold meetings with party organisers and inform them about the various welfare schemes of the Mamata Banerjee government, which they can inform people during these meetings.

“We have done many things in the Kolkata Municipal Corporation area and are still at work. Yet, we couldn’t get the support of a section despite our good work. We want to reach out to them and try to identify where we have failed,” the Trinamool Bengal president said.

Title: Ex-mayor Bikash is Left-Congress’ RS nominee for 5th seat from Bengal
Content:
File photo of Bikash Bhattacharya

KOLKATA: Left and Congress are fielding senior Calcutta high court lawyer and former mayor Bikash Bhattacharya for the fifth Rajya Sabha seat from Bengal, CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury said in Delhi on Tuesday.

Bhattacharya is likely to file his nomination on Thursday. “I will be filing my nomination on March 12 or 13,” he said.

Bhattacharya’s nomination as a Left-Congress joint candidate marks a departure from the past when Congress candidates, namely Abhishek Manu Singhvi and Pradip Bhattacharya , made it to Upper House with the support of Trinamool Congress. Congress’s hand-holding with Left in fielding Bhattacharya for the RS seat is likely to firm up the understanding between the two parties in the run-up to the 2021 assembly polls.

Bhattacharya, primarily a CPM leader, has broken barriers over a host of issues from taking up the Saradha Ponzi scam in the Supreme Court to speaking in support of civil liberty and environment. The high court lawyer didn’t hesitate to move Congress leader Abdul Mannan’s petition against the Saradha scam and also joined issues with political leaders and members of civil society under the Save Democracy umbrella.

Bhattacharya had filed his nomination as a Left candidate for Rajya Sabha three years ago in 2017. But the Election Commission found gaps in his nomination paper and cancelled it. In 2019, he contested on the CPM symbol from the Jadavpur Lok Sabha seat, but lost to TMC’s Mimi Chakrabarty.

Going by MLA count, neither Congress nor Left has the strength to win the fifth Rajya Sabha seat from Bengal when the other four are likely to go with Trinamool. The Bengal assembly now has 293 elected members of the total 294, following the demise of a member. The quota for getting elected for each candidate is thus 49 in terms of first preferential votes. The first preferential votes of Congress and Left taken together is much more than the remaining first preferential votes of Trinamool after getting four of its candidates through.

Title: West Bengal: Dooars plays host to 100 vultures
Content:
A dead cow was lying on the tracks, drawing the vultures to the spot

ODLABARI (JALPAIGURI): Yet again, some 100 vultures were spotted in Dooars, bringing cheers to nature lovers and forest workers. The birds were seen at Jalpaiguri’s Mal along railway tracks on the banks of the river Ghish. Environmentalists and forest staff said vultures of the Himalayan Grifan species have been spotted in Odlabari located on the banks of the Ghish river.

Locals said a cow carcass was lying on railway tracks passing along the banks of the river. This carcass drew some 100 vultures to the spot, locals added. As news about the vultures spread, members of an Odlabari NGO and staff from the Chel and Targhera forest ranges rushed to the spot.

“It was a great sight to see,” said local environmentalist Nafzar Ali. Tamal Mukherjee, ranger of the Chel forest range said, “We went to the spot on hearing of the vultures. We took steps to remove the carcass of the cow from the railway tracks. We have a bad experience of several vultures being killed under the wheels of a train at Gulma. Those vultures too were similarly drawn to the spot by the carcass of a cow. We also requested authorities of Odlabari power station to switch off power supply to the overhead electric wires.”

Field director of the Rajabhatkhawa Vulture centre Shyamma Chowdhury said, “All these vultures belong to the Great Himalayan Grifan species. Staff from the Chel Range and the Mal Wildlife Squad have started monitoring the vultures’ movement there.”

If you have five friends and only two of them want to smoke hookah, one needs to order at least two hookah pots. But you can sit and chill here in peace,because these people are always alert and ready. If police is anywhere around, they hide all the pots immediately. These are quite organised that way.”After all the trouble they go through to gain entry, hookah connoisseurs are not about to settle for just about anything. They have specific demands about everything from flavour to the kind of charcoal, say cafe owners. grape, kiwi, orange, mint to strawberry flavour… you name it and these cafes have it. The coal is of two types — natural and regular. Amzad says, “Most people prefer natural coal as it lasts longer and gives a clean hit that does not interfere with the flavours. It is also assumed thatnatural coal doesn’t affect one’s health.” Though natural coal costs more, it seems people are ready to shell out the extra money. A hookah pot with natural coal starts from `1000 and goes upto `1400, depending on flavours chosen but hookah with regular coal costs `700. The youngsters always find a way to spend their time in these parlours. Ratan Raju, a city-based businessman says, “Three years ago , there were multiple hookah cafes attached to coffee shops in the city. There were close to 50 hookah places in Jubliee Hils and Banjara Hills alone. But after the implementation of the ban, the number has decreased drastically. My friends still visit a few private cafes which still serve hookah. All these places only allow you if you are their registered customer.”When contacted, Radhakishan Rao, DCP of City Task Force wing said, “In the last two years, we have filed 113 cases on individuals running hookah parlours. Not only in Jubilee and Banjara Hills, we also banned places in Madhapur, Kompally and few other areas in the old city. We are leaving no stone unturned in eliminating this hookah culture from the city.” Admitting that they are indeed aware of the underground hookah parlour scene, Rao added, “Organisers are running these cafes even after we have raided them. We have arrested the owners who are running these cafes in the past too and will do so again, if we find any such cafes in the city. Customers also beware. if anyone is found inside such cafes, they too will be detained immediately. We request the public to alert the police if they come across such illegal cafes. We guarantee that the identity of our informers will not be disclosed.”2 Years: .In July 2017, Hyderabad City Police announced a total ban of hookah parlours in the city as per the order issued by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare by amending the Prohibition of Smoking in Public Places Act, 2008113 Cases registered: According to Hyderabad police officials, a whopping 113 cases have been registered against hookah parlours, who have been operating illegally in the twin citiesAccording to those who run hookah establishments, the number of women who frequent underground hookah bars is marginally higher than men

Title: Coronavirus Cases in Bangalore: Bengaluru reports three fresh coronavirus cases; infected techie's wife, daughter test positive
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

BENGALURU: Three more cases of Covid-19 infections from Bengaluru were confirmed on Tuesday, taking the total in the state to four.

The new cases include the 47-year-old wife and 13-year-old daughter of Karnataka's first positive case, a software engineer from Dell. The girl is Karnataka's first paediatric case. Unlike the techie who had returned from the United States, his wife and daughter had no travel history to any country.

The state's fourth patient is a 50-year-old software engineer of Mindtree who returned to Bengaluru from the US via London on March 8. He reported at Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases (RGICD) on Monday.

Including his wife and daughter, 12 persons who were in contact with the Mindtree techie are under observation. None of them has been admitted to the hospital.

All the four confirmed patients are now in the isolation ward at RGICD and their condition is said to be stable.

A colleague of the Dell techie who had travelled with him from the United States and was admitted to RGICD has tested negative for the infection. In all, 2,666 primary and secondary contacts of the techie's family are on the health and family welfare department's radar.

Meanwhile, a 24-year-old engineer, the first Covid-19 case of Telangana who worked and lived in Bengaluru, has recovered, a minister said.

According to a media release from the health and family welfare department on Tuesday, 25 samples came negative for Covid-19. Fourteen more samples of suspected patients have been taken for testing, said medical education minister Dr K Sudhakar.

Currently, there are nine patients admitted to hospitals across the state: Four confirmed and two suspected cases at RGICD, one each in Dakshina Kannada, Bagalkot and Hassan hospitals.

Till date, 95,151 passengers have been screened in at KIA airport, Mangaluru airport and seaports of Mangaluru and Karwar.

Title: Karnataka: Former speaker, medical education minister trade slurs in house
Content:
Former speaker KR Ramesh Kumar

BENGALURU: In an expletive-laden faceoff in the legislative assembly , former speaker KR Ramesh Kumar and medical education minister K Sudhakar locked horns on Tuesday with both abusing each other in unparliamentary language.

The war of words between the two started when Sudhakar accused the speaker's chair - then occupied by Kumar - of meting out injustice to him and 16 other MLAs, who switched sides from Congress and JD(S) to BJP. He was referring to Kumar's decision to disqualify them.

Kumar took strong objection when Sudhakar began reading out the Supreme Court's observations on the speaker's role while upholding their disqualification.

Former speaker threatens to quit after fracas

When members of the treasury bench, including Sudhakar, tried to shout him down, Kumar protested, resulting in a war of words.

"This chair meted out injustice to us. Our political career would have been over. A conspiracy was hatched to finish us off politically," Sudhakar said.

When Sudhakar persisted on discussing the issue, Kumar sought the intervention of law and parliamentary affairs minister JC Madhuswamy. "Will (Madhuswamy) you approve your minister's conduct? Will you allow a discussion on the speaker's decision and subsequent SC judgement," Kumar asked.

When Madhuswamy did not react, Kumar lost his cool and rushed to the well of the house. Both Sudhakhar and Kumar used unparliamentary words against each other and addressed each other in the singular. Ministers Ramesh Jarkiholi, Anand Singh and Shivaram Hebbar, who were also disqualified by Kumar, rushed to the support of Sudhakar. "We need to debate this issue and expose the conspiracy behind our disqualification," Jarkiholi said.

The house descended into pandemonium with members on both sides shouting at the other. "If this is the kind of debate and language being used in the house, I don't want to continue as a member. I will quit," Kumar said and left the house.

As allegations and counter-allegations flew, Congress MLA Shivanand Patil, who was in the chair, adjourned the house for 15 minutes. But the pandemonium continued when the house reconvened. Opposition leader Siddaramaiah sought to move a privilege motion against Sudhakar, while ruling party MLAs demanded Kumar's suspension. As both sides stuck to their demands, the house was adjourned for the day.

Siddaramaiah told reporters that Sudhakar's remark against Kumar was uncalled for and it amounts to breach of privilege of the house. "We will press for a privilege motion on Wednesday," he said, denying Kumar used unparliamentary words against Sudhakar. The minister said he, too, would move a privilege motion against Kumar.

Title: Beary to be third language in Karnataka schools?
Content:
Representative image

MANGALURU: Beary is set to be introduced as an optional third language across state schools from the 2020-21 academic year. The Karnataka Beary Sahitya Academy is in the process of creating a textbook for students of Class 6, which will be vetted by state authorities.

Beary, which traces it origins 1,200 years ago to Muslim traders, combines Malayalam and Tulu with a strong Arabic influence. Written in the Kannada script, the language has snatches of Kannada and Tamil as well. It is the second most spoken language after Tulu in Dakshina Kannada; the Muslim Byari community makes up an estimated 80% of Tulu Nadu's Muslim population.

Committee working on Beary text

"It is our aim to introduce Beary language for students of Class 6 to start with from the coming academic year and we will work towards that," Karnataka Beary Sahitya Academy president Rahim Uchil told mediapersons on Tuesday. A 13-member committee is drawing up the contents of the textbook which will be further scrutinised by a five-member panel. The Department of State Educational Research and Training (DSERT) will then finalise the textbook. Textbook committee members Poornima, Hamza Malar and Flora Castelino were present at the meet.

The academy will work with DSERT to train teachers to teach the language in Kannada script. "Beary can be learnt by a student who knows Kannada and taught by Kannada teachers. Members of Moya and Thiya community and those speaking Malame, a sub-Beary language, can now learn it in a formal academic set-up," Uchil said. The textbook has completed the groundwork for the contents, he said, which includes topics such as communal amity in Manjeshwar and the life of Padma Shri awardee Harekala Hajabba.

Title: Students from Telangana, Andhra Pradesh stranded in Italy
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: Hundreds of Telugu students from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana are stranded in Italy as the Mediterranean country went into lockdown to tackle the sudden surge in Covid-19 cases. The students are in places such as Padova, Rimini, Modena, Milan — all declared red zones for the virus. With Italy registering 97 deaths on March 9, more government restrictions, especially in travelling and movement, have been placed from Tuesday.The students are a worried lot given the shortage of masks and restricted entry at supermarkets. From Tuesday, the Italian government has also asked everyone to confine themselves at home while shutting down all public places.Few Telugu students told TOI that hospitals were reluctant to give ‘fit’ certificates and there was no provision to check those without symptoms, making it even more difficult for them to return. Sources said that Indian embassy authorities too are insisting on fit certificates to be considered for evacuation.Badarinath Gella from Kodad in Suryapet district of Telangana has just completed his engineering degree from the 931-year-old University of Bologna. Speaking to TOI from Italy, he said, “Over 30 of us are stranded here. It is difficult to get medical fitness certificate here, because we do not have symptoms.”

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: As panic sends prices crashing, farmer buries 6,000 chickens alive
Content:
TOI

BELAGAVI: With Covid-19 leading to a steep fall in chicken prices over unfounded fears of transmission, a desperate poultry farmer in Gokak buried alive a truckload of chickens on his farm, saying he was facing massive losses. He shot a video of the gruesome burial which has gone viral, and ironically, is being passed off as culling to prevent the spread of coronavirus Najeer Ahmed Makandar loaded nearly 6,000 chickens, all about a month old, onto a truck and dumped the live birds into a large pit at Nulsoor in Belagavi ’s Gokak taluk on Monday. “I was left with no option,” the 47-year-old told. “I have spent nearly Rs 6 lakh to rear these birds. Their food and medicine cost a lot.” Chickens are sold when they are between 42 and 45 days old.“Before the coronavirus scare , live chicken was selling at Rs 50-70 a kilo which was profitable. The prevailing price is Rs 5 to 10. A live chicken weighs up to 2.5kg which would give me a maximum of Rs 25 for a bird. I cannot sell at such a loss, nor can I maintain the birds,” he said. Makandar went on to shoot a video to make consumers aware of the plight of farmers but it is now fuelling rumours of culling over the virus scare.Sources in the poultry industry said several farmers were staring at huge losses after investing lakhs of rupees as the demand has been plunging for a month following panic over Covid-19, which has not showed any link to fowl so far. Farmers in Belagavi, which contributes nearly 10% of chickens in the state, have taken a major hit, the sources said.The input cost for producing a kg of chicken is about Rs 75. “Imagine the plight of farmers who are forced to sell birds for Rs 5 and Rs 10 a kilo. If this situation continues, many farmers may have to look for another livelihood,” said an industry expert.Madhukar Pawar, general manager of Quality Animal Feeds Private Limited, said Belagavi produces 60,000kg to 80,000kg of chickens every month and the loss is massive. “Chickens are being sold at Rs 5 and many live chicken trading companies are unable to pay farmers. My company has 1,500 employees and more than 1,000 farmers are dependent on us. This month we have managed to pay them but it will be difficult from next month,” Pawar said.Paward added that while his company used to sell 30 lakh kg of live chicken every month, the figure has halved now. “While farmers are suffering, meat traders are still selling chicken at Rs 70 to 120.”

Title: Bangalore Coronavirus: Dell techie quarantined, others told to work from home
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

BENGALURU: The software engineer from Bengaluru who tested positive for Covid-19 is employed with Dell.

The technology giant said the employee — who was returning from a business trip in the US and is under medical supervision —has been quarantined and will not return to work until cleared by medical officials. “Our leadership team is in close contact with the team member...,” Alok Ohrie, president and managing director of Dell Technologies India, said in an internal communication to the staff.

Preventive measures

“Nothing is more important than the health and safety of our employees and communities where we operate. Two employees of Dell India were tested for Covid-19 following their return from the US — including a visit to our headquarters in Round Rock, Texas. One employee tested negative, while another tested positive and has since been placed in quarantine. We continue to take measures to protect Dell Technologies team members and communities by following the health and safety guidelines from World Health Organization and Centers for Disease Control, and coordinating with local health officials,” the company said in a statement.

Ohrie also said other employees in the facility where the affected employee is working have been asked to work from home till March

24. “This will reduce the number of employees coming to office, helping ensure that team members who must be on site can do so more safely,” the email to the firm's employees said.

Title: BJP’s poll body meets to select RS candidates
Content:
The BJP central election committee on Tuesday deliberated on the party’s candidates for the March 26 Rajya Sabha polls in some states.

The committee, which includes Prime Minister Narendra Modi, met under the chairmanship of BJP president J P Nadda.

Sources said the party may announce the names of its candidates on Wednesday. Elections to 55 Rajya Sabha seats falling vacant in April will be held on March 26, the Election Commission has announced. March 13 is the last date for filing nominations.

The meeting was held on a day Jyotiraditya Scindia resigned from the Congress after meeting Union Home Minister Amit Shah and Prime Minister Modi.

Scindia, along with his supporters, is expected to join the BJP and may get a Rajya Sabha ticket from Madhya Pradesh, where election will be held on three seats.

Fifty-one of these 55 seats from 17 states are falling vacant on different dates in April due to retirement of sitting members, while the rest are already vacant due to resignation of members.

The terms of the members who had resigned in the recent past were also ending in April.

Counting will be held on the evening of March 26, an hour after the conclusion of polls.

Title: After 34 yrs of armed struggle, NDFB finally disbands itself
Content:
Bodo tribals attend an event to celebrate signing of a peace accord with the Bodo rebel group NDFB, earlier th... Read More

Thirty-four years since it was formed, the National Democratic Front of Boroland ( NDFB ) finally disbanded itself at two different locations in the last 24 hours. This was done in accordance with a clause in the memorandum of settlement (MoS) signed by the outfit’s four factions and other Bodo stakeholders with the government on January 27.

The outfit, which became one the biggest and deadliest militant outfits in the NE region, is the third such armed group and the second one in Assam to have disbanded itself after signing a peace deal. Mizo National Army — the armed wing of Mizo National Front (MNF) — was disbanded after the signing of the Mizo Accord four decades ago. In 2002, Bodo Liberation Tigers (BLT) ceased to exist after signing the second Bodo Accord.

On January 27, the four NDFB factions set aside their differences and unanimously resolved to unite for implementing all the clauses of the accord. While three NDFB factions — Saoraigwra, Ranjan Daimari and Dhiren Boro — declared the end of NDFB at Udalguri on Monday, the fourth one, NDFB (Progressive) led by Gobinda Basumatry, announced its disbanding at a ceremonial function at Serfanguri on Tuesday.

“To find a solution to the political, economic, social and cultural issues of the Bodo people, the Bodo Security Force was formed in 1986. It was renamed as NDFB in 1994. Our fight has finally come to an end after 34 years of armed struggle from within and outside the country… from Nepal, Bangladesh, Myanmar and Bhutan. We believe that the NDFB movement has been a successful one and so we are disbanding the group,” NDFB (P) leader Gobinda Basumatry said.

Title: Kolkata: Cops book 336 bikers on Dol, Bansdroni sees most arrests
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The city police took action against 336 bikers on Monday by setting up over 700 pickets across the city. In a bid to rein in errant bikers on Dol and Holi, cops carried out special drives across the city to nab the offenders.

But the most problematic zone was the south suburban Kolkata. In almost a repeat of Diwali arrests for the past two years, the maximum number of disorderly conduct arrests came from this region with cops arresting 129 people from the area.

The most important stretch of the crackdown was between Naktala and Garia, the naka on Boral Main Road yielded 20 punitive actions. Most of them were riding helmetless and had more than two people on their bike.

On Holi, cops carried out another 117 arrests, with north division arresting 52 people, which was the highest, followed by central and south suburban police divisions.

Areas in central Kolkata such as Entally, Posta and Burrabazar, too, had large number of offenders. The area witnessed punitive action against 20-25 bikers at Ananda Palit Road-Sunari Mohan Avenue crossing, Kalakar Street-Hariram Goenka Street and CR Avenue-Ganesh Chandra Avenue crossing. Shyambazar and Karunamoyee bridge at Putiyari, however, witnessed seven and five prosecutions respectively.

All FIRs were registered under the Motor Vehicles Act. Merely eight bikers and motorists were found riding under the influence of alcohol unlike 39 last year. However, 217 were caught for not using helmets and 79 were hauled up since their pillion riders did not wear helmets.

Cops said that among the worst affected stretches were Entally, Bansdroni, Bowbazar besides Burtolla (that witnessed a culpable homicide) and Ekbalpore.

Police added that specific trouble spots are identified each year and cops are instructed to carry out checks in at least three points in each of the traffic guards, up from only one on a normal working day or two on a raid day. “We had instructed our men to focus on the job, despite jibes and even veiled threats. We did not even spare locals,” said an officer.

“People driving drunk has now become all too common and hence we changed our strategy this year round and checked every youth on a bike or car. All local police stations worked in tandem to provide us the necessary back-up. In the Howrah Bridge and Jorabagan traffic guards alone, we have recorded 85 cases of drunk driving this Holi month. Till last year, it was less than 25,” said an officer at Lalbazar.

Title: GRP strives to make train ride safer on Park Circus stretch in Kolkata
Content:
A liquor den near Park Circus station being destroyed

KOLKATA: Alarmed by back-to-back attacks on women on a 4-km train route between Sealdah and Park Circus—the latest one being flagged by a woman journalist on Monday —senior officers at Sealdah and Ballygunge GRP on Tuesday launched a joint drive against trouble-mongers living by the tracks.

On the very first day, around 12 people were detained and an illicit liquor den was destroyed. “This is going to be a sustained drive . We have formed a team, comprising officers from Sealdah and Ballygunge GRP, who will work in coordination with RPF and cops from the local police station to stop crime against women and check criminal activities in this part,” said Badana Varun Chandrasekhar , SRP, Sealdah.

A young journalist posted on Facebook on Monday that while she was returning home on a Diamond Harbour-bound train from Sealdah, someone threw a plastic packet, apparently filled with urine and a stone, at her even as the train pulled out of Park Circus station. The woman, who was sitting by the window, said she got drenched and the stone barely missed her head. “Post evening, people target ladies compartments with stones and plastics carrying filth. What if someone throws acid someday? Who will take that responsibility?” she wrote in a social media post around 7.45pm on Monday. She also posted a photo of her drenched face.

Barely two weeks ago, a woman from Ranaghat claimed she was pushed off a moving train between Park Circus and Sealdah stations on the evening of Saraswati Puja, when she had protested against a man accosting her in the near-empty coach. Another woman complained an assailant had tried to snatch her daughter’s gold chain on the same route the same evening and when she protested, he had punched and slapped the daughter before snatching away the gold chain.

Cops said they have arrested three men in the snatching incident and recovered the gold chain but the assailant who had pushed the young woman off a moving train was yet to be identified.

On Tuesday, TOI took a walk along the tracks between Park Circus and Sealdah and then took a train ride from Sealdah to Ballygunge to find people drinking by the tracks and liquor dens being operated near Park Circus station. Woman daily commuters said on this stretch, they shut windows in fear of being attacked from outside and sat in groups so that they would be able to fight criminals, who often jumped into their compartment.

Although cops said they had intensified policing, passengers claimed otherwise. “Most days, there is no guard on trains,” said Sunita Halder, who commutes between Sealdah and Subhasgram.

Title: Bihar man killed in Kolkata on festival day for ‘protesting against drinking’
Content:
The spot in Sovabazar where the assault took place

KOLKATA: An argument on the evening of Dol led to the death of a 35-year-old man who had come to Kolkata from Bihar searching for a better prospect. The incident took place on Monday night in Sovabazar following which cops from the Burtolla police station have arrested two persons on the charges of culpable homicide not amounting to murder and serious hurt.Police denied that the incident had any link with Dol, but locals said the victim, Pramod Shaw, had protested against some youths, allegedly involved in a parking syndicate, making obscene comments and drinking in the open during the celebrations.The Burtolla police station received an information around 8.30pm on Monday that one person was lying on the pavement in front of Aurobindo Sarani. “We reached the spot and took Shaw to RG Kar Hospital, where he was declared dead. An inquiry revealed an argument had broken out between Avishek Gupta (28) and Jibon Debnath alias Sanu (32), both residents of the area. As the altercation continued, Shaw tried to intervene. At some point, the argument snowballed into a fight and both Gupta as well as Debnath it Shaw, who fell on the edge of a raised structure on the pavement. Shaw sustained severe cuts and bleeding injuries on his throat that led to his death,” said joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma. “The relevant pieces of evidence were collected, witnesses examined and accused—Gupta and Debnath—were arrested.”The residents of the area TOI spoke to, however, presented a different version. According to Ranjit Shaw, a local, Shaw had protested when he saw Debnath misbehaving with a woman passing by. Gupta joined Debnath and the two together assaulted him. They allegedly dragged Shaw into an adjoining room, where they assaulted him till he fell unconscious. There were several marks of the victim being hit with a sharp and penetrating object, claimed Ranjit.The family of the accused, however, denied all the claims. They said Shaw, too, was drunk and got involved in an argument with Gupta and Debnath. They claimed Shaw pushed Debnath away but he himself fell down and injured himself fatally.Shaw, who is engaged in producing stitched bags, had come from Begusarai in Bihar to Kolkata almost three decades ago but he would often visit his hometown. He had married about a decade ago and his wife and eight-year-old daughter live in Bihar. “The accused has a major stake in the local parking syndicate. The police know about several instances, when they had threatened people. The two also flaunt their political connections,” Ranjit claimed.The local councillor, Sunanda Sarkar, said even she was aware of the background of the two accused and how they made trouble in the area. The political connections they flaunted, claimed the councillor, were all fake and fabricated to suit their needs.

Title: Blind Kerala student writes class X exam using laptop
Content:
An invigilator reads out questions to Haroon Kareem T K during his SSLC examination using computer on Tuesday

MALAPPURAM: When Haroon Karim T K , a blind Class X student of GVHSS Mankada in the district wrote SSLC examination using a laptop on Tuesday, it created a history. It is for the first time that a student used a laptop for writing public examination in the state.

Haroon used laptop for writing Malayalam Paper 1 examination with a special permission from the general education department. A separate classroom was arranged for Haroon to write exam.

Haroon said it was comfortable for him to write examination using a laptop provided by school authorities. “The examination started at 9.45am. An invigilator, who is also an IT expert, supported me by reading out questions one after the other during 15-minute long cool off time and it helped me to be well-prepared to start typing answers, by 10am.

“I managed to finish the examination by 11.30am, without availing an additional time granted by the school authorities. The invigilator later took prints out my answer paper and attached them with the main sheet with register number and other details,” he said

Haroon used screen reader software to listen to the answers he wrote during the exam. He is planning to use infty editor software for typing signs and formulas for science and mathematics examinations.

Title: Death sentence: Calcutta HC cites ‘residual doubt’
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: In a first, Calcutta High Court on Friday cited “residual doubt”, which sets a higher standard of proof than normally acceptable by courts, to commute the death sentence to life of a 31-year-old Kandi resident for burning his wife and three minor daughters to death in May 2015.

First cited in a 2014 Supreme Court judgment, “residual doubt” was again mentioned as a reason in two judgments by the apex court in October 2019 to commute death sentences to life. In the 2014 verdict, the SC had defined it as “lingering or residual doubts in its mind” in spite of being convinced of the guilt of the accused beyond reasonable doubt. It had reasoned that since death is irreversible, this is also a safeguard against routine capital punishments by trial courts.

In a 21-page judgment, a division bench of justices Joymalya Bagchi and Suvra Ghosh at one point said, “These circumstances leave a lingering doubt whether the guilt of the appellant has been established with absolute certainty although one may have no doubt that the evidence on record is sufficient to uphold the conviction.” The HC said the prosecution has failed to establish that the possibility of reformation and rehabilitation of the convict is wholly ruled out. “Under such circumstances and in the light of lingering residual doubt vis a vis guilt of the appellant, it may not be prudent to confirm the death sentence imposed upon him,” the HC reasoned. The HC then commuted the death sentence to a life behind bars and made it clear that the convict will get no remission for three decades.

Police said Utsab Ali had married Nafija Bibi in 1998. They were initially happy but when Nafija gave birth to three daughters — Amina, Marshida and Tuhina — their relation turned sour and Nafija was mentally and physically tortured. On May 31, 2015, the bodies of Nafija and the couple’s three daughters, were found charred to death. Utsab was arrested later. Utsab had claimed that he was with a cousin that night. He, however, could not prove this “alibi”. A Murshidabad trial court in March 2018 sentenced Utsab to death.

The HC, while agreeing with the conviction order, faulted the probe for not doing forensic tests of seized articles, not questioning neighbours and inability to trace the woman with whom Utsab had illicit affair.

Title: Nadine Dorries: UK’s health minister contracts coronavirus
Content: LONDON: A senior health minister who is a key figure in the response to the coronavirus crisis in Britain has tested positive for the disease.Conservative MP Nadine Dorries is self-isolating after becoming the first MP to test positive for the virus. The parliamentary under-secretary of state for health and social care fell ill last friday, when ironically, she was signing a statutory instrument in relation to coronavirus. She took the test on Monday and revealed the results on Tuesday saying: “I can confirm I have tested positive for coronavirus. As soon as I was informed I took all advised precautions and have been self-isolating at home. Public Health England (PHE) has started detailed contact tracing and the department and my parliamentary office are closely following their advice."The health secretary Matt Hancock tweeted: “Really sorry to hear Nadine has tested positive for coronavirus. She has done the right thing by self isolating at home, and both NHS and PHE staff have been brilliant. We all wish her well as she recovers.”Dorries, a senior health minister who helped draw up the legislation to tackle the illness, has mixed with hundreds of MPs in Parliament and civil servants in the past week.Officials are now trying to identify all those with whom she has been in contact, meaning a whole host of people at the heart of the British government may have to self isolate.She also met 50 members of the public at a constituency surgery over the weekend and on Thursday night was at a reception in Downing Street for International Women’s Day with UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson.The 62-year-old tweeted late Tuesday: “Thanks for so many good wishes. It’s been pretty rubbish but I hope I’m over the worst of it now. More worried about my 84yo (sic) mum who is staying with me and began with the cough today. She is being tested tomorrow. Keep safe and keep washing those hands, everyone.”She is not the first health minister in the world to contract the virus. On 25 February, Iran's deputy health minister, Iraj Harirchi, said he had contracted coronavirus and placed himself in isolation, a day after appearing feverish at a press conference.By Tuesday evening the number of confirmed cases in Britain had risen to 382. The UK is expecting a sharp peak in cases in the coming weeks.Deputy chief medical officer for England Dr Jenny Harries said she expected significant increases in the number of cases in the UK beginning in about 10 to 14 days time at which time anyone with flu-like symptoms would be asked to self-isolate.The number of cases in Italy rocketed from hundreds to thousands in just a few weeks and Britain is expected to follow the same pattern. Hand sanitisers, liquid hand wash and toilet paper are virtually sold out across Britain with shelves lying empty as people panic buy and stockpile. Many general practitioners and hospitals are reporting these items are now being stolen from their premises. In one incident a hand sanitiser dispenser was ripped off the wall from a cancer ward at Northampton General Hospital and hospital staff are reporting they are also stolen from the end of patients’ beds.Some arcade owners in Britain have removed soft toys and are stocking grabber machines with toilet paper and sanitiser. Ho Barts Amusement Arcade in Devon has replaced Frozen and Peter Rabbit teddy bears with hand sanitiser and toilet rolls, whilst East Yorkshire arcade Bridlington's Chapmans Funland has filled its toy grabber machine with toilet rolls.

Title: Stimulus hopes pull oil prices up 7% after crash
Content: Oil prices jumped by more than 7% on Tuesday, bouncing from the biggest rout in nearly 30 years a day earlier, as the possibility of economic stimulus encouraged buying, and Russia signaled that it may yet hold talks with Opec about cooperation on output cuts.On Monday, US President Donald Trump pledged “major” steps to gird the US economy against the impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Japan’s government said it planned to spend more than $4 billion in a second package of steps to cope with the virus. Oil, which plunged about 25% on Monday, rebounded on Tuesday.Brent hit a session high of $38.22 a barrel. Technical traders noted that neither benchmark touched the previous session’s high and said the day’s bounce looked like prices were consolidating in a new lower range. “The oil price went up because it went insanely down yesterday, and some bargain hunters are driving things up,” said Bjoernar Tonhaugen, head of oil markets at energy consultant Rystad.

Title: Chennai Coronavirus: Faithful will greet with 'namaste', won't kiss Cross on Good Friday
Content:
Priests can suspend meetings

CHENNAI: For the first time in 20 years, Rosary Silviya will not be kissing the Cross at her Church on Good Friday. COVID-19, she's been told.Silviya and other members of her congregation were informed at church last Sunday that all parishes in the city have been asked to forego the traditional veneration this year due to the virus scare. "Instead we will be saying a quiet prayer," says the 23-year-old. "It will feel strange, but this is for our own safety and therefore we must accept it."On March7, a mail was circulated from the desk of the Archbishop of Madras and Mylapore to various diocese in Chennai with the subject: " Coronavirus ", mentioning guidelines to be followed until the Easter service on April 12."Our first faith response is to turn to God," said the letter addressed to parish priests . "I am recommending the following steps for the control of the virus."The letter instructs parish priests to encourage people not to shake hands at the sign of peace but to "greet each other with folded hands (namaste)". It also states that Holy Communion should be received in the hand and not the mouth as is the norm.“On Good Friday, at the Veneration of the Cross discourage people from kissing the Cross. The blessing with a raised Cross would be adequate. Those who desire, could come in a queue and make reverence with a bow,” says the letter. The priests have also been asked to “purify their hands in a bowl of water/sanitizer” before distribution of the Holy Communion. The Holy water stoups, which people dip their fingers in before entering church, will now be kept dry.The letter also mentions that if there is any indication that an individual in the community is infected, parish priests can temporarily suspend meetings.Priests are taking other precautions as well. At Luz Church, for instance, Father Peter Thumma is trying to cancel trips to the Holy Land, which are usually organized for the members of the parish in summer. Short trips during the Lenten period have also been called off. “This letter is issued in the interest of the parishioners,” says Father Thumma. “For a couple of weeks now in church we have been advising people on preventive measures. We’ve been telling them to eat a healthy diet, have some vitamin C, maintain hygiene, and wear masks if necessary. Better to be safe,” he says. Last Sunday, he adds, one member of the parish was spotted in a mask.

Title: Yes Bank News: Small lenders that cleared cheques via Yes Bank stuck
Content:
MUMBAI: Yes Bank ’s disconnect from various payments and fund transfer networks is affecting over 50 small banks, including cooperative, foreign and regional rural banks.

With the moratorium shutting Yes Bank from the cheque clearing and real time gross settlement (RTGS) systems, several other banks that depend on the troubled private lender are also shut out.

Yes Bank provides submember bank services to cooperative, private and foreign banks whose operations are too small to invest in a direct membership. The services include facilities such as RBI clearing house, RTGS, national electronic funds transfer (NEFT), the national financial switch (for ATMs).

Among the foreign banks that the troubled Yes Bank was servicing is Doha Bank. Several district central cooperative banks are also customers of Yes Bank.

The affected banks include 13 cooperative banks and regional rural banks in the northeast where banking penetration is relatively lower. Cheques of these banks cannot be presented for clearing as lenders have issued instructions that those that are sub-members of the clearing system through Yes Bank’s membership will not be able to get their cheques to clear.

“Yes Bank is unlike the small cooperative banks that have been regulatory placed under moratorium by the RBI. Besides being a large bank, it is also a financial services infrastructure provider for other banks,” said a banker.

Earlier this week, the fintech world was thrown into a disarray as many startups were blocked form UPI payments as they were using application programming interfaces (APIs) provided by Yes Bank.

Also, Yes Bank has 92,065 point of sale (PoS) terminals (card swipe machines), which cannot be used due to the moratorium. Thus, merchants that have only Yes Bank PoS machines have not been able to accept card payments.

Title: Coronavirus cases in Pune: 3 of family, co-traveller, cab driver
Content:
Pune

Three from a family, co-traveller & cabby test Covid-19 positive

: The daughter of the couple who tested positive for coronavirus , one of their cotravellers from a group of 40 on the Dubai tour they went for on February 23, and the cab driver who drove the family from Mumbai to Pune on March 1 when they returned, were among the five confirmed Covid-19 cases in Pune on Tuesday.The 27-year-old co-traveller is a resident of Sinhagad Road and the 43-year-old cab driver is from Manjari Budruk in Pune.District collector Naval Kishor Ram on Tuesday said there are five confirmed cases of coronavirus in Pune . The health of all five is stable, he added. A health official said they have fever, sore throats and headaches, but are recovering.The couple, who live on Sinhagad Road in Pune, were the first two travellers who tested positive for the contagion a day after they were quarantined at Naidu Hospital in Pune on Monday.“We have quarantined the couple's daughter, their 18-year-old son who did not travel to Dubai, and two co-travellers who are residents of Pune,” a civic health official told TOI.Of the two co-travellers, the Sinhagad Road resident tested positive for the infection. He is originally from Yavatmal, he added. The second co-traveller is a 24-year-old man from Hadapsar. He, and the couple's son, have tested negative for the infection.Another civic health official said, “After returning from Dubai, the couple's daughter was travelling around in her father's car. He already had symptoms like fever, cough and a sore throat. The daughter is an IT professional and works in a software company in Pune.”Health officials on Tuesday traced the 36 other co-travellers who were part of the group that visited Dubai and returned to Mumbai by flight on March 1. “None of them have any symptoms,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate told TOI.Three of the 36 co-travellers are from Belagavi in Karnataka. The rest are residents of Mumbai, Pune, Pimpri Chinchwad, Thane, Ahmednagar, Beed, Nagpur, Raigad and Yavatmal.“We have advised them home isolation for 14 days. Health officials in their districts will monitor them. Those who develop symptoms will be isolated at the designated hospital in their districts and tested for the coronavirus infection at Pune-based National Institute of Virology,” Awate added.He said they have informed Karnataka health officials about the three travellers from Belagavi.Divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar said a five member team of revenue, health, police departments and authorities from Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad municipal corporations will monitor the people who have interacted with the Covid-19 infected persons. “Any person from their office or their neighbourhood showing any symptoms will be tested,” he added.The district administration has readied 21 places with 207 beds for patients. “We do not want to create panic. Our team will handle the situation as we have the data,’’ Mhaisekar added.The divisional commissioner has told Indian Medical Association members to keep records of foreign travel history of their patients and report to the district administration if they come across such persons. “We have directed IMA office-bearers that they should sensitise doctors to immediately report to us such cases,’’he said.

Title: Rajinikanth: Periyar comment row;Case against Rajinikanth dismissed
Content:
Actor Rajinikanth

CHENNAI: Actor Rajinikanth scored his first major win in a court of law, when a magistrate court refused to categorise his statement on social reformer EVR Periyar as 'hate speech' and dismissed a petition seeking registration of a criminal case against him.

The petition to register a case against Rajinikanth was filed by Dravidar Viduthalai Kazhagam (DVK).

Dismissing the plea, Roslyn Durai, metropolitan magistrate-II at Egmore, observed that the alleged speech of the actor is at best defamatory which constitutes an offence under Sections 499 and 500 of IPC.

"Defamation is non-cognizable, and maintainable as private complaint. In this circumstance, this court finds that no grounds are made out for concluding offences Sections 153 A, 504 and 505 IPC are attracted, and the petitioner can file private complaint for defamation, damages, and compensation, if so advised."

Recording the contentions of the petitioner, the magistrate said: "On hearing the audio CD recording of the speech of Rajinikanth, made on January 14, it is seen that he has stated what he thought was a fact, about a rally held in Salem in 1971, by Thanthai Periyar, and which according to him was also published in a weekly magazine of that period."

As for the Supreme Court order submitted by the complainant's side to prove that Rajinikanth's speech was indeed a hate speech, the magistrate said: "There is no similarity between the type of speech dealt with in the decision of Supreme Court in Shamit Sanyal case and the speech of the actor. The speech in the cited decision encouraged the followers of the orator to breach law and commit offences. Whereas the speech of actor, is at best defamatory."

Title: ED slaps Rs 5 crore fine on Shriram group company
Content:
CHENNAI: Shriram Transport Finance Company on Tuesday said a penalty of Rs 5 crore has been imposed on the company by the Enforcement Directorate.

The company said it had received a notice in relation to issue of warrants by erstwhile Shriram Holdings (Madras) Pvt Ltd (SHMPL), which was amalgamated with STFC in April 2012, to a person resident outside India in 2006.

The company represented itself with relevant information and facts that it was of the bona fide view that it had not contravened any of the provisions of the Foreign Exchange Management Act.

Title: Delhi Riots News: Lok Sabha to discuss Delhi riots today
Content:
Riot-hit Chand Bagh area of east Delhi

NEW DELHI: The Lok Sabha will discuss the Delhi riots on Wednesday under Rule 193 of the house proceedings which means there will be no voting after the debate.

The Congress had long been pressing for the discussion and disrupted the house's functioning but the government maintained that they will only discuss the issue after Holi .

Even as the pandemonium continued in the lower house, the Speaker suspended 7 Congress MPs for the rest of the session.

The Lok Sabha bulletin says that Congress leader in house, Adhir Ranjan Choudhury, and BJP member "to raise a discussion on the recent law and order situation in some parts of Delhi".

Apart from this, the Congress is likely to raise the issue of the MP turmoil while senior leader Digvijaya Singh has said that he has ample proof that chartered flights were booked by BJP to fly rebel MLAs to Bengaluru.

Civil Aviation Minister Hardeep Singh Puri will introduce the The Aircraft (Amendment) Bill, 2020 for consideration and passage while the lower house will also discuss the grants for three ministries including Health and External Affairs.

--IANS

miz/vd

Title: Leipzig cruise past Spurs into Champions League quarters
Content:
(AFP photo)

LEIPZIG: Tottenham crashed out of the Champions League as RB Leipzig cruised to a 3-0 win on Tuesday to progress to the quarter-finals for the first time 4-0 on aggregate.

Leipzig captain Marcel Sabitzer struck twice in the first 21 minutes to put the tie to bed before substitute Emil Forsberg added the third late on with his first touch.

Unlike many fixtures across Europe this week, there were no restrictions on supporters attending due to the spread of coronavirus and the Leipzig fans were able to enjoy a nerve-free evening.

Spurs travelled to eastern Germany shorn of striking options without the injured Harry Kane, Son Heung-min and Steven Bergwijn.

However, it was at the other end that they buckled inside the opening quarter of the game as two errors from Hugo Lloris in goal turned a tough task into an impossible one.

Mourinho left club record signing Tanguy Ndombele on the bench after publicly criticising the French midfielder's desire in Saturday's 1-1 draw at Burnley, but the switch to a 3-4-3 formation did little to prevent Spurs' winless streak in all competitions stretching to six games.

Leipzig took just 10 minutes to open the scoring when Lloris did not get a strong enough right hand to stop Sabitzer's strike from outside the box finding the bottom corner.

Timo Werner then fired home from close range only to be denied by the offside flag as Leipzig opened up the Tottenham defence at will.

And the visitors did not learn their lesson as Serge Aurier was caught napping by a purposeful burst from Angelino.

The Manchester City loanee's cross was met by a powerful header by Sabitzer, but Lloris should still have done better to keep the ball out at his near post.

Lloris did make some measure of amends by saving from Werner and Patrik Schick to keep the score down before half-time, while at the other end Peter Gulasci was finally forced into action by Erik Lamela.

Spurs produced a remarkable fightback from 3-0 down on aggregate away at Ajax in last season's semi-finals to make the final for the first time in the club's history thanks to Lucas Moura's hat-trick.

But in keeping with their collapse since that night in Amsterdam last May, Mourinho's men lacked the quality and belief needed to reproduce that thrilling fightback.

Moura was again the one source of inspiration as he teed up Dele Alli for Spurs' best chance of the night, but the England midfielder's mishit effort was easily saved by Gulasci.

Forsberg was more clinical just 32 seconds after replacing Sabitzer to fire into the far corner three minutes from time.

Tottenham's season now hinges on refinding their form in the Premier League if they are not to miss out on the Champions League for the first time in five years.

Spurs are languishing in eighth in the Premier League, seven points adrift of the top four, and in desperate need for Mourinho to exact revenge on Manchester United for his sacking last season when the Red Devils visit north London on Sunday.

Title: Joe Biden: Former Vice President of United States Joe Biden grip on Democratic nomination tightens with big wins
Content: DETROIT: Joe Biden took a vice-like grip on the Democratic nomination race Tuesday with big primary wins in Michigan and other states confirming his growing advantage over leftist Bernie Sanders in the contest to take on President Donald Trump.First US networks projected a huge victory in Mississippi for Biden, reflecting his popularity among strategically vital African American voters. Then came Missouri and, biggest of all, Michigan -- one of the industrial Midwestern giants due to be a key battleground in the general election."Thank you Michigan!" tweeted Biden, still waiting for results from three more states holding primaries before the night was over.Barring major surprises, Biden now eyes a strong path to becoming the Democrats' candidate in the bruising and deeply divisive November polls.But if the veteran centrist and former vice president under Barack Obama might increasingly shift focus on trying to make Trump a one-term president, Sanders' next step remains a big question.Will he fight on to the bitter end, as he did four years ago against the eventual nominee Hillary Clinton? Or will he bow out early?Many Democrats blame the uncompromising, self-declared democratic socialist for subjecting Clinton to friendly fire just as she was struggling -- ultimately unsuccessfully -- against the Trump insurgency.Adding to nerves in a country on edge after three tumultuous years under Trump, fears of the coronavirus epidemic prompted both campaigns to cancel election-night rallies.Organizers of a live television debate scheduled Sunday, pitting the fiery Sanders and the moderate Biden, likewise said they would take the extraordinary step of not allowing the usual live audience.For Biden, Tuesday's six-state contest, coming a week after his surprise comeback in voting on Super Tuesday, demonstrated that his once shambolic campaign is in rude health and now ready to face Trump.Michigan in particular -- an industrial giant that Trump won in an upset in 2016 -- was targeted by Biden as a place to put down a marker ahead of the November election.Sanders accused Biden of selling out to corporate interests and ignoring a passionate leftist base.But the former vice president has insisted on steering a centrist line that he says can bring the divided country back together -- and it appears to have paid off.Banking on his credibility as Obama's vice president, he has managed to get out an enthusiastic black vote.But with stories of a hard-knock childhood in Pennsylvania and Delaware frequently featuring in his speeches, Biden also wants to recapture the blue collar white voters that Trump successfully poached from the Democrats in 2016."Biden is putting together the traditional Democratic coalition, and that's still a very powerful one," said Julian Zelizer, a professor of political history at Princeton University and media pundit.Early Tuesday, Biden began his final push by meeting workers at an under-construction automobile plant in Detroit, where he received cheers but also was confronted by one worker.In a startling exchange, the worker, wearing a construction helmet and reflective vest, accused Biden of seeking to take away Americans' firearms."You're full of shit," an angry Biden shot back, insisting that he supports the constitutional right to bear arms."I'm not taking your gun away," he said in the encounter, which Trump supporters quickly pointed to as evidence of Biden's inability to stand pressure -- but supporters saw as a show of mettle."Gimme a break, man," Biden added.Voters came out under the growing shadow of the global coronavirus epidemic, which has infected over 900 people across the United States and killed 28.Sanders and Biden called off customary election-night rallies -- both planned in Cleveland, part of another Rust Belt state, Ohio, which votes next week -- in line with public health warnings from state officials.Their precaution is at odds with Trump, who has vowed to keep holding his campaign's sometimes raucous rallies despite the concerns.Washington state, which has borne the brunt of the crisis and also was going to the polls Tuesday, votes entirely by mail -- an option some experts say should become more widespread as the epidemic grows.Idaho and North Dakota were also voting.Artist and designer Cecilia Covington, 61, was the first person to vote in Precinct 123 in downtown Detroit, braving the drizzle as she arrived at Chrysler Elementary School to vote for Biden."When he wasn't doing well in the polls I was really concerned," she said, adding that his stunning comeback on Super Tuesday "put my confidence back.""We've got to get '45' out of office," she said, referring to the current president.On Super Tuesday, Biden won 10 out of 14 states that voted, giving him a healthy lead even before the latest round of primaries.

Title: New Tallah plan faces workday test in Kolkata
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The new traffic flow from BT Road towards Shyambazar — hours before the first big test on Wednesday (schools and offices reopen after dol and holi breaks) — operated smoothly. With the new traffic flow, introduced with the opening of the rail level crossing at Chitpore, the Lockgate flyover is being used in the reverse direction — north to south.

The flyover was earlier being used for south-to-north traffic flow and locals had demanded a shift in traffic flow in the morning rush hours. Lalbazar indicated it would monitor the traffic flow for the next two weeks. The possibility of making the traffic tidal has not been ruled out yet. “We want to ensure that no student is inconvenienced during their board exams. With HS exams barely about a week away, we will not go for too many experiments,” explained an officer at Lalbazar.

“Now, for the northward journey, the smaller vehicles take Cossipore Road and buses Railway Service Road (Chitpore level crossing) for BT Road. For southward journey, buses and small vehicles take Lockgate flyover for C R Avenue or Shyambazar. In this way, we have reduced snarls on RG Kar Bridge,” said an officer.

The cops, though, are not yet diverting the buses or trucks to Brajadayal Shah Road and onwards to Strand Bank Road and Khagen Chatterjee Road. “Some expansion work is yet to be completed on Khagen Chatterjee Road that is expected to handle heavy traffic at night,” said police.

“Once it’s over, trucks can use Strand Bank Road and reach the commercial hubs of central Kolkata. The pressure on Cossipore Road will also ease. As of now, as a precautionary measure, we are not allowing vehicle movement on Lockgate flyover after 12 midnight till morning,” explained an officer from Shyambazar traffic guard.

Khagen Chatterjee Road – when fully operational — will connect Braja Dayal Shah Road located next to Cossipore Bridge with Sethpukur Road and Pranakrishna Mukherjee Road on Bagbazar side. “Trucks can use this to enter Chitpore terminal and then move towards Burrabazar and Posta using the Strand Bank Road that goes up to Armenian Ghat,” said an officer.

Title: Gender sensitization training for bus drivers, conductors in Kolkata
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The cops will train hundreds of bus drivers and conductors on gender sensitization. The police will include both government and private transport workers in this project. Auto, app-cab and taxi drivers, too, will be given the same training.

Money from Nirbhaya fund, which aims at making commuting in Kolkata safer for women, will be used for the purpose.

The decision has been taken in the wake of some recent incidents at Ruby crossing, Garden Reach and Jodhpur Park where women commuters were either physically assaulted or molested by their male co-passengers.

The training will also be a part of Kolkata Police ’s “Respect Women” movement that is likely to be officially launched on Wednesday, along with the closing ceremony of ‘Tejaswini’ workshop.

“We will be sensitising the transport workers on how to respect women and will cover all aspects of gender equality. A key concern area here will be how to make a woman comfortable while she is travelling,” said joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma .

The training is likely to be organized over the weekend in batches and the best performers are likely to be rewarded. “Twenty-five traffic guards will be involved,” said an officer.
